PETITION.TITLE: Gambling Casino, Canberra
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Gambling Casino, Canberra

To the Honourable The President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: That the establishment of a gambling casino in Canberra would debase the National Capital and increase crime in Canberra.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should seek to preserve the dignity of the National Capital by disallowing any ordinance to authorise the establishment of a gambling casino in Canberra.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination Against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The President, and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that 'The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State'. And whereas the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1).
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women; Believing that its implementation would result in:
(1) Undue cost to the Nation at this time.

(2) 'The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels' as described in Part 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

(3) The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in Article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
(4) The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our Nation and your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Peter Baume (from 77 citizens), Jack Evans (from 111 citizens), Peter Rae (from 46 citizens), Robertson (from 86 citizens), and Watson (from 18 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Adelaide to Darwin Railway
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That in 1911, as part of its new responsibility for the Northern Territory, the Commonwealth accepted a binding legislative commitment to construct a railway from Adelaide to Darwin-a promise which has never been fulfilled.
The lack of essential transport links has had, and continues to have, serious consequences for the economic and social development of the Northern Territory, and indeed all of Australia.

That the future expansion of new industries in the Territory and new trade opportunities for Australia, particularly with South-East Asia and the Western Pacific, depend on the development of the railway to link the port of Darwin with the rest of Australia. The railway is therefore an essential national project related directly to Australia's overall prospects for future economic growth.
We therefore protest the Commonwealth's continuing failure to construct the railway.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Prime Minister and members of the Federal Government honour the promise made by the Commonwealth over 70 years ago , the promise made by the previous Commonwealth Government this year, and endorsed by the present Government in opposition to complete the construction of the railway by 1988, Australia's bicentennial year. We call on the Prime Minister to give his personal assurance that the Commonwealth will honour its past and present promises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination Against Women
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:

The Universal Declaration of Human Rights affirms the principle of the inadmissibility of discrimination and proclaims that all human beings are born free and equal in dignity and rights and that everyone is entitled to all the rights and freedoms set forth therein, without distinction of any kind including distinction based on sex.

However extensive discrimination against women continues to exist. It is an obstacle to the participation of women on equal terms with men, in the political , social, economic and cultural life of this country. It hampers the growth of the prosperity of society and the family and makes more difficult the full development of the potentialities of women in the service of this country and of humanity.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government will act to ratify the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL COMMITTEE FOR THE EVALUATION OF THE YOUTH SERVICES SCHEME

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-For the information of honourable senators I present the report of the National Committee for the Evaluation of the Youth Services Scheme. The report is titled 'One Step Forward' Youth Homelessness and Emergency Accommodation Services. The Youth Services Scheme is a program providing joint Commonwealth and State funding for services providing emergency accommodation and support for homeless youth. The Commonwealth funding is being provided under the Children's Services Program. During 1979-1982 the program operated on a pilot basis, and funding was extended for this financial year pending the completion of this report and the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare, which was tabled in Parliament last August.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government now has at hand two substantial reports on youth homelessness, and is carefully examining them in the process of making decisions for future assistance in this area. The evaluation of the Youth Services Scheme was conducted by a committee of officials representing Commonwealth and State governments, and reporting to all the Ministers involved. As required by the Committee's brief, the report focusses entirely on the Youth Services Scheme, and the assistance it was or was not able to provide for homeless youth. It is not a general research document on youth homelessness as such, nor does it provide a comparative analysis of other methods of assistance to the homeless supported by other programs of the States or the Commonwealth.

The principal focus of the report is on the youth who used the services, assessing their common situations, their needs, and the degree to which the Youth Services Scheme, as established within its guidelines, was able to meet these needs. The conclusions and recommendations concentrate on the type and level of demand, the needs of the youth, including preventive measures to reduce homelessness, and the features seen as required in future guidelines of any national program of accommodation services to improve the ability to respond effectively to the needs of the youth, and to make national administration more efficient. The recommendations are not drafted as a policy document ready for implementation, but rather suggest parameters and essential features for inclusion in a future policy document.

The report itself contains a summary (on pages 2 to 7). Briefly, the main findings of the Evaluation Committee are that: The scheme as established was not able to meet all the continuing demand for emergency accommodation. Reasons suggested for this are the volume of demand and the number of youth remaining in accommodation for extended periods. The Committee estimated that for about half the users the principal need was for long term accommodation-that is, independent housing. There is a significant demand from young adults in the age range 19 years to 25 years not covered by the guidelines for the Scheme. A recommendation is that the eligible age range be extended in a future funding scheme. The youths predominantly lack support from their families for a variety of reasons, and when this is combined, as it almost invariably is, with unemployment, the youths' ability to attain independence is hindered, rendering them homeless.

Recommendations cover the need for employment opportunities for youth, so they may achieve independence, and for improved support for families with adolescents , to help them provide a more supportive environment for the youth. A new expanded youth accommodation program is recommended and it is suggested that a program which can better respond to youth homelessness needs to have three components in an integrated network on a regional basis, namely: A front line of emergency accommodation services; a secondary group of services accepting referrals from the frontline services, providing medium to long term supportive accommodation, and services providing assistance in obtaining housing; and a third group providing services directed at the needs of the younger and particularly disadvantaged-that is, those who are handicapped or who have health problems, or institutionalised youth.

Recommendations covering administration of the recommended new, expanded program suggest continued Commonwealth and State involvement in funding, with the Commonwealth component provided through specific purpose block grants to the States. The report emphasises the need for employment and adequate income for unemployed youth as a means of preventing longer term homelessness.

As the Senate is aware, job creation programs are a high priority for this Government, and we will be moving as soon as possible to get the programs under way. It is our hope that these will go a long way to redress some of the problems highlighted by this report. It is also Government policy that the young unemployed living away from home and all unemployed people renting privately should be paid supplementary rent assistance. The Government is concerned that young people should have the opportunity through schooling, or other technical and further education or community courses, to have appropriate training before attempting to enter the work force, but, of course, for those unable to obtain work, the income benefits should be adequate to allow them to live with dignity. This Government will be establishing a task force to examine the programs currently available which provide educational allowances and other income support for 15 to 24-year-olds. We see this as an area in need of urgent review, and we will be examining this report and other information closely in this regard.

The Youth Services Scheme is presently being examined as part of a review of all Commonwealth crisis accommodation programs. This review was instigated by the previous Government in 1982 and it is being undertaken jointly by the Department of Housing and Construction and the Department of Social Security. It is expected to be completed in August 1983. I will also be consulting with my colleague the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) on matters which relate to her portfolio.

The recommendations contained in 'One Step Forward' and the Report of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare, 'Youth Homelessness', will be considered in the crisis accommodation review. The Government will not be responding separately to these reports until decisions are announced following consideration of the review. Pending finalisation of decisions relating to the long term, the Government is giving urgent attention to the immediate funding requirements of the services; as honourable senators will be aware current funding is approved only until 30 June 1983. I hope to be in a position to make a statement about this matter shortly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the Paper.

Very briefly, as the report of the National Committee for the Evaluation of the Youth Services Scheme has only just reached my hands, I have not had an opportunity even to look at it except to acknowledge the points made in the speech by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes). Several of the points, I think, are highly relevant. The problems of homeless youth comprise one of the most significant areas of need in this community at present. This matter has been gaining a great deal of prominence and attention not only from community workers but also from the media and certainly from members of the Senate. Of course, that has been evidenced by the work of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare in this area, and the worth of its report brought down last year has been acknowledged in all quarters. Apart from that, at the moment the Standing Committee on Social Welfare is engaged in an ongoing inquiry into institutionalised care for homeless youth. No doubt that will add further to the weight of evidence in this area.

I am glad that the Minister has seen fit to release the report and to bring us up to date with his thinking in this regard. Indeed, several of the thoughts that he has acknowledged in his statement today are the kinds of points that we would want to see developed in his forthcoming discussions with the States in relation to funding. Certainly many matters require urgent attention. I am pleased that he is undertaking an early review of this matter and that we will not be waiting for further reports from the Government in this area before decisions are taken. We look forward to immediate action and I will be watching very closely the steps the Government takes as a result of this report.

Many of the interlocking matters that were mentioned by the Minister in his statement, such as those relating to training and education, are of the deepest concern and the Opposition gives its support in regard to the way in which the Minister will approach further negotiations with the States. I see that the Minister intends to underake further discussions with his colleague the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan). That area is of critical concern when dealing with this problem. I hope that we will be kept up to date on the Minister's thinking and on the development of policies not only in the Department of Social Security but also in the Department of Education and Youth Affairs. As regards the task force that the Minister will establish to review this matter, and in particular with regard to income support, I hope that he will make available to the Opposition from time to time access to that task force so that we may obtain information. I also hope he will ask for input from the Opposition into this vital area. I look forward to working with him on that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note very briefly the importance of the report of the National Committee for the Evaluation of the Youth Services Scheme which has been tabled by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes), dealing as it does with youth homelessness and the provision of emergency accommodation. Those of us who yesterday met with some of the several hundred young people who came to Parliament House to press their concern upon us would be well aware of how dire the situation is in which those young people find themselves. Having read the report briefly, it is not surprising that it establishes that the scheme is not able to meet all the continuing demands for emergency accommodation. Indeed, in a situation of continuing distressingly high levels of unemployment, particularly in the younger age categories, one can understand that the problem has been exacerbated in the present economic conditions rather than being in any way ameliorated by a generally more bouyant situation in the economy. I have had only a very brief chance to look at the report and I notice that on page 79, after citing some figures, the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: This is a clear demonstration that often a youth may suffer from lack of support from the family, which precipitates an accommodation crisis for the youth, but when this is also combined with inability to gain employment and an income to support himself, the lack of the employment becomes the primary problem for the youth, and the temporary crisis is exacerbated and often perpetuated.

So while it is a fact that family breakdown and virtual eviction from the home under the tensions and strains that might be in the household are the initial causes of the homelesness, it is quite clear that unless problems relating to income support for these homeless youths are addressed by way of social security benefit-one would hope in the long term by the provision of employment opportunities-then we will have the continuing cycle of young people being so inadequately supported by the community, as I say either by the provision of benefits or jobs, that they will almost inevitably drift into that sub-culture where drug taking and prostitution become a means of either escape or alleviating some of the financial hardship and distress in which those young people find themselves.

I am surprised to see that the report says that there is a significant demand by young adults in the age range of 19 to 25 years. My impression from talking to refuge workers and young people who came to see us yesterday was that the age groups which are now going into refuges are becoming lower. In fact, I was informed that it is not uncommon to have 15-year-olds and 14-year-olds going to refuges. Of course, if the accommodation cannot be provided by the refuge, 15- year-old girls in particular are finding themselves drifting into other forms of association in order to get the shelter, care and sustenance which they require.

I notice with pleasure that the Minister in his response says that income benefits should be adequate to allow such homeless youths to live with dignity. Indeed, unless that is the case we can hardly claim to be a civilised, fair and just society, let alone a compassionate society when confronted with this distressing phenomenon in our midst.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you any rough estimate of the number of homeless youth?
—I have not been able to determine that.
—It does not appear to be in the report either.

—It does not appear to be in the report but I am sure that the Minister by interjection could help me to answer the honourable senator's question. I notice that there is a recognition in the report of the need for financial assistance to young people who go into emergency shelters or refuges in order to enable them to go into other forms of housing. Indeed, it was found that for over 70 per cent of the youth who required this financial assistance to enable them to go into rental accommodation such as boarding houses or other forms of accommodation such assistance is just not available because when the service was set up it was not anticipated that the shelters or refuges would need to have a cash reserve to enable them to help young people after a period of weeks in the shelter to move into other types of accommodation. That, of course, just compounds the distressing situation of young people who live in the refuges endlessly rather than moving into other types of accommodation such as boarding house and low rental accommodation. The availability of small cash subsidies to enable this to occur would be most helpful.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like previous speakers, I have not yet had the time to read in any depth the report of the National Committee for the Evaluation of the Youth Services Scheme. This is not a new problem. I recall speaking to the Senate last year on the question of homeless youth and homeless families. I cited a number of cases that had been drawn to my attention in my home State of young people in their mid-teens who were reduced to living in abandoned cars and bus shelters and moving from place to place to avoid being apprehended by the law-often of course, for their own good. It is, as has been said, a tragedy that family breakdowns, social pressures and, in some instances, the absolute abdication of parental responsibility should lead to the sort of situation that produces these reports. Nevertheless, we must acknowledge that unpalatable fact. Governments have to act, if they are at all to be seen as responsible governments, to mitigate as much as possible the disastrous consequences of this situation.

SPEECH.PARA: We need to supply suitable and adequate emergency and long term accommodation that is readily accessible to those young people who are in need when they need it and not a week or two later, when it could well be too late. We need to provide adequate and suitable community support services which are palatable as well as accessible to the young people in need. Of course, we need to provide funding that will allow us to set up those services and that accommodation. The Youth Services Scheme which the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) mentioned on the first page of his statement is a commendable program, but it is only a short term program. We must incorporate in our planning some long term preventive measures as well as the curative actions we have taken to date. It is therefore pleasing to see on page 4 of the Minister's statement that the Government recognises the vital importance of job creation schemes for young people and, I am hopeful, the permanent types of job creation schemes that are needed, not the one-off type which eliminate a problem only for a short period. There is no doubt that the provision of jobs is essential if we are to go any way at all towards curing the problem of homeless youth.

I was interested to note the comment on page 4 of the Minister's statement with regard to the payment of supplementary rent assistance to unemployed young people who are renting privately. This, of course, has been the Australian Democrats' policy for a considerable number of years. I hope that it is a hint of what may be announced in today's mini-Budget. If not, I ask, why it is not provided. The Minister goes on to say that income benefits should be adequate to allow people in this predicament to live with dignity. Again, I remind the Minister of some comments I made a week ago about the discrepancy that exists between the unemployment benefit and the poverty line. The Minister said at the time that it was admirable for that gap to be closed. But I wonder when it will be closed, since no real action on income support for young people has been undertaken since the Commission of Inquiry into Poverty said it was an urgent necessity some five or more years ago. I hope that the action that the Minister says will be taken some time between now and 30 June, which is only six weeks away, will be undertaken after the Government has consulted with the National Youth Coalition for Housing and the major youth organisation, the Youth Affairs Council of Australia. Only when the needs and knowledge of those organisations are taken into account will any satisfactory result occur with regard to youth housing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse the remarks that have been made by previous speakers. The extent of youth homelessness that exists is, indeed, a national tragedy and a scandal. Of course, I am not surprised that there is some debate and doubt about the actual numbers, because in actual fact there has only been a limited study of the number of young people affected. Of course, it is very difficult area to determine just how many young people are affected. I would like to see urgent consideration given to increasing the benefit for those under the age of 18. It is obvious from the report of the National Committee for the Evaluation of the Youth Services Scheme that the under 18 age group is severely disadvantaged, particularly in the current economic climate in which employment opportunities are few. This group, of course, needs realistic income support. We need job creation schemes directed specifically to this age group. Obviously, rental assistance is important. But if we can provide job opportunities for young people, they could achieve independence without rent supplements.

SPEECH.PARA: A point I make in regard to the emergency housing program is that we must give an assurance and a guarantee of funding. I know that in Queensland too frequently we find that organisations do not know when their next grant will be available. There is an overbureaucratisation of finance handling. Organisations which are usually dependent on voluntary assistance are completely confused about when additional financial grants will be forthcoming. This seriously jeopardises very good emergency programs.

Another thing I would like to mention is the report's concern with family support. This is obviously a much more complex issue than I can go into on this occasion. We are living in times of grave uncertainty. It is very simple to say that more families should support young people, but it is another thing to ensure that this in fact happens. Obviously any innovative program that can give increased counselling to families who are having difficulty in regard to their young people would be welcome. But I think we have to realise that this is a very complex issue and that the greater need is for job creation and independence for young people. Senator Susan Ryan has foreshadowed this Government's interest in innovative programs such as communes which could provide both job opportunities and housing.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much do you think the Government should put into all these programs?

—I was merely looking at ideas that I think the Government must further investigate. It is a great pity that the present Opposition did not spend the last seven years investigating such programs. The final thing I would like to say is that I think it is well to highlight the numbers of young, homeless people who are drifting north in the hope of finding job opportunities in Queensland. Far be it from me to suggest that they are not welcome in Queensland, but I certainly emphasise that the job situation in Queensland is very serious. Any young people who think that life might be easier up there will find that it is in fact much more difficult for a number of reasons. Obviously there is the Queensland Government's attitude to a whole range of issues but also many young people find that it is difficult to get their social welfare benefits transferred. There are delays, and they actually find that they are not able to find work and they do not have the family support that they may have in the areas from which they come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to make some comments on the statement put down by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes). I was a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare which investigated the problems of homeless youth. We found that many of the problems were derived from the fact that families had insufficient means to support their children. I believe it is that stage-before young people have to leave home because of financial reasons-which should be taken care of. If more support was given to the family structure we would have less homeless youth on the streets. It is an impossible situation when homeless youth are out on the streets. They cannot obtain employment. If they have no home and no base to work from it is impossible to gain employment.

SPEECH.PARA: In the past we have looked to the family. We have provided homes for regular families and the elderly and now we are providing homes for single parents, but we do not provide homes for young people. Senator Chipp asked how many young people out on the streets are homeless. Nobody in this country could give an accurate figure. A large number is double counted, but we do know that the number is immense and the problem is increasing. I think that governments should take very firm action. If the problems increase in the future they will be so immense that we will not be able to cure them. I believe that when families get into difficulty family structures should be supported so that parents will be able to afford to keep their children.

There are many causes of youth homelessness but one of the main causes is poverty. We should all address ourselves to that situation. I believe that young people should be given a guarantee of work. Young people finishing their education have no opportunity to enter the work force. They get into bad habits such as drug taking, prostitution, and all the rest of it. If young people were given a guarantee of work rather than the Government working out how much unemployment benefit to pay them, there would be fewer problems. Governments in the future should look seriously at this problem. In places such as Japan no legislation is laid down, but it is traditional that young people are employed. When one goes into an hotel one finds that half a dozen young people try to give one service. If this attitude were adopted in this country we would have fewer problems.

It is very important for young people, after finishing their educational studies, to get into employment. Even to overemploy people would be far better. If we do not take action now the cost will be immense in the future. We will have all the ills and evils of crime in the community. We have seen this in many countries: Where governments do not take action in particular areas, the problem just festers and multiplies. Sooner or later the whole community must pay. Action taken later is much more costly than action taken earlier. I admire what the Government is attempting to do. I think this is a very serious problem. I believe that action should be taken earlier rather than later. There is a whole range of problems. For example, young people cannot afford to pay the bonds necessary to rent homes. That should be taken into account. If we have some sensible solutions this problem would most certainly be overcome to the benefit of all concerned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare, which looked at this problem of homeless youth. As Senator Elstob has already said, we were unable to get any figures on the number of homeless youth throughout Australia. The surveys that were done were far from accurate. Surveys were done in most States but their multiplying effect rendered the figures completely unusable. Not only did the surveys involve double and treble counting-sometimes the figures were even counted six or seven times-but also they did not take into account those homeless youth who were in the first stages of homelessness, living with friends-perhaps in another family situation- or perhaps even sleeping in parks-sleeping rough, as it is called. So the figures were completely useless to the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: We found that the typical homeless youth came from a background of family breakdown or from a one-parent family-either a single mother or after a divorce. We found that the average homeless youth had been more or less discarded by the family for security's sake: The mother would become involved in another relationship and, if the children were incompatible, they seemed to be discarded . The Committee was even told of a case of two very young people coming home from school to find that their mum and dad had actually moved all their goods and chattels. They had nowhere to go and slept under the school building for a time. It is a tragic situation. In the cases that we had given to us it was a rare occasion when the parents wanted the children back and the children were not going back.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you get any reliable estimates as to numbers?

—None at all. It was impossible. I will give an example. A survey was conducted of all shelters in the Melbourne metropolitan area. The survey was conducted over, roughly, a three-week period, but the results were brought down to a weekly period. Those which replied gave figures of 300 requests for shelter in one week. They multiplied that by 52 and came up with this remarkable figure of 15,000 homeless youth in the metropolitan area. Of course, when we went into it we found that the average stay in a shelter was 1 1 /2 to 2 nights. In other words, the youths moved from shelter to shelter so that one person could be counted four or five times. Therefore, the surveys were extremely inaccurate. As I say, the people who did the survey did not take into account the children in the first stage. When these children moved out of home or were thrown out of home they lived with a friend for a number of nights until the mother of that friend got sick of having them in the home and said: 'You have got to go'. They then slept rough in some of the parks until they heard by word of mouth that there was a shelter down the street that would take them, and so they moved into this area.

SPEECH.PARA: The typical homeless youth came from a family breakdown situation; some family crisis had occurred and the family had broken down. They usually came from a disadvantaged group and, in the majority of cases, they were unemployed. We had situations, as Senator Elstob said, where some of them had held a number of jobs . They said 'I could not do that. It is boring', or 'I am not going to stick to that because I could not put up with it'. When one looks at the jobs they held one wonders whether one could put up with it oneself. I am not being critical, but these young people are not educated enough to realise that they should keep the job. We said: 'If you stick to that job for just a while you will get a better job'. They are not educated enough in the work situation to know that if they stick at one perhaps boring job for a while then the next job might be better.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —As representatives of a community within a civilised society, each one of us must be appalled at the details that are before us in this report 'One step forward. Youth Homelessness and Emergency Accommodation Services'. That report has only just come into the hands of honourable senators. Therefore I, as well as other honourable senators, have not had an opportunity of thoroughly studying the report and considering the implications of it.
—Why don't you set the debate aside for another day?

—I am going to. I will seek to continue my remarks in a very short time. I want to say two very short things in support of what Senator Elstob and Senator Walters said. It is clear from my cursory glance at the report that what those two honourable senators have said, with their experience in the field, is correct. Clearly, financial pressures are experienced in the homes from which many of the youth come, and the typical homeless youth comes from a family breakdown situation. In respect of those two issues we should ensure that economic policies are designed not, as they are now, to force a situation in which people must almost have a two-income family to live at a reasonable standard, but to ensure that a family is able to live with dignity on one income. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

DEBATE.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION INTO THE USE OF CHEMICAL AGENTS IN VIETNAM

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The involvement of Australian service personnel in the war in Vietnam has led to concern among veterans of that war and their families that ill health and other related problems which they have experienced since discharge from the forces may have their origins in that service in Vietnam. In particular, many feel that their disabilities may be related to exposure to certain chemicals used by the Allied forces in Vietnam, in particular the phenoxy herbicide agent orange, and other herbicides, insecticides and chemical irritants. In recent years considerable public disquiet has been raised about this matter, a disquiet shared by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment inquired into this matter and presented a first report in November last year. Notwithstanding the Committee's conclusion, among other things, that it was unlikely that the majority of Australian troops were directly or indirectly exposed to the herbicides used by United States forces in Vietnam, the Government believes that the matter is still not resolved. For this reason, it was decided to establish a Royal Commission to inquire into the effects of the use of chemical agents, including herbicides and other pesticides, on Australian personnel who served in Vietnam.

I publicly announced the details of the inquiry at the fourth Annual Congress of the Vietnam Veterans Association on Saturday, 14 May. Honourable senators will no doubt have read newspaper reports on this. The inquiry will be chaired by the Honourable Mr Justice Phillip George Evatt, D.S.C., a judge of the Federal Court of Australia. Mr Justice Evatt, I might add was first appointed to judicial office in 1974. He served in the Royal Australian Naval Volunteer Reserve during the Second World War. He is well qualified to serve as Royal Commissioner. Mr Justice Evatt will commence work on the Royal Commission once he has discharged his present judicial commitments. He will be assisted by senior counsel.

The terms of reference are purposefully wide and comprehensive so that as many relevant matters as possible can be canvassed by the Commission. They were drawn up in close consultation with the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia so that its concerns would be addressed by the Commission. The Returned Services League has expressed some concern with the terms. In the light of these concerns I should stress to the Senate that the Royal Commission in no way threatens the rights and benefits currently offered to ex-service men and women. In general the terms of reference require the Royal Commission to look at and report on the use of chemical agents in Vietnam, the effect of any exposure to such chemicals on Australian personnel, the operation and administration of the repatriation legislation as it applies to claims regarding chemical related disabilities and the adequacy of current Government assistance afforded to Vietnam veterans.

The Royal Commissioner's attention has been drawn specifically to the following matters: The conditions under which Australians served in Vietnam; the details of the chemical agents used; the time and place of their use; the adequacy of safety precautions in their use; the toxic properties of the chemicals; their effects upon humans and the extent and duration of exposure necessary to have such effects; evidence of the effects on the mental and physical health and well -being of veterans and their spouses; the possible extent to which chemical exposure may have caused congenital anomalies; and the extent of safety precautions in the disposal of unused chemicals.

The Royal Commission has a formidable task in front of it. It will be a broad- ranging inquiry involving extensive consideration of written material, oral evidence and divergent opinions on many issues, including on medical matters. The material to be studied includes records held in Australia concerning the use of chemical agents in Vietnam and the conditions of service there generally. There is also a large body of medical literature to be examined. There are relevant studies to be considered, both in Australia and overseas, many of which are not yet finalised. The Royal Commission has full powers to summon witnesses and documents and to take evidence under oath in the conduct of its inquiry. An important part of the Commission's work will be in hearing the evidence presented on behalf of Vietnam veterans and their families. Witnesses will have statutory protection concerning their evidence.

Legal and other assistance will also be given to the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia to ensure relevant matters are able to be presented properly to the Commission. Consultants will be appointed to assist the Royal Commission in relation to the scientific, medical and other issues before it. The governments of the United States of America, New Zealand and Vietnam, all of which have an interest in this matter, have been informed of the terms of reference of the Commission.

Mr Deputy President, the Government places great importance on the work of the Royal Commission. It is important that, in the interests of all those who served in Vietnam, the concerns of Vietnam veterans and their families should be adjudicated in a high level forum constituted by a judge. I hope the Royal Commission's work will be completed as speedily as possible. Mr Justice Evatt has been asked to report by the end of June 1984.
The matters which the Royal Commission will be required to inquire into and to report on are set out in the Letters Patent.
I move:
That the Senate take note of the statement.
I seek leave to have the letters patent incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
COMMONWEALTH OF AUSTRALIA
ELIZABETH THE SECOND, by the Grace of God Queen of Australia and Her other Realms and Territories, Head of the Commonwealth:
TO THE HONOURABLE PHILLIP GEORGE EVATT DSC, LL.B.
GREETING:

WE DO by these our Letters Patent issued in Our name by Our Governor-General of the Commonwealth of Australia on the advice of the Federal Executive Council and in pursuance of the Constitution of the Commonwealth of Australia, the Royal Commissions Act 1902 and other enabling powers, appoint you to be a Commissioner to inquire for the purposes of the exercise and performance of the powers and functions of the Parliament and Government of the Commonwealth, into the following matters, namely-

(a) the use of chemical agents in the course of hostilities in Vietnam during the period commencing on 31 July 1962 and ending at the expiration of 11 January 1973, insofar as they may have affected Australian personnel;
(b) the effects on Australian personnel of exposure to the chemical agents used ; and

(c) the operation and administration of the Repatriation Act 1920, the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962 and any other relevant Acts, as applicable to claims by Australian personnel of chemical-caused disabilities:
AND, without restricting the scope of your inquiry, We direct you to inquire particularly into the following matters, namely-
(d) the conditions in which Australian personnel served in Vietnam;
(e) the nature, scale, purpose and manner of use of chemical agents;
(f) the periods during which chemical agents were used, the locations of use, their subsequent spread and the location from time to time of Australian personnel;
(g) the extent to which adequate safety precautions were taken and the extent to which adequate action was taken when any possible harmful effect of chemical agents became known;

(h) the toxic properties, resulting from use separately or in combination, in relation to humans of each of the chemical agents used, with particular emphasis on, but not limited to, any direct or indirect carcinogenic, mutagenic, teratogenic or neurotoxic properties and the extent and duration of exposure necessary to affect humans;

(i) evidence relating to the effects of any exposure to chemical agents on the mental and physical health and well-being of Australian personnel and any effects on the mental and physical health and well being of their spouses;
(j) evidence relating to the extent to which exposure to the chemical agents used has resulted in congenital anomalies among the children of Australian personnel;

(k) notwithstanding any limitations contained in paragraph (a), the nature and extent of the safety precautions taken, during the disposal at any time by or on behalf of Australia of surplus chemical agents that were in Vietnam during the period commencing on 31 July 1962 and ending at the expiration of 11January 1973 :
AND We declare that in these Our Letters Patent-

(1) the expression ''Australian personnel'' means any persons, including members of the Australian Defence Force, who were engaged in performing defence service or any other function for or on behalf of Australia in Vietnam, whether as employees or otherwise;
(m) the expression ''chemical agents'' includes any herbicides (including defoliants), insecticides or chemical irritants; and

(n) the expression ''Vietnam'' means the areas specified in the First and Fifth Schedules to the Repartriation (Special Areas) Regulations in force under the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962.

AND We require you to make such recommendations arising out of your inquiry as you think appropriate, including recommendations regarding the legislative or administrative changes, if any, that are necessary or desirable and the adequacy of present assistance available to Australian personnel:

AND, in particular, we require you to make such recommendations as you consider appropriate in relation to assistance which any Government Department may be able to give relating to the health problems of Australian personnel and the power of a Department to grant, and the adequacy of the present method of granting assistance, with a view to ensuring that Australian personnel receive the full benefit of all available assistance:
AND We direct that, in making your inquiry, you have regard to any other matters which may appear to you to be relevant to any of paragraphs (a) to (k) ( inclusive):
AND We further direct that, in making your inquiry, you have regard to the records kept by the Defence Force and to published studies and reports relating to the use and effects of chemical agents:

AND We require you as expeditiously as possible to make your inquiry and, not later than 30 June 1984 or such later date as We may be please to fix, to furnish to Our Governor-General of the Commonwealth of Australia a report of the results of your inquiry and your recommendations.

WITNESS His Excellency the Right Honourable Sir Ninian Martin Stephen, a member of Her Majesty's Most Honourable Privy Council, Knight of the Order of Australia , Knight Grand Cross of the Most Distinguished Order of Saint Michael and Saint George, Knight Grand Cross of the Royal Victorian Order, Knight Commander of the Most Excellent Order of British Empire, Knight of the Most Venerable Order of the Hospital of Saint John of Jerusalem, Governor-General of the Commonwealth of Australia and Commander-in-Chief of the Defence Force.
Dated this Thirteenth day of May 1983.
Governor-General
By His Excellency's Command,
Prime Minister

The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to provide for the winding up of the Christmas Island Phosphate Commission, and the termination of the Christmas Island Agreement with New Zealand. As indicated in the Schedule to the Bill, both the Australian and New Zealand governments have agreed to these changes being made.

Honourable senators will recall that in June 1981 the Christmas Island Agreement Act was amended to enable an Australian Government company-the Phosphate Mining Company of Christmas Island Ltd-to replace the British Phosphate Commissioners as the managing agents of the Christmas Island Phosphate Commission. As was indicated in the second reading speech on that legislation, those amendments were of an interim kind, and a completely new Christmas Island Agreement was to be negotiated with New Zealand.

The legislation now before the Senate takes that process further. Article I in the Schedule provides that the Christmas Island Phosphate Commission shall cease to function as soon as practicable, following which the Christmas Island Agreement will terminate, in accordance with Article IV. As to Article II, the intention is that the assets of the Commission on the Island-the phosphate rock, buildings, plant, etc.-will pass to the Phosphate Mining Company of Christmas Island Ltd, which will then mine the phosphate deposits in its own right rather than as managing agents.

Agreement is close to being reached with New Zealand on arrangements which will operate in future between the two countries in respect of Island phosphate. This agreement will be embodied in an Exchange of Notes, which will begin to operate when the legislation before the House comes into force.

Mr President, just as the 1981 legislation affecting the Christmas Island Agreement paved the way for the British Phosphate Commissioners to be wound up, so does this legislation spell the end of the Christmas Island Phosphate Commission. The Commission was established in 1949 by the Australian and New Zealand governments after they had on 31 December 1948 purchased the assets on the Island of the Christmas Island Phosphate Company Ltd. That Company had been mining phosphate on the island since the 1880s. The purchase price was two million six hundred and ninety thousand pounds sterling. The original 1949 Agreement was revised in 1958 when Christmas Island became an Australian territory.

The Commission always has been an unusual organisation. There are three part- time Commissioners, but no employees, the Commission having always had managing agents-for 32 years the British Phosphate Commissioners and since July 1981 the Phosphate Mining Company of Christmas Island Ltd. I take this opportunity to pay tribute to the present Commissioners-Mr M. C. Timbs, A.O, the Australian Commissioner; Mr W. D. M. Bremner, C.M.G., the New Zealand Commissioner; and Mr W. B. Marston, O.B.E., the Joint Commissioner.

It is a measure of the relationship between Australia and New Zealand that a body under the authority of both of them could for 25 years be responsible for conducting a mining operation on a territory under the authority of one of them. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, may I suggest that it would suit the convenience of the Senate to have a cognate debate involving all six Constitution Alteration Bills now before the Senate, namely, the Constitution Alteration (Fixed Term Parliaments) Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Inter-change of Powers) Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Advisory Jurisdiction of High Court) Bill and the Constitution Alteration (Removal of Outmoded and Expended Provisions) Bill, those being government measures, and the two private members' measures, the Constitution Alteration (Appropriation Bills) Bill introduced by Senator Peter Rae and the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill introduced by Senator Mason.
—Is leave granted? There being no objection, leave is granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has indicated that the Senate is to debate the four Bills which he has introduced on behalf of the Government which propose alterations to the Constitution, and two further Bills, one introduced by Senator Peter Rae two days ago, and one which was originally introduced some time ago by Senator Mason , providing for electors' initiative in the Constitution. At the outset, on behalf of the Opposition, I indicate the position of the Opposition in respect of all six measures. The opposition will oppose the Constitution Alteration ( Fixed Term Parliaments) Bill 1983.
—Some of you will oppose it.

—The Opposition will oppose it. The Opposition will support the Constitution Alteration (Inter-change of Powers) Bill 1983, the Constitution Alteration (Advisory Jurisdiction of High Court) Bill 1983 and the Constitution Alteration (Removal of Outmoded and Expended Provisions) Bill 1983. It will, of course, support Senator Peter Rae's proposal for the Constitution Alteration ( Appropriation Bills) Bill 1983 because it is one that the present Opposition has maintained since the Australian Constitutional Convention held in Hobart in 1976 . It will oppose the proposal for the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill 1982 [1983].

SPEECH.PARA: I find it rather strange that the Parliament and, indeed, the people of Australia are being asked to consider these constitutional proposals at this point and by way of a referendum to be held on 20 August. The attention of the Government-certainly, this was the basis on which it was elected-should have been directed firmly to the state of the economy. We are told that a mini-Budget will be brought down tonight. Of course, in August, a few days after the referendum is held, the Budget for 1983-84 will be brought down by the Government. I would have thought that that was a matter to which the attention of this Government and the people would be mainly directed. But at the moment the Parliament is being diverted-the people will be diverted on 20 August-to consider some referendum proposals, not one of which, I suggest, is of such immediate importance as to justify the Government's proceeding at this time in this way and at this cost. We are constantly reminded of the huge Budget deficit . We will be told further in the mini-Budget tonight about the Government's efforts to cut it back; yet we are to face an additional and unnecessary cost of $21m, which is the estimated cost of the referendums with which the Government now wants us to proceed.

Let us speculate about the real reasons why the Government is proceeding with unseemly haste. I venture to suggest that there are probably two main reasons. One is that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) wants to have a more convenient election timetable for himself in the immediate future because there must be a half Senate election before 30 June 1985. It will presumably be very convenient for the Prime Minister to be able to postpone that until the end of 1985. In fact he may even have to hold an election at the end of 1984 or early in 1985. It is obvious that the real, but unstated, reason for these proposals has a lot to do with the situation with which the Government and the Prime Minister are faced.

I also believe that another reason for these referendum proposals being brought on with such great haste has something to do with the self-image of the Attorney -General as a great constitutional reformer. He is dragging the Government and the people through this unnecessary process to give some substance to that self- image. Also, for an Attorney-General who promised so much and who has performed so little as far as law reform is concerned, I think it probably has something to do with soothing his bruised ego. I also ask, and I think the people of Australia should be asking, what is the benefit of these proposals for them? What is the benefit in them for the people? If one quickly looks through the four proposals of the Attorney-General, one finds that there is really nothing in them for the people. The fixed term parliaments proposal is alleged to be of benefit to the people in that it will mean fewer elections. But when we analyse it, we see that the likelihood is that there will be more elections. In any event, the proposal for fixed terms of parliament and for allegedly fewer elections is likely to be of more benefit to politicians than to the people. The proposal for interchange of powers is simply to convenience both Federal and State governments in Australia, in jiggering the division of powers amongst themselves without referring to the people at all. The advisory jurisdiction of the High Court is again for the benefit of Federal and State governments to be able to get the opinion of the High Court as soon as possible about its legislation. The removal of outmoded and expended provisions does not seem to be of any benefit to anybody. In opening this debate on these proposals, I ask fairly and squarely, and I ask the people of Australia to ask the Government fairly and squarely, what is the point of it all? At a time when very great restraint is being asked of the people, why is $21m being spent on these rather wild goose chases?

I propose to spend the major proportion of my time dealing with the proposal for fixed term parliaments, because that, of course, is a proposal of great magnitude, and because of that, of great importance. If it was passed it would make very great changes to the Constitution. That is not to say it would make good changes to the Constitution, but it would certainly make great changes. On 23 March last year, when I was putting the then Government's case against Senator Evans's Constitution Alteration (Fixed Term Parliaments) Bill 1981 which he first introduced with great flourish on 11 November 1981-I was only really paraphrasing what Senator Evans himself said about this proposal-I said:

The Bill proposes an elaborate and drastic reordering and restructuring of the Australian constitutional system. If adopted, the proposal would involve shifts of a fundamental kind in our institutions of representative and responsible government which would become entrenched in our political system.

It is true that in principle and in theory the idea of having an election on a set day every third or fourth year-or every second year as occurs in the United States of America-has a lot of appeal. Therefore, one naturally gives such a proposal a very great deal of consideration. But what we have to ask ourselves is whether such a system is compatible with our particular system of democratic and responsible government. Of course, the proposal is, in the public mind I am sure, equated with the American Constitution which provides for elections on a fixed day every second year for the Congress, and every fourth year for the Presidency. Naturally, people think that this proposal would provide the same thing for Australia. Although on the face of it it seems as if that is what the proposal provides for, on analysis one sees that it does no such thing.

In any event, the United States of America has a completely different constitutional structure with a separation of powers. Not only does the United States have a fixed term parliament-or Congress as it is called-but also a fixed term Executive; an Executive popularly elected for a fixed term of four years. Now that has no relation to Australia's constitutional system, the Westminster system, the system of responsible government. That in itself presents a very grave problem-in fact, it presents what I have already called an insoluble dilemma-for anybody proposing a fixed term parliamentary system in this country.

Before I proceed with any further analysis of the problems that would be presented if such a proposal became part of our Constitution, I turn to the real reason why Senator Evans has produced this measure. I am not speculating about this. One thing I will say about Senator Evans in relation to this matter-in fact I would probably have more than one thing to say about him if I really thought about it-is that he has been perfectly frank about his motives. His motives are to emasculate the powers of the Senate in relation to not only Supply and Appropriation Bills but also money Bills. He presents this proposal as his solution. He tells us that it is the second best solution, but it is his solution to the problems of 1975.

Other people who support fixed term parliaments have, I think, higher and perhaps more worthy motives than Senator Evans has in proposing this measure. But Senator Evans has made no bones whatever about that fact. That is underlined by the great flourish with which he introduced his original proposal on 11 November 1981-the sixth anniversary of the events of 1975. He has also made no bones about the fact that his wishes are the same as the wishes of his party. His Government's wishes would be to have a very clean cut solution to the problem of 1975 simply by directly removing altogether from the Constitution the powers of the Senate on money Bills. That is the Government's preferred solution , but it does not dare propose it. It knows that it would be utterly rejected by the people because it has been made clear in so many gallup polls over the years that the people support the retention of those powers in the Senate. The Government knows that and, for that reason, does not propose that idea directly. This proposal intends to do indirectly what the Government is not prepared to attempt directly. I want it to be clearly understood in this chamber and everywhere else by the people of Australia that, on Senator Evans's own admission, throughout the whole of this long debate which started in November 1981, it is his and the Government's intention to destroy the power of the Senate by this measure. On Senator Evans's reasoning-whether it is good or bad does not matter-the Senate will not use those powers if it cannot force an immediate election.

Those are the real reasons for this proposal. Those reasons of course are rejected by the Opposition because the Opposition believes that the Senate's powers must be preserved. The Opposition also believes that the only constitutional alteration that is justified is the proposal of Senator Peter Rae -the proposal originally made by Sir Charles Court at the Hobart convention in 1976 and passed by the Perth convention in 1978; that is, that the Constitution be amended to provide, where the Senate blocks or defers Supply, that the Senate must go to the people at the same time as it forces the House of Representatives to do so. In other words, there would be an immediate and automatic double dissolution in those cases. That is what the Opposition says is the only required solution to the problem of 1975. Any solution of a more drastic kind which Senator Evans really believes in and which the Government really believes in, such as the proposal of Mr Whitlam after 1975, is of course anathema to us and would be opposed by us. But because Senator Evans's fixed term proposal is quite unashamedly and quite clearly directed at preventing the Senate from exercising those powers in any circumstances or at any time, as Senator Evans sees it, we are opposed to it, and the result it would achieve.

I turn to the insoluble dilemma, as I have called it, that is faced by anybody proposing a fixed term under the Westminster system. The proponent is seeking to engraft this system on one of responsible government. This means that the Executive is created by and is dependent upon the Parliament. It is a completely different situation in the United States, as I have already said. So any proponent of the system of fixed terms has to face that fundamental problem. He has to evolve provisions to resolve a conflict between the Executive and the body which creates it and to which it is responsible, namely, the Parliament. On the other hand, the more that is done to resolve that problem, to provide for all the situations that may arise in the life of our parliamentary democracy, the further and further away one gets from the fixed term concept.

Senator Evans is again faced with that dilemma, as are all proponents of this fixed term concept within our Westminster system. Senator Evans, to give him his due, recognises that and seeks to provide a solution to it. His solution is to provide for a formal vote of no confidence as the only way in which the House of Representatives can resolve that conflict if it arises within the House of Representatives. The other problem that is faced under our Constitution is conflict between the House of Representatives and the Senate. Senator Evans does not propose-except with regard to the effect of a double dissolution on the life of a parliament-any changes to the existing provisions of section 57 of the Constitution. So the double dissolution provisions remain in full force and effect.

Clearly, this proposal-the Evans proposal in this Bill-may well result not in a fixed term for the Parliament at all but for early elections to occur if there were a vote of no confidence in the government of the day in the House of Representatives and no other government were installed within seven days. In those circumstances there would be an election regardless of the fact that there is a fixed term for parliament and a requirement for an election to be held on the third Saturday of every third November. Whenever that situation happened there would be an early election. Thereby, there would be a fundamental derogation from the fixed term concept, in point of fact. Under the double dissolution provisions, as we well know, there have been early elections in recent years. There were double dissolutions for the elections of 1974, 1975 and , recently, 1983. When people think that this proposal will do away with early elections they should all bear in mind the fact that these early elections, including the one in March this year of which people are most critical, were, in fact, the result of double dissolutions. This Bill does nothing to change that situation except in one respect, with which I will deal later.

After making those major qualifications to the proposal for fixed term parliaments which this Bill makes, I wish to put down some further major criticisms of this proposed solution. They are criticisms in the sense that they do not meet the requirements of the Westminster system. The principal criticisms are that there could be a situation in which the Government does not have or loses control of the House of Representatives for a number of reasons, but at the same time nobody could be prepared to move a vote of no-confidence in the government. That is quite likely to occur because those who are opposed to the government and who may have the numbers to pass a vote of no-confidence may not wish to have an early election at that time.

Of course, we remember the situation which occurred last year in West Germany when the Free Democrats left the Schmidt Government and joined the Christian Democrats. The Christian Democrats wanted to have an election at the time in order to get a mandate for their new coalition government, but the Free Democrats did not want an election in the middle of last year. The deal was made that they would have an election in March this year. The irony of it all is that that election happened on 6 March, the day after our so-called early election. That election in West Germany was brought on by a manipulation of a fixed term parliament system which, in fact, operates in West Germany and which is similar to the proposal Senator Evans is putting in this legislation. I digressed somewhat because that is another objection to Senator Evans's proposal-that such a system could be so easily manipulated by either members of a government or its opponents who wish to bring on an election at a time of their choosing and not at the expiration of the fixed time which had been allotted.

Let us look at the situation regardless of the West German experience. The fact is that in a Constitution we have to provide for situations even though we do not think they are likely. In our recent experience there has not been that situation of instability in the House of Representatives. That is not to say that that situation will not occur in the future. It certainly was a feature of the House of Representatives for the first 15 or 20 years of the operation of this Parliament under our Constitution. Difficulties were experienced by government in getting the necessary majority to govern. The only ultimate solution to that problem would be by holding an early election, by resort to the people. What is wrong with that under our system? In the end the Parliament is dependent upon the people. They are sovereign and not the parliament or the members of parliament. It is the people who are sovereign in this country. I think it is about time Senator Evans and the Government learnt and acknowledged that. If there is no solution to the constitutional problems within a parliament , the only and proper course is to go to the people. As I said, what is wrong with that? Why should the people object to being asked to resolve the problem amongst their representatives in the Parliament? That is not only the traditional but also the appropriate way of solving the problem in a parliamentary democracy.

The next matter which is ignored by Senator Evans's Bill is the problem of Supply. This Bill by its design, not only emasculates the Senate's powers over Supply but also has that effect on the House of Representatives. If the Senate refuses Supply there is no way in which that problem can be resolved under Senator Evans's Bill. Of course, it could be resolved by the Government manipulating a no confidence motion against itself. That would be the only way the problem could be resolved. If the Senate defers or defeats a Supply Bill, an Appropriation Bill or a major money Bill that action does not and cannot result in an election under the Bill. This also applies to the House of Representatives . The majority in the House of Representatives, however it is made up, might refuse Supply to the Government. There would be nothing that the Prime Minister could do about it. No solution to the problem of Supply is contained in Senator Evans's Bill.

Another major deficiency in the Bill is the way it emasculates the powers of the Governor-General. Under this Bill a Governor-General will be rendered powerless to dismiss a Prime Minister who may be acting illegally even or acting in fundamental breach of a constitutional convention or conventions. If the Primer Minister commands a solid majority in the House of Representatives, of course there is simply no way in which he can be removed. On the other hand, if there is a destabilised situation in the House of Representatives in which the Government cannot get its legislation through because it is constantly harassed and frustrated by minority groups joining forces with the Opposition, amongst themselves or whatever, the Government cannot do anything except manipulate a vote of no confidence in itself. Therefore, we could have a completely lame duck , useless, powerless government stumbling along until the fixed date for an election comes around. It is a most undesirable situation for any country to be placed in.

For all these reasons the Opposition is opposed to Senator Evans's Bill. We have looked at it and thought about it. I looked at it very seriously when I was Attorney-General. We looked at it when we were in Government; we have looked at it again. We have thought about it over and over again. We do not think there is any way in which it can be improved. It is a Bill which will impose upon us a straight-jacket of an unworkable system. It makes a major change to our constitutional structure for the wrong reasons. Even if they were not the real reasons for having a fixed term-I know that many people believe that a fixed term is a good idea-this Bill creates so many problems and provides such inadequate solutions to existing problems that the Opposition opposes it.
(Extension of time granted).

I thank the Senate. Mr Acting Deputy President, I shall proceed immediately to the other proposals about which, of course, I do not need to say very much. The Opposition, as I said, supports the interchange of powers proposal, although I doubt, frankly, whether it is of any great significance. The proposal has been accepted more or less as an article of faith since the 1973 Constitutional Convention. It had, as far as I could see, unanimous support at the Adelaide Constitutional Convention in the amended form, which Senator Evans wisely agreed to, and it seems that it perhaps may in some circumstances be a useful facility to have in the Constitution. Whether it is conceivably worh $21m is an entirely different matter, but it could be. I think the people ought to know, though, that the real reason for the proposal in the first place-probably it is still the reason for it-is to enable State governments to impose sales taxes and indirect taxes. I do not think the people will be very impressed when they know the real reason for it, but still that is a matter for them. It is for them to say whether they want to allow State governments to do these things.

Although it is a two-way process, State governments have been said to be reluctant to refer powers to the Commonwealth because they were not too sure what the effect of that referral would be. I do not believe that. I believe that State governments do not refer powers to the Commonwealth because they like to keep their powers. I do not think this move will make any difference to real reasons why that reference of powers proposal has not worked. Having tried for 5 1/2 years to get a reference of powers from the States which made and still make great public play of how much they support the power of the Commonwealth to make uniform laws in relation to the custody and maintenance of children, I did not notice any great enthusiasm on the part of the States when it came to the nitty- gritty of making a reference of powers. The recent big song and dance act by Mr Landa is highly ironical.

The advisory jurisdication proposal is another one of those constitutional proposals that have been around for so long that I have forgotten when it began. I happen to think it would be a good idea if the High Court of Australia could give advisory opinions. I think it could save a great deal of litigation, time and cost in determining the actual parameters of a power. We have had plenty of examples of that point. We still do not know the ramifications of the corporations power. I do not know how long it took-perhaps 10 years-to find out just what sort of road maintenance taxes the States could impose. I can see some benefits in the proposal, but again I do not really see the urgency of it.

I now turn to the fourth proposal about the removal of outmoded and extended provisions. I suppose it is a good idea to tidy up the Constitution. If we are to have a referendum anyway we might as well tidy it up. I have already referred , of course, to Senator Rae's proposal which the Opposition strongly supports. Senator Rae recently introduced his proposal in a very extensive and clear second reading speech, and I have nothing to add to it. I trust that the Senate will give that proposal a speedy passage. I do not think Senator Mason's proposal-I think it is his Bill; it always has been-to provide for the elector's initiative, although it has been put down for debate by Senator Mason on a number of occasions, has ever in fact been debated in the Senate. It provides that following the signing of a petition by 250,000 voters a change in the law can be sought. It can be any law, not just an alteration in the Constitution. A new law can be proposed and if 250,000 people sign a petition then the proposal has to be submitted to the people at a referendum. It is passed in that way, not by the Parliament. I do not propose to go into the other details.

The Opposition is opposed to such a proposal because it would lead to quite fantastic and fundamental change in not only our parliamentary democracy but also our notions of democracy and of representative and responsible government. Of course we know what happens when provisions of this kind are exercised. California has a similar provision and the first thing that the people were asked to vote on was Proposition 13, which just about destroyed the finances of the State of California. So there are a number of objections to this provision but the Opposition really opposes it because it is so contrary to our whole system of parliamentary democracy.

I thank the Senate for giving me the opportunity to complete the Opposition's case on these matters. I trust that the Senate will reject the proposal for a fixed term and will reject the proposal for electors' initiative in making laws in this country. We strongly support the proposal of Senator Peter Rae. We see no reason why the people themselves should not decide whether they want to allow governments to exchange powers between themselves without reference to the people or why the High Court should not be allowed to have an advisory jurisdiction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with pleasure that I rise to support the Government's proposal to put before the Australian people by way of referendum propositions concerning alterations to the Constitution in relation to a fixed term for the Federal Parliament, the removal of outmoded provisions from the Constitution, provisions for an interchange of powers between Federal and State governments and a proposal to confer an advisory jurisdiction on the High Court. It is interesting to hear, amongst all the bombast of the shadow Attorney- General, Senator Durack, about the rights of soveriegn people, that the Liberal- National Party members of this Parliament, including honourable senators opposite, intend, if their vote is effective today, to deny to the people of Australia-that sovereign body of Australians-the right to consider this matter by way of referendum. It must be recalled and asserted that all this Parliament will do is send the proposal to the people. It is interesting, and I think it reveals the hypocrisy of the Opposition members, that they do not intend that that opportunity be given to the Australian people. Their opposition at a political level could be understood once the campaign was under way, but they do not want to allow the Australian people that opportunity.

SPEECH.PARA: The espousal of opposition to the concept of a fixed term parliament by the shadow Attorney-General on behalf of the Liberal and National parties was totally unconvincing in that it was muddled, confused and in some instances I believe quite incorrect. It was a confused performance because Senator Durack said that none of the four propositions would be of any benefit to the people. Having asserted that he then said that the Opposition would support three of them but would not support one of them. When we have such evident muddle- headedness as that we are entitled to wonder where the real conviction of the Opposition lies. It is simply wrong and a deliberate misleading of this chamber, this Parliament and the people for Senator Durack to suggest that if this referendum were passed by the people then the Govenor-General would lose his present power to dismiss a Prime Minister who was acting illegally. That power is untouched by this proposition and would continue to be vested in the Governor -General. So in that respect I believe Senator Durack, in order to bolster his confused and weak case, deliberately misled this Parliament and raised fears and misgivings which need not have been raised.

I want to spend the great bulk of my time in relation to the fixed term parliaments proposition. I think it is well understood in the general community, if not by the Opposition, that the best argument for fixed term parliaments was the election forced and foisted on the Australian people on 5 March so opportunistically and so characteristically by a Prime Minister who manipulated and perverted the Constitution to suit his own political advantage whenever he deemed it necessary. I believe that both those points are important. Such action was taken always with a view to his own political advantage.
