It was a manipulation of the Constitution to suit party political prospects as he saw them. But more important is the fact that he did so whenever he deemed it necessary. There we have the core of the problem. An undue discretion is vested in a Prime Minister under our present constitutional arrangements. One recalls an article by Hood Phillips, a very well known, and perhaps Great Britain's leading, constitutional lawyer, in which he said:
This squalid practice of the leaders of both main parties as it has developed--
That is, the practice of calling an early election-
is the least creditable aspect of the British Constitution.

This proportion does not affect the core concept of the Westminster democracy at all, but it is no doubt a fact that the least creditable aspect of our present constitutional arrangements derived from Britain is this undue discretion being vested in a Prime Minister to call on an early election before the parliamentary term has expired because he thinks some political advantage may be gained. Incidentally, I believe further support will be generated for the proposition when it is put to the people at a referendum by the fact that the calling of the early election on 5 March had the effect-I believe it was a deliberate effect-of preventing tens of thousands and perhaps hundreds of thousands of Australians, new citizens and young people in particular, from casting a vote. Without forewarning an election was thrust upon them before they had an opportunity to register and get on the electoral rolls. It is a further argument for saying that with a definite fixed term parliament, with an election held every third Saturday of November in every third year, the people would know that they were required to be on the electoral rolls by the due date in order to exercise their rights as citizens, which rights were denied to them by the opportunistic calling of an early election by Prime Minister Fraser earlier this year.

The basic contention of this proposition is that elections for the House of Representatives be held on the third Saturday in November every three years-on a constitutionally fixed date. That is what occurs in the democracy of the United States of America. No one would deny that that country has a democratic system of government. We are saying that that system ought to apply in Australia. Indeed, the people support that view. Senator Durack-I am getting support even from the galleries in putting this point of view-asks why the people should object--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the only place you will get it from.

—That is where the voters are, so I am very pleased to get it from there. The fact is that people do object to going to the polls at the behest and opportunistic whim of a Prime Minister. The opinion polls are very supportive and confirmatory in putting this matter to the people. State by State, Territory by Territory, seven out of ten Australian voters, the overwhelming proportion of the voting population, have indicated their desire to have fixed terms to our parliamentary process. That is why the proposition deserves the support it is getting.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, there is a fundamentally good reason, quite apart from stripping a Prime Minister of this power, for supporting the proposition. It will bring an era of predictability and stability in public and private sector planning, of which this country had not had the benefit, particularly in the last 10 years or so. There is no doubt that planning for a public sector expenditure policy and a private sector expenditure policy is needed. There is also a need for an environment within which planning is not brought to the point of virtual impossibility by the constant leaking of the possibility that an election might be held, with all the ramifications that that has for creating nervousness in the stock market and in those, for example who make investment decisions.

The fact is that the proposal retains the key features of the Westminster system. It merely strips away the least creditable parts of that system-as outlined by the great constitutional lawyer Hood Phillips, Q.C.-to which I have already adverted. The key element of the Westminster system is that a Prime Minister is entitled to lead a government so long as he retains the confidence and support of the House of Representatives. Governments are created in that House. We all know that that is what the electoral process is designed to do. A government is given the right to govern by enjoying the support-continuing to enjoy that support and being sustained by that confidence-of a majority of elected members of the House of Representatives.

This proposal acknowledges two instances in which the fixed term of the Parliament may be foreshortened. The first exception-this is in harmony with the Westminster system-is when the confidence of the House of Representatives is lost and no alternative government commands majority support within that chamber . This proposal endorses, reinforces and strengthens the Westminster tradition. It certainly does not destroy it, as was quite mischievously suggested by Senator Durack. Indeed, the only other way for a fixed term to be foreshortened is by the existence of a dispute between the House of Representatives and the Senate as to the passage of legislation-that is, a double dissolution situation under section 57 of the Constitution. The actual occasion on which the Prime Minister may seek a double dissolution may concern either the simple existence of a dispute about certain legislative proposals-section 57 is not touched at all-or where there is a refusal of Supply by the Senate. This proposal, despite everything that Senator Durack tried to suggest, does not take away that power insofar, of course, as it is asserted to exist. If the Senate obstinately and obdurately refuses Supply to the government, a government which still enjoys the confidence of the House of Representatives, a general election will be able to be called either because a double dissolution situation exists-a dispute between the Houses as to other legislation upon which a double dissolution can be based- or there can be a technical vote of no confidence in the House of Representatives. In that way, as I say, the power of the Senate to refuse Supply is sufficiently acknowledged.

On the contrary, of course, Senator Rae's proposal-the Constitution Alteration (Appropriation Bills) Bill-would give explicit constitutional sanction to the 1975 situation. Senator Rae's proposal is based on the proposition put by the then Premier of Western Australia, Sir Charles Court, to the Australian Constitutional Convention in Perth some years ago. Senator Rae's proposal explicitly enshrines expressly into our Constitution the 1975 power to refuse Supply. But what it does-all that it was conceived to do by the conservative forces which pushed this proposition at the Perth Constitutional Convention-is to remove the Governor-General from the fulcrum of political controversy. The proposal put forward by Senator Rae was conceived-I think probably correctly so- to remove the Governor-General from the exercise of discretion in relation to the granting of a double dissolution. Of course, in that sense, his proposal would be of benefit and be pleasing to the holder of that office and to the Sovereign, who must have been aghast at what happened in 1975.

The Opposition refuses to explicity entrench and expressly acknowledge that particular power of the Senate. We believe that Senator Rae's proposal goes nowhere near solving this crucial, central dilemma of our constitutional arrangements, which is that there may be a majority hostile to the Government in this chamber whilst the Government continues to enjoy the confidence of a majority in the House of Representatives. Insofar as Senator Rae's proposal in no way addresses that crucial, central problem, we on this side of the chamber cannot find it in our hearts to support it.

This proposal recognises, in a way which Senator Durack apparently did not perceive, that the people are sovereign and that when they elect their representatives to this Parliament they are entitled to have those representatives see out their parliamentary terms and work for the better peace, order and good government of Australia over the three years of the parliamentary term for which they are elected. The people deserve that the Parliament should see out its full term. It is within the context of the Parliament being conceived as working over a three-year period towards national goals for which a government has a mandate that I believe this referendum proposal will generate the support which it so deserves.

Three other propositions are to be put to the people by the Government. One is to strip the Constitution of provisions which have become outmoded and which time has seen emptied of content or meaning within our national life and within the arrangements of our Executive and Parliament. I believe that the whole of the community will support that proposition.

I believe that the proposal relating to the interchange of powers between State and Federal parliaments will be a little used power, but insofar as it will provide for the representatives of the people, at both the national and State levels, to exchange certain legislative powers in full view of their electorates and after full parliamentary debate-there is nothing done by subterfuge, nothing done in the dark and murky rooms-and insofar as it would enable the occasional transfer of some legislative power, perhaps in relation to a particular form of tax or family law matters, I believe it can only be beneficial.

It is my wish, after Question Time, to say some words about the proposal to confer an advisory opinion jurisdiction on the High Court, because I believe it is extremely important that the High Court be given a true judicial power to deliver an opinion on questions of law which are of large and radical moment and which ought to be aired before the High Court-that bench of impartial justices- before legislative action, perhaps, is finally undertaken and certainly before administrative arrangements are entered into on the basis of what might, in a constitutional challenge, emerge as unconstitutional, invalid or beyond the powers of the Parliament. However, I will deal with that particular proposal after Question Time. Mr President, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the widespread public concern about the extent and ramifications of organised crime in Australia, will the Attorney-General, firstly, review the leisurely approach he has adopted to the establishment of a National Crimes Commission, despite the fact that legislation has passed both houses of Parliament and the former Government was about to establish the Commission at the time of the election? Secondly, does he agree that the extent of purely federal crime justifies the early establishment of the Commission regardless of the desirability of including the States as a part of it? Thirdly, will he expedite the Green Paper foreshadowed by him and presumably being prepared by his Department in view of the very extensive work that has been done by his Department on this subject since at least this time last year? Finally, will the Attorney-General indicate when his proposed seminar on the subject will be held and who will be invited to it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —For a question like that to come from the bottom-of-the- drawer man, as Senator Durack is known, is a bit of a cheek. Let me deal directly with the questions that have been asked. In respect of the establishment of a Crimes Commission, issues of real complexity are involved in getting the right kind of model on foot which strikes an appropriate balance between on the one hand, the need for an agency armed with effective investigative powers and, on the other hand, the need for such an agency and all that it implies to have due and proper respect for the traditional liberties of the subject.

ANSWER.PARA: There are, no doubt as Senator Durack is aware, basically two competing models around which the argument revolves. On the one hand there is the royal commission model armed with very extensive powers but not necessarily directed towards the efficient or effective accumulation of admissible evidence which can subsequently be used to sustain actual prosecutions. On the other hand, there is the other sort of commission model which perhaps is less well geared towards the production of public reports but may be better geared towards the production of admissible evidence and more appropriately focused towards the prosecution of the criminals whose activities it thus reveals. It is quite a complex business to unravel the competing considerations that are involved in these two basic approaches to the proper investigation of organised crime. The Government is not wanting to rush into either the enactment or proclamation of legislation in this area without making sure that it has those basic principles right.

In the meantime, of course, nobody is letting any grass grow under his or her feet. The Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union continues in operation. I note that the Special Minister of State has indicated that there will be some expansion of the resources of the Costigan Commission, notwithstanding the fact that its formal life will not be very long; in fact, it is proposed to wind it up at the end of this year. Certainly, as I have said on numerous occasions, the Costigan Commission is acting, for all practical purposes, as a de facto crimes commission. There is no slackening in the Commonwealth's endeavour both to investigate and expose organised crime in this country.

That, of course, is not the only body operating in the field. The Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking has just completed one inquiry and is now about to embark on another in relation to Nugan Hand Ltd. We have corporate affairs commissions investigating a number of related matters. We have the Commonwealth-New South Wales Joint Task Force on Drug Trafficking in which Commonwealth and State police forces are engaged in pursuing particular matters. In fact, we have a whole series of reports from previous royal commissions in respect of which complete follow-up action has by no means yet been taken.

I am advised that the Green Paper, to which the shadow Attorney-General referred, will be completed within a matter of days, at least in draft form. I certainly hope to have it publicly circulated as soon as possible in the month of June. As to the proposed seminar at which that Green Paper will be discussed and the issues canvassed, I hope in order to reach some agreement or to obtain a meeting of minds as to what the permanent crimes commission body should look like, all I can say at this stage is that it is still proposed that the seminar take place during the parliamentary winter recess. I imagine on present indications that it will be some time later in July. The attendance at that seminar is still to be resolved. I have indicated already that it is not intended that it be a closed shop affair. There will be an opportunity for public observance of the proceedings. The matter of who will be officially invited to participate on the floor, as it were, at the seminar is still to be resolved. It is not our intention to exclude any party or organisation with a genuine interest, or any individual who might have something useful to contribute in this very difficult policy area.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CONSTRUCTION OF OIL SEED PROCESSING PLANT

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to reports in the Courier-Mail earlier this week that a Paraguayan businessman Dr Oskar is still seeking from the Queensland Government a $6m loan guarantee for the construction of an oil seed processing plant. I ask : Is this the same person who earlier this week was ordered by the Western Australian Supreme Court to pay $280,000 which he owed by way of a guarantee to Nissho Iwai Australia Ltd? How does the Federal Government view a proposal to provide Dr Oskar with a State government loan guarantee of $6m?
—It is none of their business.

—Senator Martin interjected that it is none of our business. It is a view which of course is quite tenable. The honourable senator's question relates to Dr Oskar who has been entrepreneurial in the oil seeds field. All I can contribute to the debate which seems to be going on in Queensland as to whether the Queensland Government should guarantee a substantial sum of money for investment in Dr Oskar's project is to make the point that the Australian Government is currently suing Dr Oskar on the guarantee for a loan to Bunbury Foods Pty Ltd, of which Dr Oskar is the principal shareholder and promoter, for the sum of $1.6m. That matter is currently being dealt with by the Western Australian Supreme Court. It would not be appropriate for me to comment on it. I suppose the point of the honourable senator's question is that all governments in this country should conduct their business in the best way possible and with the prudence which the Premier of Queensland has always advised governments of other States and the Commonwealth to show.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. I refer to the Minister's assurance given, I think not for the first time, at the Australian Minerals and Energy Council meeting last week that the Government's proposed resources rental tax would be a replacement rather than an additional or extra tax. Given what the Minister has described as the difference in 'quality and locational advantages' between deposits of minerals such as coal in various States-this observation of the Minister is borne out by the varying profitability of the companies involved-does the Minister agree that the proposed tax will raise revenues in a quite different pattern from the present mixture of taxes; that is, that the proportion of overall revenue raised in particular States is likely to vary from the present pattern? If each State's revenue is to be unaffected, is it not likely that there will have to be substantial transfers of funds raised in one State to another? If that is so, what incentive will there be for a likely donor State to agree to the new tax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —There were several sub-questions in the honourable senator's question. I hope I can remember all of them. Certainly it is true that we have stated that the Government's intention is to impose, in some areas, a resources rent tax as a replacement. It is correct, as Senator Chaney has said, that there would be some variations in the incidence of that new tax system as it affects particular companies or particular States. I will deal with the companies first. A major reason why the Government proposes to introduce such a tax is that the existing tax, with minor variations, falls on producers of a particular mineral regardless of the company level of profitability--
—I haven't raised the companies. I am not concerned about that point.

—Well, I will just give the honourable senator some background information. The existing tax, with minor variations falls on producers of a particular mineral regardless of the reasons, the level of profitability of the company or the economic rent component of the price it receives. That is certainly a major reason, if not the major reason, why the Government wants a change. Such a tax would not affect companies in a period of low prices to nearly the same extent as raising the same amount of revenue in the present way affects companies in a period of low prices, as exists today. It is also correct -I would expect at least for coal-that there would be variations in the relative amount of tax raised inside various States. In seeking agreement with the States on our proposal I would expect that allowance would be made for that in the final distribution of Commonwealth funds to the States.

ANSWER.PARA: Finally, the Government's view of the question which is of primary importance in this matter is not who imposes the tax. The type of tax which is imposed is of overriding importance. As I mentioned yesterday in reply to a question asked by Senator Chaney it is, of course, a fact with respect to this or any other matter affecting State revenue, that the bottom line regarding both the absolute amount of payments of State revenue and the relative amounts of State revenue is written by the Commonwealth now and can continue to be written by the Commonwealth in the future, depending on what decisions the Commonwealth makes about total State payments and State relativities. Any changes to State revenue bases resulting from our proposal to introduce a different type of tax, of course, would be taken account of in determining that bottom line.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. What is the Government's view of the latest developments in the shearers' dispute over the use of wide combs? Is the Government confident that the issue is now close to resolution?

—Senator Zakharov has asked a question about the wide comb dispute about which Senator Scott asked last week. It is a source of great gratification to me that honourable senators on both sides of the chamber should display an intelligent interest in this matter. To borrow a comment by the Prime Minister, honourable senators on the Opposition side of the chamber have been obsessed with what he has been pleased to describe as the wide Combe dispute in the last week rather than the dispute which is the subject of this important question. The Government welcomes the fact that since Senator Scott asked the question last week-I am not attributing the results entirely to him-the shearers in New South Wales have ended their strike and have resumed normal work. The Government has established--
—Do you mean normal work?

—Oh, Senator! The Government has established an inquiry into this matter which will involve all the parties. The Government will be giving that inquiry every assistance to try to bring about a long term resolution of this complex problem. We believe that more issues are involved than just the use of the wide comb. All those matters will be before the inquiry. We believe there is now a realistic and co-operative approach to determining this difficult problem. The Government will give that approach every support.

—Is the Leader of the Government aware that the present Australian Broadcasting Commission which, whether or not its membership varies, will be replaced by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation upon the passage of relevant legislation, is making wholesale appointments of staff on a permanent basis to senior positions? Is the Minister aware that these appointments are to positions that are either under review or very senior, up to and including the level of controller? Is the Minister aware that such appointments, even if made on the basis of merit alone, could prejudice the effective rejuvenation of the ABC which the new legislation will, I hope, produce?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am asked whether I am aware that the Commission will be replaced by a corporation following the passage of legislation. I am aware of that and I regard that essentially as a bipartisan policy. It is true, as the question suggests, that a number of senior positions in the ABC have been filled within the last three months. When I say 'senior positions' I refer to those above level 1 of the Second Division and they include a chief manager of a State , a controller of administrative services, controller of personnel and establishments, director of finance and director of information systems. Altogether 10 such positions have been filled this year. I am not able to make any comment about that.

ANSWER.PARA: In answer to the last part of the honourable senator's question, the Dix Committee of Review into the Australian Broadcasting Commission observed that there was a need for a substantial improvement in the efficiency and capacity of senior management within that organisation. The Australian Labor Party, when it was in opposition, accepted that view; albeit somewhat reluctantly the Government of the day also accepted that view. I hope that anything which has taken place in the last few months will not be prejudicial to the rejuvenation of the ABC as a great independent national broadcasting organisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Recently I received a delegation representing Torres Strait and Aboriginal ex- servicemen who served the nation during the Second World War. They complain that they are being discriminated against as far as benefits are concerned. What is the Minister doing to correct what I consider to be a sorry affair?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Georges is correct. Some concern has been expressed about the Australian Government's obligation to Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders. This was brought to the notice of the previous Government as a result of an article in the Defence Force Journal in 1980 by a Mr Hall, and it has been hanging around in the various government departments since that period. I find it somewhat disturbing that an issue involving the rights of a considerable number of people of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Island descent has not been resolved satisfactorily from the point of view of those persons.

ANSWER.PARA: The allegation that was made by Mr Hall relates to underpayment and was taken up by my Department and referred to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Department of Defence. When it was brought to my attention I immediately instructed my Department to step up the investigation with a view to resolving the claim which, I believe, is thoroughly justified and is one that hangs somewhat in the area of shame so far as governments in the post-war years are concerned.

The background to the issue seems to be that an estimated 680 Torres Strait Islanders and 100 mainland Aboriginals served in special Defence Force units raised in the Northern Territory as a result of a decision made by the War Cabinet in 1941. Their rates of pay were determined by the Department of the Army and the Department of Native Affairs. As a result of that decision, rates of pay were considerably lower than those paid to other members of the defence forces. The Government believes that that is an unacceptable position. Similarly , it seems that repatriation benefits given to these Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders were both unjust and discriminatory. I believe the previous Government is indicted for not taking action to rectify that position.

The matter in respect of pay lies largely in the area of the Department of Defence. I have drawn the matter to the attention of the Minister for Defence. His Department failed to advise him of this underpayment and failure to recognise our obligations in this matter. However, the Government's view is that this wrong should be righted and it will be righted. I am currently having discussions within the Department of Veterans' Affairs with a view to having the matter dealt with retrospectively so that the Repatriation Act 1920, which is the legislation under which we have our obligations, will be applied with a view to having the matter properly attended to. Whatever repatriation matters are outstanding, my Department will accept its responsibilities. I am assured that that is also the view of the Minister for Defence.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Resources and Energy. It follows one asked by Senator Chaney yesterday. I remind the Minister of a statement made by his colleague Mr Keating last year. When speaking to the Australian Coal Conference on 21 April Mr Keating stated:

QUESTION.PARA: The States would take a lot of convincing to lift State charges in favour of Commonwealth taxation even with commensurate reimbursement on the part of the Commonwealth Government.
He then said, and I put emphasis on it:
Nevertheless it has to happen.
He went on to say:

We would be concerned to consult with the States to secure a rationalisation of the various taxation regimes with the ultimate objective of replacing most existing charges with a profits-related mechanism. Agreement would need to be reached with the States for the sharing of the proceeds.

Should such an approach prove unsuccessful a Commonwealth Government could consider as a last resort embarking upon the more direct course of removing the incentive State mineral taxation. In simple terms this would involve reducing Commonwealth general revenue grants to individual States by the amount of the mineral taxation in question.
Is this not a simple declaration that the Hawke Government will resort to coercion in its pursuit of a resources rental tax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The position at the moment with the coal industry in particular is that the level of production taxes-with minor variations that is what the present system of taxation is-which is quite high on export quality coal, has reached the point that a number of higher cost mines have either been forced out of production or are on the brink of being forced out of production. This Government proposes to change the tax system so that that situation will no longer happen. I would have hoped that in pursuit of the objective of keeping higher cost mines in operation we would have had the support of all political parties and of all governments. But if that is not to be the case, those governments or political parties which have resisted the achievement of that objective will bear the political odium of having done so and the political odium flowing from the unnecessary closure of higher cost mines and the unnecessary bankruptcy or insolvency of some producers.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Keating just stated in different words what I mentioned to Senator Chaney yesterday and repeated today; that of course the bottom line determining total State revenue and the relative distribution of revenue between the States has for the last 40 years been written by the Commonwealth Government. That is an option that is available to the Commonwealth Government and an option that Mr Keating said would be considered.

As to coercion, I am reminded that last year the Victorian Government exercised its autonomous right to fund part of its public hospital system through imposing a levy. We then had the unseemly spectacle of the phony champions of States rights who populate the Liberal-National Party benches in this Parliament and in other parliaments, giving the Victorians a healthy dose of Canberra Fraser- Liberal Party style centralism and attempting to stop the Victorian Government from imposing that levy. I wish the Liberal Party would make up its mind on questions like this. Does it believe that financial inducements-or, if it prefers the harsh term, coercion-ought to be applied to State governments? Does it accept the principle of applying coercion to State governments which do not tailor their policies in accordance with Commonwealth desires? It would be a major moral improvement if the Liberal Party were to make an unequivocal statement about that instead of applying in the future the principle that it has applied in the past; that is, that Labor State governments will get a heavy dose of Fraser-Liberal Party style centralism and non-Labor State governments can do whatever they like.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Treasurer advise the Senate, firstly, of the net increase in the total number of people employed during the seven years of the Fraser Government and, secondly, of the net increase in the number of people unemployed during those seven years? Thirdly, is this the worst record of unemployment of any government in this country over the past 50 years? Fourthly, can he assure the Senate that the present Government--
—In percentage terms or in true figures?
—The Opposition still jests about unemployment. Can the Minister assure the Senate that the present Government will take the problem of unemployment a lot more seriously than its predecessor?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that Senator Bolkus asked four questions. The net increase in employment-that is, the number of people employed during the period of the Fraser Government, specifically from November 1975 to April 1983-totalled 297, 000. In round figures there was a growth of 300,000 in total employment. The net increase in the number of people unemployed was 397,000-in round figures, 400, 000. So in the seven years that the Fraser Government was in office total employment increased by 300,000 and unemployment increased by 400,000. At the time the Fraser Government came into office unemployment was around 300,000. According to that Government, that was a catastrophic and wholly unnecessary level of unemployment. During the seven years it was in power the Fraser Government more than doubled that level of unemployment.

ANSWER.PARA: I am not sure whether the Fraser Government's record in regard to unemployment is the worst for the last 50 years because I am not sure about the precise levels of unemployment which prevailed in the mid-1930s. But it is without doubt by far the worst unemployment record over which any government has presided in the last 40 years. I draw honourable senators' attention once again to the fact that in seven years the number of people unemployed increased by 400,000. That was the record of those seven dark years. I remind the Senate that this is the record of a government and of political parties which came into office promising jobs for all within three years, predicting real economic growth of between 5 per cent and 7 per cent in the first year and every year thereafter. In none of the seven dark years that the Liberal-Country Party coalition was in government was the bottom figure of that range actually achieved. When the Government was elected in 1975 it said it would achieve five to seven per cent real economic growth in the first year and every other year.

TALK.START.PARA: —When are you going to blame the Western Australian Liberal Party?
—If the honourable senator would like me to make a statement about the Western Australian Liberal Party, I will. As a distinguished former member of the House of Representatives said the other day--
—Senator Walsh, I suggest you make that statement after Question Time.
—I was about to forecast that, Mr President.
—Back into the gutter.

—The insider trader is in no position to talk about gutters. As a distinguished former member of the House of Representatives said the other day, this is only a half-hour program and I do not have time to go into all of that. Only half an hour of Question Time remains, so I do not have time to go into a full examination of the Western Australian Liberal Party. With the vastly exacerbated problem of unemployment confronting the present Government-I think it is important to note this-it is necessary to achieve real economic growth rates of close to 5 per cent a year in order to reduce unemployment at all. That that growth rate was achieved in only one year during the last decade is a sobering thought.

ANSWER.PARA: This Government certainly will take the problem more seriously than did the previous Government. The first major instalment, if I may use that term, of the implementation of the Government's policy will be announced tonight. As has been publicly stated by a number of responsible Ministers, measures will be announced to stimulate employment and to distribute more equally the burden of sacrifice imposed by the present level of unemployment. When that statement is made, particularly with respect to the equality of sacrifice, I hope that those proposals will not be met with carping criticism or irresponsible endorsement of the greedy bleatings and complaints of privileged groups. I hope that the Opposition will not respond to the statement in that way although I fear from its record that that is a forlorn hope.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, who is also Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Is the Minister aware of an article which appeared in yesterday's Australian newspaper headed '$10,000 scholarship to ''give women a go'',' which describes an award initiated by an anonymous Western Australian to encourage women to enrol in the male-dominated field of geophysics at the Western Australian Institute of Technology? Does the Minister support this concept? If so, will she see that the Commonwealth Government institutes its own similar affirmative action incentive so that women are not only encouraged but also enabled to take up tertiary courses leading to careers in traditional male fields?

—I did see that article very briefly. I noted with approval the fact that members of the Government and members of the Australian Democrats are not the only people who are concerned about more educational opportunities for women , particularly in fields from which they have been traditionally excluded. The Commonwealth Government intends to do a number of things which should lead to more access by women to such courses. I have already had discussions with the Tertiary Education Commission about the Government's objectives, which include a much higher participation by women in all forms of tertiary education, but with particular attention to areas such as nuclear research, engineering and so on in which women have been discriminated against by prejudice within institutions. I expect that in the guidelines I will be issuing to the Tertiary Education Commission for the funding of all tertiary institutions for the next triennium there will be some very clear statements of the Government's objectives. I hope that by that time the tertiary institutions will have discovered ways in which they can increase access of women to these courses. We do not have in mind at this stage any special scholarships aimed particularly at women, such as the one provided by a private donor, but we believe that all the resources of our tertiary institutions should be accessible to women students and researchers.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I am concerned that veterans who receive treatment through the repatriation hospital system have access to the same high standard of health care that is available to the general community, including access to high technology diagnostic equipment. I note that the Repatriation General Hospital, Concord, is now the second largest hospital in this country, after the Royal Prince Alfred Hospital; yet Concord does not have a CAT scanning facility. Can the Minister inform me whether it is the intention of the Government to provide veterans with the benefits of this high technology equipment at Concord?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question of standards in the repatriation general hospitals gives me some concern. Unfortunately, there have been 11 different Ministers in the Veterans' Affairs area in the last 12 years. I assure the Senate that that does not lead to the sort of administration that is necessary to have our repatriation hospitals regarded as an integral part of the public hospital system. There is a morale problem, along with other problems which need the attention of the Government. However, with respect to the repatriation hospital in Yaralla Street to which Senator Richardson referred, I and the Department have been concerned that the repatriation hospital system should be of the highest standard. I am sure that that is what the community wants too.

ANSWER.PARA: With regard to new technology, we intend to have installed a computerised axial tomographic scanner, which is an absolutely essential piece of equipment in order to increase the standards within our repatriation hospitals. This piece of technology has the objective of significantly improving the level of diagnostic accuracy and, as I understand it, it is an essential piece of equipment in all of our hospitals. In 1979, the previous Government made a decision to have such equipment approved, but it was not until the last Budget that the funds were actually provided. That seems to me to be an unnecessary delay in providing our hospitals, which look after war veterans, with essential pieces of equipment.

The scanner, as it is commonly called, reduces the risk to patients of many invasive diagnostic procedures which can and should be avoided. It will improve patient care considerably by the elimination of waiting times and the need for transport facilities to be provided for patients who currently must travel to units in other hospitals in order to have access to it. It also has the effect of reducing the operating costs at the hospital. Therefore, the CAT scanning facility is vitally essential in any modern hospital system. We will shortly be introducing that piece of equipment. I hope ultimately to convince the Government that such facilities should be provided in all of our repatriation hospitals.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy.
—This will be good.

—I will not indulge myself. I refer to the Minister's assurance that the proposed resource rental tax will be a replacement rather than an additional tax. Can he explain to the Senate whether he intends merely to replace the former tax or whether the proposed tax will be used to raise additional revenue for the Commonwealth?
—I call the Minister.
—Now restrain yourself.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will. The proposal-I do not know how many times I have to say this-is that it be a replacement tax. The question of the absolute amount of tax which would be collected in various areas is, of course, one which governments decide from year to year. Perhaps I should lodge one caveat to that: The discredited former Government introduced a whole heap of tax concessions in its last 12 months in office, the cost of which, of course, was deferred to a future government.

ANSWER.PARA: Apart from being a replacement tax, the intention is that a stable tax regime be introduced, the precise details of which are yet to be worked out, but which will remain fixed for as long as possible. I add that this will be in marked contrast to the record of the discredited former Government when, in its last three years in office, it made changes to the taxation laws affecting the mining industry on no fewer than five occasions-five changes in three years-thereby showing its complete disregard for one of the important principles affecting the growth and health of the Australian mining industry, that is, that the tax regime which the industry must cope with must be predictable and must remain stable. That is the objective of this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Walsh might first of all give us an assurance that the revenue raised will be of the same scale as that which has been raised in the past, explain to us whether there will be a distraction from the revenue presently received by the States and give us an assurance that there will be no additional revenue to the Commonwealth. I wonder whether he might tell us what process and calculations will be used in achieving his objectives?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought I had answered that already. When I heard the States mentioned, I though that Senator Crichton-Browne might say something about States' rights which would have prompted me to repeat a comment I made yesterday . In reply to Senator Crichton-Browne I said that the precise details-I have said this on numerous occasions both outside the Parliament and, I think, inside it-are yet to be worked out, and they will be discussed over an extended period with the industry.

ANSWER.PARA: So far as the same amount of revenue is concerned, the one area where, of course, the Commonwealth does have virtually unimpeded power to change the tax system is the taxing of crude oil. It is the intention that in that area the amount of revenue raised will be comparable to that raised by the current levy, but it will be raised in a more efficient way.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs. During the election campaign a promise was made by the then shadow Minister of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to provide funds to help establish a Chair of Modern Greek at Flinders University, South Australia. I understand that funds were to be provided by the Federal Government sufficient to meet the salary costs of a professor in modern Greek and that the local community and the South Australian Government would also provide support funds. Will the Minister say whether any further consideration has been given to this promise? If so, what stage have the deliberations reached?

—Further consideration has been given to this proposal. I am aware that there is a great deal of interest in it in South Australia and that a Committee for the Teaching of Modern Greek at a University in South Australia has been formed and is very active. The progress that has been made is as follows: I understand that the Flinders University has included a proposal to establish a Chair in Modern Greek in its submission for the 1985-87 triennium to the Universities Council of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission. The Universities Council will be discussing the submission with the University during its visit to Adelaide at the end of June this year. Of course, the honourable senator will be aware that the Government receives advice on developments of this sort from the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission. The Government will have the opportunity to consider the Commission's advice in the light of its pre-election undertaking when the Commission reports in April 1984.
—Mr President, in accordance with the Standing Orders, I ask that the document quoted from by Senator Ryan be tabled.
—I am perfectly happy to table the document. I now table the document.

—Does the Minister for Resources and Energy agree that the oil pricing arrangements for new oil found in Australia were a considerable incentive to oil exploration in Australia? If so, does he agree that any change in taxation which lessens that incentive will prejudice both exploration and future domestic production of oil in this country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The present exemption from levy of oil discovered after 1975-76 was based on a presumption that any new discoveries would be high cost oil, because it was in small pools, in remote locations, at great depth, or off-shore . If that expectation, upon which the present policy was founded, is borne out by history, the type of tax that this Government is proposing will not affect those fields. If, on the other hand, that expectation should be wrong and, unlikely though it is, an oil field comparable to Bass Strait is discovered no realist would expect that any government would allow an oil strike of that magnitude to remain subject only to normal company taxation. Such an unrealistic expectation once applied to producers of Bowen Basin coal. They found out how wrong they were when the Queensland Government started imposing both heavy royalties and heavy, above-economic freight charges for transport to the ports.

ANSWER.PARA: With respect to oil exploration, I refer to an editorial which appeared in last weekend's Weekend Australian which endorsed the sentiments expressed by Senator Reid. It states:
. . . the existing policy of taxing newly discovered oil at a lower rate than existing fields has led to an unprecedented increase in local oil exploration.

There is a minor error of fact in that, but given the magnitude of the factual errors which appear in editorials in that newspaper by the same author I will not go into that minor error; I will deal just with the major error. There has been a bipartisan policy ever since 1975 to pay the import parity price for new oil discoveries. I have before me a record of petroleum exploration and development in Australia over the last eight years which shows the number of exploration wells drilled in that period. In 1976, 19 wells were drilled and, in 1977, 21 wells. In 1978, the figure had increased slightly to 55 wells and, in 1979, 52 wells were drilled. Then the figure took off, almost doubling in 1980 to 94 wells, increasing by 60 per cent in 1981 to 158 wells and increasing by 40 per cent to 226 in the 1982 calendar year.

The point I make is that it was not the bipartisan import parity pricing which stimulated oil exploration; it was the second Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries price hike, which I remind honourable senators happened in 1979. In 1980, the year following, exploration really took off. As a matter of historical fact, it was not the import parity pricing policy per se which led to the increase in oil exploration; it was the doubling of oil prices in a 12-month period in 1979 and early 1980. Because in real terms and even in money terms the world price of oil has been falling over the last 12 months, there is already a decline in exploration activity. I would expect that a supplementary reason for that decline would be the absense of any major strike, although a number of significant strikes have been made. The important point is that the world price of oil has declined, even in money terms, by about 17 per cent and, over the last couple of years, by a great deal more than that in real terms.

I draw attention to the fact that the Bureau of Mineral Resources has forecast that just over 100 wells will be drilled in 1983 as against 226 wells in 1982. This was a forecast made, I hasten to add, in January 1983 before the Federal election was called and before the Government had changed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walsh, you are tending to debate the matter now. I suggest that you restrict your remarks.

—I am sorry, Mr President. I will finish very quickly. If the BMR is thought to be a suspect source under the previous Administration, I would like to quote from a Press statement issued by the Petroleum Exploration Association Ltd on 1 February this year. It states:

ANSWER.PARA: Plans for seismic work-the essential precursor to drilling-are at one of their lowest levels in the past decade and indicate that a dramatic slump could occur in drilling in 1984-85 if the industry is unable to raise large-scale support from Australian investors.

That rundown in exploration activity was under way at the end of last year and the beginning of this year. However, if precedent is any guide, I do not expect that an inconvenient fact such as that will prevent the Liberal and National parties from misrepresenting what is already happening and attributing it to the election of a Labor government.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF SOCIAL SECURITY: ADELAIDE COMPUTER SYSTEM

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. Is it a fact that the Adelaide computer system of the Department of Social Security broke down on Tuesday? If this is so, what arrangements were made to process Northern Territory social security cheques normally processed in Adelaide? Can beneficiaries expect delays in delivery?

—Yes, the computer facilities in the Department of Social Security in Adelaide did break down on Tuesday. This is an unfortunate event which occurs too often in an automatic data processing system throughout Australia which is old and in many cases obsolete. Moves were made by the Department to transfer the processing of those cheques to Melbourne. At the moment we do not expect any delays in cheques that would have originally come out of the Adelaide office. Work is proceeding at the moment to get the computer mechanisms in Adelaide back on line. At the moment the Melbourne backup is satisfactory. The Government also has before it a program of re-equipping the computer system in the Department of Social Security which has been developed over the last two years. A decision will be made on that shortly.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is it not a fact that the Melbourne system also broke down due to overloading? If so, why is Melbourne the only back up system when Perth was given approval in 1981?

—I am not aware that the Melbourne system broke down through overloading. I will check on that for the honourable senator. I am also not aware of the honourable senator's assertion that our Perth system was meant to be developed as a backup system for Adelaide in 1981. I will check on both those facts with the Department and let the honourable senator know later.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Does the Government accept that nuclear power will have to play a major and increasing role in many countries in contributing to overall long term peacetime energy security? Further, does the Government accept the importance of encouraging stable trade in nuclear fuel?

—I think I have the honourable senator's comment accurately. He asks: Does the Government accept that nuclear power will have to play a major and increasing role? No, the Government does not accept that because it is not correct. The honourable senator uses the words 'will have to play'. It may or may not play an increasing role. It does not have to play an increasing role because there are alternatives to nuclear power. In most situations the alternatives are available at lower cost although probably not in all situations . So the question as to whether nuclear power will play a major and increasing role, political considerations aside, will be determined by the relative cost-I suppose this is, to some extent, a political consideration-and the relative assessments which varying countries will make not only of cost but also of environment and other considerations that will arise. As to the second part of Senator Sir John Carrick's question, the policy of the Labor Party on this question has been published for five years so it ought to be well known. As I mentioned in reply to questions asked yesterday, the matter of safeguards, among other things, is currently under review.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. In view of the answer of Senator Walsh, I ask: Is it a fact that at the International Energy Agency meeting held a week or so ago his Government and he were represented by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden. I ask whether it is a fact that Mr Hayden was a signatory to the communique which stated:

QUESTION.PARA: Ministers stress the importance of encouraging stable trade in nuclear equipment, fuel cycle services and nuclear fuel.

If that is so and those are the facts-and I have read from the communique-why is it that Mr Hayden committed this country to a policy which is completely different from and totally opposed to what the Minister has said? Why is it that the IEA and the Ministers concerned have concentrated on asserting the imperative need for nuclear energy? Can the Minister please explain why this ministerial representative differs so markedly from him, or did he think it was a good idea at the time?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not able to confirm whether that statement is a precise account of what was issued.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have the communique.
—The honourable senator need not bother, and he should not get excited. I am aware-
—I suggest that Senator Walsh answer the supplementary question.

—I am aware that a general agreement which is, broadly and in principle, in accord with that sort of statement was issued and that Mr Hayden was a party to it. I am sure that Senator Sir John Carrick knows very well that statements issued at the end of any such conference are an indication of broad agreement and that, except in ultra-special circumstances, no conference participant is likely to issue an explicit repudiation of a general sort of remark. That did not happen in this case. I stress that that statement commits Australia to no specific action. It constitutes an agreement to go along with the broad statement of intent and assessment. I suppose that if Senator Sir John Carrick wanted to be pedantic and think that a stable trade in uranium is the paramount objective, he would be somewhat in conflict with his apparent preference for a rapidly increasing trade in uranium.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Given the concerns that I and many other of my colleagues have expressed many times in this place on matters relating to family law, will the Attorney-General comment on the article appearing in today's Sydney Morning Herald in which a Sydney barrister, Laurence Gruzman, Q.C., criticises a number of aspects of the operation of the Family Court of Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article headed 'The court that could be even more friendly' written by Laurence Gruzman which appears in today's Sydney Morning Herald. He makes a number of significant criticisms of the operation of the Court to which I think it is appropriate to respond briefly. Firstly, he says that there is a three-year delay in hearing property matters. As to that criticism I say that there are property cases that can take three years to be heard. However, on my advice, the delays in those cases are very much attributable to the parties or their advisers rather than to the Family Court itself. Presently the delay between the time a property case is ready to be heard and its hearing is 12 months in the Sydney Registry of the Court. He also says that the Family Court applies technical rules more rigidly than most courts . I simply believe that that is untrue.

ANSWER.PARA: The Family Law Act and the regulations under it require the Court to proceed without undue formality and expressly provide that non-compliance with formalities is not to be penalised. A further criticism is that the Family Court is unable to deal with what he describes as the wife avoidance industry-for example, husbands arranging assets to circumvent Court orders. In reply to that comment I say that there is a view that litigants have not, to date, tested the full extent of the Family Court's powers to deal with this problem. Sections 85 and 114 of the Act are relevant in that respect. To that extent, I suggest, it is partly the fault of the legal profession that the wife avoidance industry is becoming, in many ways, as prevalent as tax avoidance has been in recent times.

There are a further couple of criticisms relating to the jurisdiction of the Court suggesting there ought to be appeal rights to the Federal Court of Australia and that the Supreme Court should have jurisdiction to hear property cases involving sums of over $300,000. Suggestions of this kind are similar to a number of suggestions that are now under active consideration in the context of the proposal for an integrated national courts system. Certainly the Government will be taking that kind of view into account.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have an answer to a question raised by Senator Harradine in this place on 5 May which I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard.

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

On 5 May 1983, Senator Harradine asked a question concerning the extent of press and speech freedom among Unesco member countries, Unesco involvement in the New World Information and Communication Order, and Australian involvement in the Unesco International Program for Development of Communication.

The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer: Among the 158 member nations of Unesco there are some whose governments have very different ideas about freedom, including Press freedom, from those espoused by the Australian Government and people. The Government accepts that, in any international organisation where membership is open to all states, such differences are inevitable.

The honourable senator will be aware that debate on a possible New World Information and Communication Order has been continuing in the international community since the early 1970s. UNESCO has, by virtue of its mandate, been closely involved in these discussions. In particular, its contribution has been the creation in 1980 of an International Program for the Development of Communication, which seeks to move the debate away from rhetoric in a more practical direction. The IPDC was designed as a clearing house, matching communication needs with available resources and assessing global priorities, IPDC activity is funded both from UNESCO's regular program budget and from a special account set up for this purpose, Australia of course contributes to the regular program budget. It has not contributed to the special account.

As a nation which enjoys the benefit of an unfettered and active media, Australia has a long-standing interest in international discussion of communications issues. We shall continue to ensure that our voice is heard on these matters in international bodies and we shall speak in favour of the freest possible flow of news and ideas between nations. So far as the IPDC is concerned , we shall continue to encourage it to concentrate on practical measures which will assist developing countries to improve the standard of their communications facilities and the quality of their media.
