TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a matter during this debate regarding a decision taken over the last year by the Australian Broadcasting Commission in South Australia and in respect of the position of the radio drama producer in South Australia. It is a decision which, as I go through the recent history of it and the rationale behind it, I will attempt to indicate is shortsighted, inconsistent and convoluted in its process. On 2 April 1982 the ABC's then radio drama producer in South Australia, Mr Herbert Davies, retired. For a period before that time and for the period since, the relevant associations, be they the ABC Staff Association or the Actors Equity Association of Australia in that State, have consistently attempted to have a person appointed to fill the vacancy. Their attempts have been met with a stonewalling action from the ABC, a response which does not hold water.

SPEECH.PARA: There is, I submit, a rather strong case for the filling of the vacancy. At the moment in South Australia we have a production capacity, both in terms of studio space and facilities as well as in the area of work opportunities, which has not been met. In recent years ABC radio drama in South Australia has provided valuable work opportunities for South Australian actors. As well as that it has also produced opportunities for South Australian writers. In fact in 1981 when one radio drama was being produced in South Australia every three weeks by the ABC at its Collinswood studios, 15 per cent of members of Actors Equity in South Australia were employed by the Commission in relation to that radio drama. Quite a number of people have been employed directly and indirectly as a consequence of production related to and centred on the position of ABC radio drama producer in that State. It is also incongruous to note in passing that a State that is recognised Australia-wide and, to a certain extent world-wide, as having a deep and rather developed interest in the arts, is at the moment neglecting one very important aspect of art.

I mentioned earlier that the decision-making process in this matter is one that indicates a certain amount of inconsistency and a lack of, shall we say, sincerity by the management involved. I also mentioned that the problems have arisen because of the retirement of Mr Herbert Davies over 13 months ago. Since then we have had a series of machinations and manoeuvres that have led virtually nowhere. I suggest that in the course of that period the ABC has shown a certain degree of unacceptable inconsistency in the way in which it has approached its industrial relations and its decision-making process. I mentioned that before Mr Davies' retirement the imminent problem was raised by the ABC Staff Association as well as Actors Equity. In fact it had been raised a number of times, and the first response of any substance came from the ABC's Chief Manager in South Australia, Mr John Geyer, on 8 July 1982 when, in response to a complaint from the ABC Staff Association, he replied:
Before commenting on the position in question, I would prefer to know the recommendations of the Media Management Working Group which is due to complete its report tomorrow week.

In essence, he was promising an answer within a couple of weeks. The management group did report but the appearance of the report was delayed. However, on 22 September 1982, approximately two months after Mr Geyer's reply, the group made a number of recommendations, one of which was that the position be advertised internally and externally as a permanent vacancy-a vacancy that should be filled from either within or outside the Australian Broadcasting Commission. No substantive action was taken, however, and the associations kept on pursuing the matter, only to be informed by the Acting Assistant General Manager (Radio), on 22 October, approximately a month later, that it was no longer a matter of implementing the working group's report. The relevant feature was referred to by the person acting in the position, Betty Parsons, who said:
I have been seeking information about the likely drama production load in South Australia and hope this will be provided shortly to Mr Mackriell.

It seems, then, that the decision was to be based on a new aspect, one that had been brought in three months after the complaint had been made by the relevant association. However, it did not end there, because approximately two weeks later a proposition was put to the Staff Association that a particular person be transferred from the Tasmanian radio drama section of the ABC to Adelaide. That, in itself, could well have been an acceptable proposition but for the fact that the person to be appointed was nearing the end of a term of service and was also due to retire within a short time. The associations involved at that stage felt that that would be unacceptable in light of the fact that what was needed was someone who could generate and plan into both the short and the long term future a role for ABC radio drama in that State.

In the meantime, the associations were obviously having problems with their membership, and industrial action was mooted. It was not taken, but the suggestion of industrial action, which was a rather muted one, was seized upon later by the Acting General Manager (Radio) in South Australia as an excuse for not taking any immediate action to satisfy the problem that was obviously developing. On 23 December 1982 the Acting General Manager (Radio) wrote back to the associations involved and said that this time one of the problems that had developed was that the insistence by the ABC Staff Association that the position be officially advertised had led to an administrative delay and as a consequence no action had been taken to fill the position.

Two points need to be made. Firstly, administrative procedures should not take the time that they had taken to that date and, secondly, the propostion of which the Acting General Manager complained was one which had been put forward by the body set up by the ABC in South Australia to investigate the problem in the first instance. The Acting General Manager went on to say:

I will be contacting in the near future the Controllers of the Networks and the Director of Radio Drama. When we have had an opportunity to canvass further all the issues involved I shall, as promised, be in touch with you again.

Procrastination then seemed to be the order of the day. The situation has not been improved since that day. There have been continual requests and demands from the ABC Staff Association, together with Actors and Announcers Equity, both on a State level and on a Federal level. Despite all this there has been no definite and clear response by the ABC to these organisations.

I raise this matter as one of extreme importance, not in terms of an assessment of how the ABC's decision-making process works or does not work but because of the fact that a number of South Australians who are professionals in this area, who have worked in this area in the past and who would be looking for work opportunities in this area are being denied these opportunities because of the procrastination in decision-making and because of a lack of decisiveness in this area. As I mentioned earlier, a substantial proportion of Actors Equity membership in South Australia had worked in ABC radio drama production. Now those people, because of the general recession that Australia finds itself in, also because of the peculiar problems of the industry and the stagnation in production by ABC radio in the State, are finding that this source of employmennt opportunity is now not available to them.

I hope that by raising this matter in the Senate I will be able to precipitate some definite response from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation in terms of satisfying the request. It seems to me that the decision taken so far-which, essentially, is not to take a decision-is one that generates unemployment rather than one which generates economic activity. To that extent it would run counter to the economic direction of this newly elected Labor Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address the question of drought relief. I think all honourable senators would be aware of the previous Government's initiatives designed and brought to bear to alleviate the drought experienced in the eastern States. The importance of primary industry to Australia's economy should not be underestimated. The most recent figures available from the Australian Bureau of Statistics show that in the financial year 1980-81 exports of rural origin accounted for 42.6 per cent of Australian exports. In current dollar terms that amounts to $8,071m earned and generated outside capital cities, on our farms. Ten years ago, prior to most of the major mining projects coming on stream, rural production accounted for 48.9 per cent of Australia's export earnings, or in 1970-71 terms something like $2, 075m. In other words, rural industries have retained their position as our most single important export dollar earners despite major investments in mining and manufacturing in the last decade. They have not in any way significantly reduced their share of our export earnings. To me that is a clear argument for a sensitive approach by government to the problems of primary producers, especially in a drought situation. As I have said, the actions of the past Government were sensitive, understanding and commendable in view of the problems being faced by farmers particularly in drought areas.

SPEECH.PARA: What concerns me, as a senator from Western Australia, is that governments do not seem to be as effective as they might be in recognising all the problems caused by drought particularly when we have recurring bad seasons and not just a single bad season. No doubt the difficulties of Western Australia have been masked by the fact that in the 1982-83 season wheat production in Western Australia was 5.22 million tonnes, which represented 66.7 per cent of Australia' s total production. One could be forgiven for concluding that farmers in Western Australia had a bumper year, but it may surprise honourable senators to learn that many of them did not. Most of those in the north-eastern wheat belt, particularly in shires such as Mullewa, Morawa, Perenjori, Dalwallinu, Koorda and Mount Marshall, have experienced drought for six of the last seven years. In the south-east of the State, around Ravensthorpe and Gnowangerup, drought declarations have been in effect for three of the last six years. The area north of Esperance has likewise been drought declared for three of the last six years. In 1976-77 there were 2,670 drought declared farms in Western Australia, and about the same number the following year. The number was 1,304 in 1979-80 and 3, 924 in 1980-81. Even in the last season, in which Western Australia accounted for two-thirds of the national output of wheat, 1,653 farms were still under drought.

It seems to me that until a widespread drought of the type that the eastern States has experienced takes hold, the problems of farmers in relatively small and, to some degree, isolated areas of Australia are largely ignored or not understood. I make that point quite deliberately. Until last year the main drought relief mechanism was the so-called carry-on finance arrangement which was jointly funded by the Commonwealth and the States on a three-for-one basis. One glaring weakness in that arrangement was that farmers were able to qualify for the loan at the concessional rate of 4 per cent only when they could show that finance was not available from normal conventional sources such as banks and stock firms. In other words, to qualify for assistance, a farmer had already to be in dire straits to the point at which conventional financial institutions were no longer willing to assist. That is really a case of the door being closed after the horse has bolted.

To some extent the interest rate subsidy overcomes some of the financial problems faced by farmers by assisting in loan repayments to the extent of subsidising interest payments above 12 per cent. The subsidy will apply in cases of existing debt prior to 31 August 1982 and carry-on finance debt incurred as a result of drought after that date. However, this scheme does not strike at the vital question, in my view, of the structure of rural debt. The question is of particular importance in my own State, as is shown by the estimates which I will now enumerate. They have been provided by the Primary Industry Association of Western Australia. They demonstrate that the estimated average farm debt as at 30 June 1982 was, in New South Wales, $39,700; in Victoria, $35,800; in Queeensland, $69,300; in South Australia, $57,000; in Tasmania, $63,600; and in Western Australia, $75,000. The average farm debt in Western Australia is, therefore, by far the highest in Australia. Of course, that average underestimates the position of those in drought affected areas, particularly those suffering from recurrent drought situations.

The interest subsidy announced by the previous Government will benefit mainly farmers who have recently moved into the industry; that is, those farmers who would be expecting to pay the contemporary high interest rates which have prevailed in recent years. They, of course, will be the ones who have the highest debt load. The subsidy will also apply to farmers who have recently purchased new equipment. Once again, farmers in the north-east wheat belt area are a good example. With the recurrent droughts in that area, many farmers have moved progressively out of sheep and wheat farming into exclusively, or at least predominantly, grain production, necessitating higher hire purchase commitments brought about by increasing mechanisation. In other words, a decision brought about by climatic factors has contributed to a higher debt amongst those farmers who by reason of successive poorseasons are least able to service their debts. It is not a matter of competence or incompetence but simply one of a rational economic decision being affected by the intangible factor of climate. Short term debts with a high amortisation factor can also be incurred by farmers whose properties are perhaps too small and who have sought to overcome their problems by further land acquisition. That has been particularly true in the south-east of Western Australia, where once again prolonged droughts have adversely affected a farmer's ability to meet his new and ever-demanding financial commitments. Once again it is a case of an intangible factor being imposed on what was at the time a perfectly rational economic decision.

I suggest that the dilemma lies in the present structure of rural debt. The present drought assistance loans work over a maximum period of seven years at an interest rate of 4 per cent with a holiday on repayments for the first two years . Repayments in years three to seven are made at the rate of 24.3c for each $1 of the loan, which in fact is roughly the same as a seven year loan with no holiday on repayments at an interest rate of 16 per cent. The latter situation provides that annual repayments be made at the rate of 24.7 per cent for each $1 of loan. Of course, there is no repayment-free period in the latter case. But these two repayment-free years in the first case are of little benefit to farmers such as those in the north-eastern wheat belt who have been in a drought situation for six of the last seven years.

If rural debt were to be restructured over a longer period-say, over 15 years- at 16 per cent, repayments would be made at an annual rate of approximately 17. 9c per each $1 of debt, representing a saving on annual repayments of $6,357 on a loan of $100,000 which, of course, far exceeds the average farm debt in Western Australia. But the effect would be quite dramatic. The annual saving on repayments would enable a farmer to borrow an additional $35,400 which, at an average cost of $50 a hectare, would allow an additional 708 hectares to be cropped. The break-even yield on these additional 708 hectares-that is, the yield at which that additional debt could be completely serviced-is a mere 0.45 tonnes a hectare. That is less than half the average yield in Western Australia, at 1.08 tonnes per hectare on an average over the last 10 years. At that average yield, and assuming a perfectly elastic demand for wheat, the additional land under crop would generate of the order of $86,000 in additional revenue, which could in part be put towards the overall farm debt.

To put all this into perspective, as I indicated earlier, 1977-78 was a bad year for drought in Western Australia, with 2,510 farms affected over 31 shires. Yields in those north-eastern wheat belt shires amounted to about 45 per cent of the 1975-76 non-drought total, implying that even in the drought years the yields would have been sufficient to service the additional debt brought about by bringing new areas into production. In better years, even in marginally better years which could still be described as drought years, farmers could expect additional revenue under this scheme. The other side of the coin for farmers who do not have additional land to bring into production is that the savings on repayments can be put towards recurrent production costs. For example , the Shire of Morawa is one of those shires which have been affected by drought in six of the last seven years. The average size of a farm in that shire is approximately 2,000 hectares. Because of the drought in that area, farmers are frequently in a position of having to borrow all, or most, of the following year 's production costs. However, under the restructured rural debt scheme that I have outlined, farmers in that shire would have their liquidity position for the current program improved to the extent of about one-third of production costs.

There is no doubt that as a result of recurrent debts and droughts in some parts of Australia which have been largely ignored in recent years because relatively small areas have been involved, a restructuring of rural debt is essential. It is one thing to recognise hardship while a drought declaration is current and quite another to understand that the hardships do not end with the first rains, which is the impression that seems to be given by many people, particularly those in the Parliament who have no understanding of rural matters. In my view a restructuring of rural debt will address both problems. What is necessary to bring that about is a recognition of what constitutes a drought-not a major drought such as one which strikes the eastern States and which attracts headlines because everybody recognises it, but perhaps the more geographically confined droughts such as those in the north-eastern wheat belt and the lower Great Southern regions of Western Australia that have been suffering badly. If the recent comments of the Western Australian Premier, Mr Burke, are any indication, it will be a problem for some time-at least as long as the Labor Government is in office in Western Australia. Honourable senators may recall that only some weeks ago, Mr Burke, the Australian Labor Party Premier of Western Australia, on his departure to the magnificent National Economic Summit, said that Western Australia could pull Australia out of its recession because, amongst other reasons, it had not suffered from drought. I only hope that that is not the level of perception of rural matters in every part of the ALP in Western Australia and Canberra. If so, our rural industries will be in a very sorry state.

I conclude by saying that changes are needed not only in the Parliament and the rural community, but in the community as a whole to ensure that the intrinsic, vital and significant contribution that is made to our economy, the decentralisation of our community and strengthening of the fabric of society, as we understand it, is recognised. Until we are prepared to come to grips with and recognise the vital role and the heavy burden under which the rural community is labouring with respect to increasing costs, and the ever increasing costs cast upon it by more and more protection, the rural sector will continue to suffer. Alleviating the problems caused by drought, including the attendant question of rural debt, will be a crucial starting point and should demand our immediate attention.

SPEECH.PARA: I use this first reading debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 5) 1982-83 to discuss the National Economic Summit Conference which was held in the national Parliament last month and the attempts by the Opposition to tear apart its achievements. The Summit, which was the brainchild of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), was, of course, foreshadowed during the election campaign in February and as such represented the fulfilment of a promise made to the people of Australia. It involved the coming together of governments, unions, business leaders and various professional and employer organisations in a spirit of consensus and co-operation in a way never seen before in this country. It was supported by most major newspapers and by all sections of the Australian community except, of course, the Federal Opposition led by Mr Peacock and Mr Howard, who insisted that they should have been invited. An extract from the Adelaide Advertiser of 6 April refers to the behaviour of the Opposition. It states:
The Federal Opposition and the Australian Democrats have been loud in their criticism of the Government's failure to invite them to take part in the Summit.
Many of those whose interests they represent, however, will have voices at the Conference and the politicians themselves have Parliament as an adequate forum for their views.
On the subject of Opposition representation at the Summit, the Weekend Australian of 9-10 April stated:

. . . if Mr Peacock and Mr Anthony were to be taking part, the Conference would probably be little more than a replica of the Federal Parliament, augmented by a host of private citizens sitting not in the gallery, but on the floor of the House.
The Fraser government could not complain that Mr Hawke failed to tell them of his intention to hold a summit. It was the centre-piece of his election campaign .
It was during the campaign that the Liberal and National Parties should have raised these objections in principle which seem to have occurred to them only after the votes were counted.

So much for the Opposition's criticism of the Summit! The Government did not pretend that it was a cure all and end all. It was meant to achieve some common ground and general agreement on a whole range of important economic issues and to set down the framework for Australia's economic recovery. One of the important achievements of the Conference was the agreement to return to centralised wage fixation. This will end the uncertainty and chaos which has characterised our wages system since wage indexation was abolished in 1981. It is no coincidence that the large increase in wages in 1981 and 1982, which the Liberal-National Party coalition has blamed for all our economic woes, was brought about as a direct result of the Fraser Government's decision to abolish wage indexation. Therefore, if anyone is to be blamed for this so-called wages explosion, it is the previous Government, not the workers or the unions. The return to a centralised wage fixing system will see a return to a more orderly and fairer system, with all sectors of the working community able to share the burden of restraint more equitably.

The Conference sought and obtained restraint from all parties. For their part, the unions agreed to forgo any wage catch-ups during this period of economic crisis, and employers similarly agreed to restraint in areas of pricing and the issue of dividends. The Conference also recognised that non-wage income must not be allowed to increase at a rate faster than ordinary wages. For their part, the governments, both Federal and State, agreed to keep all increases in charges to a minimum. In the area of industrial relations, the moves foreshadowed by the Government in paragraph 34 to abolish the Industrial Relations Bureau and to facilitate the amalgamation of unions in line with the National Labour Consultative Council's recommendations as contained in the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill 1983 will go a long way towards achieving a more peaceful and harmonious industrial relations climate. The proposed review of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and regulations will also result in a vast improvement in legislation in the industrial relations area. I was also pleased to see that the Summit recognised the need to give greater priority to occupational health and safety in the work place and the need for a concerted effort by all parties to improve the general quality of the working environment in Australia. The Summit also agreed on the need to establish the Economic Planning Advisory Council-known as EPAC-so that the spirit of consensus and the process of consultation can be carried on in the months and years ahead. This Council is to consist of Government Ministers, representatives of the States, business, unions, farmers and a representative from community support groups. The Summit has been hailed as an outstanding success by all of those who participated except, of course, Mr Bjelke-Petersen, Mr Gray and the Federal Opposition. At the conclusion of the Conference, Mr D. J. Hughes, President of the Confederation of Australian Industry, said:

The National Economic Summit has been an historic milestone in Australia's history. Never before have we witnessed such a bringing together of the representatives of diverse groups which make up our total community. The fact that the Commonwealth Government, through the Prime Minister and his senior Ministers, has met in an open forum with State Premiers and Ministers, with the full Executive of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, with representatives of a broad cross-section of Australian industry and commerce and the wide spectrum of community groups, indicates beyond question, the deep understanding which the Government has of this nation's present problems and its preparedness frankly and fully to discuss those problems with a view to producing acceptable, realistic and workable solutions.
In its appraisal of the Summit, the Melbourne Age had this to say:

The Economic Summit Conference has achieved more than optimistic realists dared to hope and pessimistic cynics were prepared to predict . . . The Summit was not simply a cleverly staged spectacle designed to display the conciliatory skills of Mr Hawke or to demonstrate a degree of consensus that does not really exist. It was the auspicious beginning of a long and difficult process to lift Australia from the depth of recession, and of a new style of government involving a measure of consultation and participation not hitherto attempted in this country.

Of course, the Summit in itself will not solve our problems, but it is a start, and it represents the end of seven years of divisiveness and despair for the Australian people. Given the general agreement on the success of the Summit, one would have thought that the Leader of the Opposition would have recognised its achievement. Instead, he continued to alienate himself and his party from the Australian people by knocking the Summit and the Prime Minister. He is attempting to undermine the efforts being made by this Government to revive the economy, just as he attempted to undermine the Constitutional Convention earlier this month.

I think the Opposition would have done itself a favour by joining with the rest of the community in helping to make this thing work. Instead, it has deliberately tried to disrupt this Government's attempts to seek consensus and has jumped on to every single issue and declared it a national scandal. It has now been joined by the newspapers-principally the Murdoch Press-in a dishonest and desperate attempt to create an air of crisis. One has only to look at the headlines in the Australian for the last two weeks to get an idea of the dirty smear campaign being waged by the Murdoch Press against the Hawke Government. It has even resorted to the dishonourable tactic of placing editorials on the front page. I believe that the actions of the Opposition and sections of the print media amount to an act of sabotage. Perhaps we should get the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation to look into the relationship between the Opposition and the Murdoch Press, because what they are doing is clearly against the national interests.

For the last three weeks, in fact since the Senate started sitting on 21 April, the Opposition has asked only two questions relating to unemployment, and even then it was the tired old line about the link between wages and unemployment. That is clear evidence of the Opposition's lack of concern for the welfare of the Australian people. It is too busy digging up scandals and muckraking to care about the ordinary men and women in the community and the well-being of the Australian economy. That is why it will stay on the Opposition benches for the rest of this decade. It is totally devoid of policies, and has the audacity to criticise our wages accord, despite the fact that it does not have any wages policy of its own. It is about time the Opposition stopped knocking and became more constructive in its contributions to this Parliament. Perhaps it could learn from the Australian Democrats in this regard. If the Opposition keeps up this sort of tactic, I am sure that it will not be long before we see Mr Peacock sitting on the back benches again.
To sum up, I would like to quote the Prime Minister's words at the conclusion of the Conference. He said:

We do not have to believe that a conference like this can achieve a total resolution of conflict. The nature of our system, the very condition of freedom, the most priceless asset that we have as a society, mitigates against that . . . But what we have achieved at this Conference-I believe most deeply-is a basic consensus on some fundamental issues of key importance to the social and economic future of Australia.
I do not think anybody could disagree that this sort of consensus is very desirable, and forms a very sound basis indeed on which to rebuild our depressed economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —A recent American President said: ' Yesterday is not ours to recover, but tomorrow is ours to win or lose'. This is a vital time in Australia's development. We have deluded ourselves into unrealistic expectations and now crisis is upon us. We have overpaid and overserviced ourselves to a stage where our inflation rate is now double that of our trading partners. In such circumstances we simply cannot remain competitive. We have unemployment levels that are intolerable. Not only are we failing to utilise the most valuable of our resources-that of our potential work force-but also we will face increasing social stress from the mere existence of such a large section of Australians being frustrated and disappointed by the failure of our economic system to accommodate their reasonable expectations. The key to overcoming the current crisis is to provide the environment and incentives for economic growth.

SPEECH.PARA: It was one of the great disappointments of the National Economic Summit Conference that under the guidelines of traditional Australian Labor Party philosophy, and despite lip service to the contrary, the concentration was upon the equitable redistribution of resources-although a worthwhile objective in itself-rather than on economic growth, which can result in redistribution of greater resources and therefore improve the material well-being of all Australians. Those of us who are looking for a blueprint for growth were sorely disappointed. In that spirit I have in this chamber in the past looked at the subject of taxation incentives and have called for measures to help in updating plant and equipment, such as increased depreciation rates and the reduction of disincentives such as double taxation on dividends. I have been pleased to see some concrete change for the better, which I have applauded as it has come about . I have looked at comparisons of government encouragement of industrial development in our competitors, and in particular analysed and made recommendations in relation to our system of export encouragement. Before the election I had intended to move on to the subject of the role of government in industrial research and development, which I still intend to do as soon as possible.

Within the scenario of economic growth I wish today to look at the sector of the community which received the most marked neglect by the Economic Conference. The sector I wish to examine, and which in all likelihood holds the key to the most rapid absorption of our army of unemployed and to making the most significant contribution to economic growth in the short term, is small business . Small business was directly represented by just one of the 100 official organisations and indirectly by a few of the delegates to the Summit, and received but one cursory comment in the 55-paragraph communique. Yet the new Labor Government would do well to appreciate its significance in the Australian economy and community. Mr Don Gibbons, Chairman of the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia, who was the only direct delegate from small business to the Conference, estimated that there are 400,000 small businesses throughout Australia, which excludes primary producers. COSBOA has further estimated that small enterprises account for between 50 per cent and 60 per cent of total employment in the private sector and that its contribution to gross national product is about the same as that of big business, which of course had many delegates to the Conference, as did big unions.

This Government should beware of the apparently distorted view it is taking of business. When one is considering policy alternatives, such as increased protection to the steel industry which may result in higher steel prices, one must also consider the effects of such policy initiatives upon the many thousands of downstream small businesses utilising the products of that particular big business which might be detrimentally affected thereby.

A recent paper on small business in Australia, put out by the Legislative Research Service of the Parliamentary Library, attempted to summarise the economic and social importance of the small business sector. In relation to economic importance it adopted part of the United Kingdom Bolton Committee's assessment of importance of the activities of small firms as specialist suppliers of parts, components, et cetera; as a source of innovation in product technique and services; in providing competition checking monopoly profits and the inefficiency of monopoly; and as a productive outlet for the energies of enterprising and independent people. The report also referred to the importance of that sector in industries and trade in which the optimum size of the enterprise is small; the importance in providing products and services in a limited or specialised market which large firms would not find worth while or economic; as a breeding ground for new industries and as a means of entry into business for new entrepreneurial talents.

The social importance of small business includes its contribution to employment and its potential to reduce unemployment-each new job usually requiring less capital in the form of fixed assets; of particular importance, the usually closer relationship between employer and employee; and the opportunity it offers for equitable ownership of the nation's resources and potential, thus contributing to the decentralisation of economic power. The contribution in respect of a geographical decentralisation of the Australian economy is also significant. Given the economic and social importance of this sector, one could reasonably have thought that the opportunity for expansion, increased strength and growth of this sector would have been one of the major considerations of the Economic Summit. One must now also have some fear that the high profile action program for small business, promoted by the Australian Labor Party during the election campaign, is slipping in priority. Certainly, the health of the overall economy is of great benefit to small business. It will not simply come about by effluxion of time; rather it will come about by the application of specific beneficial policies. That is why the Conference communique was so disappointing. Considering the array of talent present one could reasonably have expected more than a series of motherhood statements.

The approach of COSBOA has been that anomalies have developed within our regulatory environment that specifically prejudice small business at the expense of big business. It is argued that to rectify these prejudices would in itself encourage expansion and growth of small business. Regrettably, none of its recommendations received mention in the communique. One distortion to which it refers is Division 7-undistributed profits tax. From the point of view of comparison between public and private companies or, speaking generally, big and small business, it means that the latter is prejudiced in its ability to obtain internally generated funds. The capacity to finance growth from its own funds is , of course, vitally important. The previous Government liberalised Division 7 by reducing to 20 per cent the after-tax trading profits that must be distributed to avoid undistributed profits tax. That trend deserves acknowledgement.

The second distortion relates to internal superannuation funds. Many small businesses are operated by sole traders or through partnerships, and they are prejudiced in relation to superannuation as compared with employee funds. For example, there are tax concessions for employer contributions to employee funds but to a fixed limit for self-employed persons. Income from employee funds is tax exempt, subject to the 30-20 rule, but all income over 5 per cent is taxable at 50 per cent for self-employed funds. The maximum benefit under employee funds tapers away above an annual average salary of $22,000. But self-employed funds are cut off at that figure and different retirement ages are provided. There is also prejudice against smaller company funds, as opposed to big company funds, in particular, by restricting the amount of contributions that can be claimed against taxable income.

The third area often raised by COSBOA relates to provisional tax. Provisional tax, for a given period, must be paid well in advance of company tax for the same period. Thus there is discrimination against the sole trader or partnership in favour of usually larger business operated through companies. Furthermore, the sole trader or partnership is obliged to pay the full sum of provisional tax at one time, whereas company tax is collected by quarterly instalments. It is not surprising, therefore, that small business organisations, such as COSBOA, have, for a very long time, been advocating that the forward spread payments of provisional tax be permitted on a quarterly basis. Unfortunately, again there is no mention of this in the communique.

Apart from these prejudices against small business which call for reform one would have thought that the Summit Conference would have turned its attention to areas of the structural management of the economy that inhibit free and fair competition and thus retard the growth and development of small business. The Trade Practices Act comes immediately to mind, a principal purpose of which is the protection of the weak from the predatory. Yet reports such as the report of the Trade Practices Consultative Committee entitled 'Small Business and the Trade Practices Act' have indicated a number of areas in which the Act is failing to achieve its purpose. Price discrimination, where its effect is substantially to lessen competition, is prohibited by section 49 of the Trade Practices Act. But a small business may be forced out of business by price discrimination without any damage to competition within the market and, therefore, will not invoke the section. In any event, as is pointed out by COSBOA, small business does not have the facilities, the time or the resources to rally against big business in an effort to prove discrimination.

Solutions have been suggested by the Trade Practices Consultative Committee which has offered potential solutions which would have been a worthwhile challenge for the Summit. In the same way clearly restrictive practices in the labour market, for example, in relation to penalty rates, inhibit the growth expansion of small business and call for reform. Another cry of small business has been for greater access to finance with fair rates of interest. The Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System agreed that small business did not have equal access to the financial market when compared with large business. It acknowledged:

In particular loans are more expensive and more security is required, equity funds are more difficult and costly to obtain and small business proprietors have less financial expertise in presenting finance applications.

The Library Legislative Research Service identified the type of firm typically unable to meet trading bank guidelines as recently estabished firms, fast growing firms and product innovative firms. They tend to be faced with obtaining finance from other sources at increased cost which may affect the viability of planned projects. They are the firms that particularly need fostering in today's climate.

A report of the Committee of the Small Business Advisory Council entitled ' Finance for Small Business' published in June 1980 recommended the establishment of a new financial institution-the Small Business Finance Corporation-to provide small business with long term debt finance, equity capital and innovation capital to take prototypes into the production and marketing stages. Even Campbell, somewhat in conflict with the basic philosophy of the report, acknowledged that encouragement could be given to the establishment of private small business investment companies whose primary role would be to invest in the equity of small businesses, new ventures and innovations. COSBOA has called for an amendment to the charter of the Commonwealth Development Bank of Australia to allow it to borrow on the open market for on-lending to small business on an equity or debt basis. If the Economic Conference had been fairly represented by small business, with appropriate background papers, it could have given real guidance to government which would have been helpful.

Finally, if the Government is to look, as it should, to small business as part of an answer to Australia's economic crisis, it must note research such as that carried out in the James Cook University of Queensland which concluded:
. . . of the 2,440 small business bankruptcies in 1978-79 a major cause in more than 25 per cent of cases was lack of business ability, training or experience.

The need for more effective, easily accessible management training becomes of critical importance. The Government would be well advised to examine the report entitled 'Small Business Education and Training in Australia', prepared on behalf of the National Training Council and put down in 1980. That report concluded:
Small business education and training needs are not being adequately met by traditional institutions.

There can be no doubt that the various small business bureaus within the States are making a worthwhile contribution and the materials and courses provided by the Department of Industry and Commerce similarly have been worth while. The education and training gap seems to have remained. COSBOA has called for greater utilisation of programs developed and presented by trade and industry associations. To me that seems to be more in accord with the type of need the research has identified.

At the recent election the Government made extensive and specific promises regarding small business. The first indication of the importance of the promises in the Government's program was the National Economic Summit Conference and the second was the Governor-General's Speech. No doubt many in small business who anticipated reiteration of the pre-election promises were stunned with the neglect of the communique and the Governor-General's Speech. They hoped for and deserved better than a vague offer of some tax relief when economic conditions improve.

One can only suspect that small business has been grossly misled. My colleagues and I will, however, continually remind the Government of its commitments. We of course have a philosophical affinity with those in small business who show enterprise, entrepreneurial spirit, independence and determination to improve their lot. Whilst on the one hand we will on behalf of small business demand that the Government keep its promises, we will equally be working under our shadow Minister for small business, Roger Shipton, in the development of new and innovative policies which will assist this vital sector of the Australian community and which we will implement when we are returned to government after the next election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -I take the opportunity afforded by the first reading of Appropriation Bill (No. 5) to reflect on some of the confusion and inaction of the present Government in the fields of foreign affairs and defence and the way they reflect on the security of this country. I would like to deal, first of all, with the field of foreign affairs and, of the many points that have come up, with three which seem quite important to me. One of the moves of the Government I applaud and two of them I deplore. Firstly, to the Government's credit, there seems to be a reversal of the traditional antagonism of Indonesia. It is a refreshing change to see a Labor Government starting to move into the real world and accepting some of the realities of our neighbourhood. There is no future at all in traditional and doctrinaire hatred of Indonesia that the Australian Labor Party has manifested since the mid-1950s. My only request is that the dissenting voices in the Labor Party keep their debate within the privacy of Caucus, if that is possible, and argue the case there and not go out on the platform attacking Indonesia, particularly in relation to the East Timor.

SPEECH.PARA: The second matter to which I refer is the statement by the Minister for Trade, the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen), over the weekend about the deployment of Australian troops in Kampuchea. Could one ever believe, having lived through the agonies of Vietnam, that we would ever hear a Labor Party member, let alone a Minister of a Labor government suggesting that a peacekeeping force be sent to South East Asia? It is breathtaking, but it is regrettably true.

The insensitivity and the total ignorance of this man moving into a portfolio which is not his responsibility in any way at all trying to commit this country to an alliance with Japan in a peacekeeping force just boggle the imagination. He would not know the reaction of our Association of South East Asian Nations colleagues to the deployment of Japanese troops in this area. He would not understand the reaction of the Philippines and the Philippine Government to a proposition that Japanese troops go back into an area where the memories of the 1940s still live. I suppose he thought it was just a good idea, but it is more than just a slip of the tongue or a minor blunder, because when analysts overseas look at Lionel Bowen, they do not see Lionel Bowen as a person; they see him as a Minister in a government. What is more, they see him as the Deputy Prime Minister, the second most important man in this country, and they see him coming up with an absolutely revolutionary scheme like this. It is no wonder he got an icy response from the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) on this matter. The damage to Australia and the damage to Australia's diplomatic relationships by such an ill-conceived move cannot be expressed in a few simple words.

The third matter that concerns me is the nuclear free zone. Again we come to marked inconsistency on the part of the Labor Party. Mr Hawke, the Prime Minister, was asked by Dr Everingham in the House of Representatives this week for his views on a nuclear free zone. The Prime Minister made a very ambiguous statement. He stated:

. . . Australia, are strongly opposed to the testing and storing of nuclear weapons in the region and to the dumping of nuclear waste in the South Pacific . . . At the same time as we have that view, Australia is concerned that we do not endanger our alliance relationship . . . In particular we do not wish to impede the passage of United States nuclear powered and armed vessels through the Pacific or port calls by United States vessels in the region nor, of course, do we wish to impede the right of United States aircraft in transiting international air space.

Neglecting the nonsense of the last statement of transiting international air space, even with the egomania the Prime Minister has, he has no control over the international air space around Australia or any other part of the world. To oppose nuclear weapons in the region and then to allow transit of ships and aircraft with those armaments through the area is inconsistent and it means that the Prime Minister is flirting with the lunatic Left of his party. He is trying to have his cake and eat it. Again, there are important ramifications for our allies in following such an inconsistent line. Either he believes in a nuclear free zone or he does not. He cannot have a little bit of both.

I will conclude shortly because I would like the Senate to have the benefit of Senator Townley's speech. However, before I sit down I would like to move on to a defence matter. The Governor-General's Speech stated very clearly the importance of defence and foreign affairs to this Labor Government. In that long and platitudinous speech that the Prime Minister wrote for the Governor-General, of 24 topics, can one imagine where defence and foreign affairs appeared? They were covered by the statement:
The defence and security of Australia and the integrity of her territory is the fundamental obligation of the Government of Australia.

Those are fine words. I support them absolutely. But where did that statement appear? Of the 24 articles mentioned in the Governor-General's Speech it was twenty-fourth. I wish to refer to the acute crisis in the Royal Australian Navy at present over the way the Government has bungled the matter of an aircraft carrier and the disbandment of the Fleet Air Arm. My views on the carrier are well known. I led the fight in this Parliament against the proposition to replace Melbourne with a carrier of less capability. I believe in organic air power at sea but it has to be properly provided. The type of carrier proposed for the Navy which does not have an air borne early warning capability or an adequate strike and defence fighter aircraft on it is no good in my judgment. But that is by the way. The point is that there was a way for the Government to act, and that is with sensitivity and tact without totally destroying the morale of the Royal Australian Navy as has happened. There are not only internal problems, but also very serious international problems because the navy of our strongest ally, the United States of America, is very concerned about the collapse of morale in the Navy in this region.

We have a responsibility in the Indian Ocean and the Pacific Ocean to help our allies in the face of the biggest Soviet fleet deployed in any ocean of the world. The Soviet Pacific fleet is their biggest commitment. We have a real responsibility which we have to measure up to as a nation with respect to both the Indian Ocean and the Pacific Ocean. One of the prime responsibilities falls on the Royal Australian Navy. It cannot be dealt with by a Navy that has had its morale shattered or a Navy that has had its capability destroyed because no planning has been done as to how air capability at sea will be provided. We must have that capability, presumably in a rotary wing form both for over the horizon targeting and for anti-submarine work. The action of this Government in crudely and cruelly destroying an asset without any thought as to how it will be replaced-and there is no sign of the Government being prepared to think about how it will be replaced-has profound ramifications for us. I hope that with the passage of time we will see some responsibility from this Government in the fields of foreign affairs and defence, but at the moment we look in vain.

DEBATE.TITLE: GUIDELINES FOR THE FORM AND STANDARD OF FINANCIAL STATEMENTS OF COMMONWEALTH UNDERTAKINGS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report
Debate resumed from 18 May, on motion by Senator Coates:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations and now its Chairman, I think it appropriate that I comment briefly on the paper, 'Guidelines for the Form and Standard of Financial Statements of Commonwealth Undertakings' from the Department of Finance which was tabled yesterday. I want to indicate that I personally and certainly the Committee as a whole welcome this tabling and the content of the document. When the Finance and Government Operations Committee was re- established in 1977 its major and continuing reference was the scrutiny of statutory authorities.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the first problems the Committee encountered in examining authority financial dealings was the lack of a uniform accounting standard that could be applied to authorities. The Committee, through its case study approach, identified many problem areas and held discussions regarding these accounting problems with the Department of Finance, the Auditor-General's Office and particular authorities. The lack of guidelines in the past resulted in differences of approach to the most basic accounting principles between particular authorities. Some authorities used traditional government cash accounting procedures whilst others employed commercial or accrual accounting techniques.

In the Committee's third report on 'Statutory Authorities of the Commonwealth' it recommended that a single accounting standard apply and that that standard be full accrual accounting. This recommendation became one of the central parts of the Committee's proposal for an annual reports Act which was set out in the Committee's fifth report. The fifth report of the Committee commented in detail on the then draft guidelines and wholeheartedly recommended their adoption. The Committee's goal in recommending an annual reports Act, in particular, the guidelines which have now been adopted by the Government, was to improve accountability of authorities to the Parliament and to the public. The adoption of the guidelines will help achieve that aim. Once again, I congratulate the Government on tabling this report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too wish to commend the Government on its prompt and positive response to a number of initiatives in this area, one of which was the setting up of a joint committee comprising people drawn from the Auditor-General's Office, the Department of Finance and the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. I refer also to last year's Joint Committee of Public Accounts discussion paper entitled 'Guidelines for the Form and Standard of Financial Statements of Commonwealth Undertakings'. The new Department of Finance guidelines contain significant reforms and I believe they will help to standardise public sector accounting to a significant degree.

SPEECH.PARA: As chairman of the Committee whose members drew up the sectional report I am pleased to say that many of the Committee's recommendations have been adopted. Our investigations demonstrated the inadequacy and irrelevance of many annual reports and financial statements from government authorities. We pointed out the distinctive nature of public sector accounting and the need to establish distinctive guidelines. People in public life frequently lose sight of the basic objective of accounting and financial reporting in the federal system. This is to provide useful information for assessing management's performance and stewardship. Assessing this basically involves determining what an entity has achieved and what it can achieve in the future. This second aspect, regrettably, is still ignored.

In assessing performance, information must provide indicators on three things: Firstly, financial viability; secondly, program activity; and, thirdly, fiscal compliance. The information, which indicates how efficient and effective management operates, helps users to assess stewardship and performance. Another difficulty is that if disclosed accounting profit or surplus is a major determinant of pricing policies, under a user pays concept of public sector service, determination of such profit or surplus must be fair. This applies particularly in monopoly-type situations. To our Public Accounts Committee this meant that accounting must be factual in current economic terms rather than hypothetical or the product of traditional and sometimes irrelevant accounting techniques.

I believe that we probably need to go further than do these new guidelines issued by the Department of Finance. I still believe there are deficiencies in these guidelines. I believe that in some cases there can still be a failure to determine full cost by ignoring, for example, the existence of inflation. There could be a failure still to provide a framework for communicating management's expectations and estimates. I think this is fairly significant. There can still be failures to specify the nature and effect of large scale contracts and commitments on the future operations. Our Public Accounts Committee believed that a genuine research effort still must be mounted, employing the resources from both within the accounting profession and outside it. I must say that initiatives in both these directions have commenced.

In other words, we must systematically construct a relevant theoretical framework for financial reporting by public sector authorities. There are significant differences in objectives and outlook between private sector and public sector accounting. I believe such an approach must again embrace at least three factors: Firstly, a determination of user needs; secondly, an examination of the concept of certainty in relation to the needs for budgetary disclosure and commitment accounting in the public sector; and, thirdly, discussion between private and public sector accountants on the strengths and weaknesses of conventional financial reporting to identify the likely economic consequences and effects on consumers of the adoption of various financial accountability measurement systems. However, I believe that these current guidelines represent progress in a chain in which we have still a lot further to go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to indicate that I too welcome the introduction of the 'Guidelines for the Form and Standard of Financial Statements of Commonwealth Undertakings'. I think it is another step forward- although not by any means a final step-in the development of a system which will ensure that we have an adequate, up to date and appropriate system operating in relation to statutory authorities. One aspect about which I did not hear Senator Coates, as the new Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, comment-perhaps he would like to by way of interjection- is whether the Finance and Government Operations Committee has considered the attachments which set out the list of authorities or, as they are called, undertakings required to keep accounts in accordance with the commercial practice and whether that list meets with the approval of the Finance and Government Operations Committee.
—The Committee has not met since the report was tabled. I am sure we will look at it.

—I thank the honourable senator very much. I am happy with both aspects of the interjection which answers one of the questions I wanted to raise. I believe that Australia is still in advance of most other comparable countries in endeavouring to overcome some of the shortcomings that were so graphically portrayed to the world when the city of New York went bankrupt. I think there is an awful lot to be done in public accounting and in ensuring that proper accounts which fully disclose the state of affairs in, particularly, the statutory authorities and government generally, are identified. I welcome the contribution of Senator Watson as a member of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. I trust that there was an occasion when both the Public Accounts Committee and the Finance and Government Operations Committee worked together in endeavouring each to look at their particular areas of interest to develop recommendations for advances in the Australian practice. I hope that the PAC will look at what might be called the more accounting aspects whilst the Finance and Government Operations Committee will look at the other aspects in which it has taken a primary interest.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw attention to one problem, and that is the definition of accruing liabilities. Probably the problem is best demonstrated if I refer to-but not with any suggestion that it is an exclusive case-the very well known situation of Trans Australia Airlines and the $236m in respect of employers' superannuation contributions which it was obliged to make to the Commonwealth. The Finance and Government Operations Committee received evidence from a significant number of statutory authorities that there were problems in relation to how one accounts and makes adequate provision for that accruing liability. I think it is something to which further attention needs to be paid.

Finally, because there is only a very short time for me to refer to these matters, I ask also that some attention be paid to the question of insurance. Many statutory authorities are in a dilemma in relation to insurance. They are told that the Government practice of carrying their own insurance ought to apply but the Government will give no guarantee, as I understand it, to any statutory authority that in the event of a loss being suffered the Government will provide that statutory authority with sufficient funds to cover that loss. I do not think that one can reasonably expect statutory authorities to self-insure. One can reasonably expect the Government to self-insure but if it requires its authorities to self-insure it must provide some understood method of compensating those authorities in the event of a disaster, otherwise the proper practice will be that authorities insure in the normal way. I take as an example the Australian Maritime College which has two ships worth some millions of dollars, each of which could readily be subject to some major disaster. This is not likely because I am quite sure that the Maritime College will ensure that that does not happen. However, it could. Does the Maritime College have to carry the insurance itself? I ask that that matter be taken into account as one of the further aspects that needs dealing with.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH SCIENTIFIC AND INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH ORGANISATION LABORATORIES-SAFETY STANDARDS AND DEATH OF DR R. BERGAMASCO

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report and Ministerial Statement
Debate resumed from 18 May, on motion by Senator Crowley:
That the Senate take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take this opportunity to make a brief comment in relation to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation Laboratories report, not so much in terms of the reference requiring the committee of inquiry to look into any possible connection or cause of the death of Dr Bergamasco from his work site but rather to address the Senate's attention to the occupational health and safety aspects of this report. I think they highlight some very important features, and lack of proper arrangements, about occupational health and safety, a point that I referred to in my maiden speech. I take the opportunity of debating this very comprehensive report to talk again on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Matters are raised in this report that are quite frightening, I think, in terms of the description of the lack of safety facilities at this work site. The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation is hardly a place that is unaware of health hazards and safety hazards, seeing that the very business of much of its work, particularly in this laboratory, deals with toxic chemicals, the testing of various chemicals of a highly dangerous sort and various chemical operations. It is a place which one would have thought would attend to safety at all times. The report seems to suggest that the CSIRO has been remiss in doing so.

The first problem at the Fishermens Bend laboratory is the design of the building. It is an older building and over a number of years there has been $1m spent on upgrading the facilities. But this has not adequately coped with the lack of facilities. I do not wish to list all of them. People can look at the report for the detailed description of them. I note that the Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Barry Jones, in referring to this paper in the House recently, listed, amongst other things, that the laboratories are severely crowded; the exhaust from the house vacuum system is directly under and close to the air intake of the ventilation system; the ventilation of the organic chemical store is inadequate-which is a very kind way of saying it, as according to the report it is grossly inadequate!-the increase in number and efficiency of fume cupboards has led to a potential deficiency in the make-up air capacity in the building; the fume cupboards do not achieve adequate air flow velocity unless cupboard doors are opened only a minimal amount; and the exhaust from the fume extractors has not been raised above roof level, so the fumes are and can be happily recycled through the building. Asbestos is still used as bench sheets and in oven packing in the building. I have just listed some of the problems of the design of the building. I can understand that with an old building it is difficult to arrange safer designs without considerable expense. This laboratory is being moved very soon to Clayton and presumably all these points will be taken note of in the design of the new building.

However, the points that matter more are the occupational, health and safety provisions which accompany these inadequately designed buildings. The staff has available to it something that is said in this report to be unique, and that is a full time nursing sister and a visiting Commonwealth medical officer, provisions that are not available to most other CSIRO staff. However, the Committee believes that the doctors concerned do not have any specific training in occupational health. While a considerable provision seems to be there it is not, in fact, the case.

I notice that my time is drawing to an end so I will move on to make the most important point of this paper, and that is the separation between occupational health facilities and occupational safety considerations. While these two matters remain separate and attended to by different personnel and different staff, with inadequate training, inadequate data collection and inadequate record keeping the problems are likely to continue. The Australian Labor Party, in its policy, has addressed itself specifically to the establishment of an occupational health and safety commission to address itself to just these points .

One of the most important points that is clearly missing from this report is any notion of prevention. That has to be seen as an integral part of occupational health and safety provisions. It is also part of the Labor policy. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF IMMIGRATION AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Review of Activities to 30 June 1982

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Statement by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This statement was made by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) to the House of Representatives yesterday. It outlines what the Minister calls the Government's decision concerning Australia's immigration policy and the size and composition of the 1983-84 immigration program. Whilst there is much detail in the statement that the Opposition would not take issue with, on the whole the presentation of the statement is a gesture, some of which will be at the expense of Australia. The statement by the Minister, particularly in relation to retraining Australians, is largely window dressing. Family reunion migrants will remain the significant group in Australia's immigration in 1983-84 , as it has for some time.

I draw the Senate's attention to the statements by the Minister on the subject of migrants in the category of 'labour shortage and business migration'. The fact is that the immigration of skilled workers has been at a maximum level of no more than 12,000 per year in any average year. There is a furphy abroad in the community-it is a convenient one to run when there are debates on other issues such as unemployment-that we would have fewer problems in this country if there were fewer migrants. In recent years our migrant intake has been very limited indeed in comparison to the intakes of previous years, and the skilled workers who have come to Australia have not taken the jobs of Australians. As I said, they have formed a relatively small group in the total number who have come to Australia, and this group is certainly much smaller than the family reunion group. We can expect in a time of economic recession that demand for people skilled in certain occupations is likely to drop. With our present economic conditions we could have expected that there would be far fewer migrants in that category anyway. If the Government claims in due course that it has significantly reduced unemployment amongst Australians because fewer migrants in this category have come in, it is likely not to be an accurate claim .

The Minister lays emphasis on the subject of retraining Australians. Of course, it is desirable to retrain Australians, particularly those who are unemployed. That was our Government's policy. It is much cheaper and much more desirable. There were a lot of incentives for the previous Government to follow this policy , and it did. In fact too few people were available or willing to undertake the sort of training available to fill the categories of employment that have been filled in previous years under the skilled labour intake. If we could have retrained more of our own citizens in skills in demand we would have done so. Suitable people simply were not available in the sorts of numbers in which they were needed. As I said, in a time of economic recession demand will drop anyway. But even in a time of growth retraining has not been able to provide enough workers with the skills which are in demand. If the Minister really wants to bring his portfolio into active participation in this area he will have to urge his Government to bite the bullet on the subject of the trade unions' traditional attitudes and the difficulties that they have put in the way of adult apprenticeships. That has been a major obstacle in the retraining of Australians.

I wish to say a few words on the subject of temporary visas for workers. The Minister has taken away, has had taken away, or has agreed to have taken away, all ministerial discretion in relation to special cases. Some emphasis was given to the fact that people who come here on a temporary visa, under which they can undertake work, will have to go home. This can only be harmful to Australia. A number of creative and talented people, particularly in the arts and sporting areas, have been allowed to stay in Australia under this provision. But in any event the number of people approved in any year has been small indeed. The so- called loophole of ministerial discretion has been very valuable in enabling us to keep these people here. That sort of person to whom I have referred would be unlikely to meet immigration criteria if he or she went home. In any event, there are others who would have been approved if they had applied from overseas and who would have been permitted to stay. What would be the point of sending them home and making them apply to come back when it is known that they will be accepted as migrants? Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-My comments on this matter will be brief. Let me congratulate the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs ( Mr West) on his first major statement in this area, which is most important to the whole of Australia but of particular interest to me and the Northern Territory. It seems to me that the Minister has adopted a very humanitarian and sound approach in a very difficult economic situation. I do not have to elaborate on that matter; it is covered clearly in the Minister's statement. I should like to commend particularly the emphasis on family reunion. This issue has been mentioned in the previous Government's statements, and the previous Government looked towards reuniting families. It is good to see that the present Minister has continued that policy and has asked that it be extended in a certain way.

SPEECH.PARA: There still remains the problem that has been with us all the time; that is, the extended family. Certainly, it is nothing new to any honourable senators present in the chamber at this moment; I have raised it before. We know that a number of Asian families see the extension beyond what we call the nuclear family into other elements of the family group. This is expressed not only in their concern for them but also in the fact that they continue to send money to their home countries for grandmother, brother or sister or any member of the family needing assistance. I have made the point many times in this place and to the Minister that it seems poor economic practice to send out of Australia, money which could be spent in Australia. If money is being sent to Malaysia, why do we not allow the recipient of that money to come to Australia and spend the money in Australia? Quite clearly, as far as we are concerned, the money would do more good here than it would overseas. I commend to the Minister the proposition that we do look at this extended family and not limit ourselves to the nuclear family. Perhaps we could use as some sort of criterion the point that the family member here is sending quite a deal of money out of the country to a person he is supporting elsewhere. The preamble to the statement, in part, reads:
1. The Australian Government alone decides who can enter Australia.

This is a commendable proposition, but it does not work quite like that. Unfortunately we have the situation where other countries decide who will come to Australia. I am thinking particularly of Indonesia, which has prevented people from East Timor coming to Australia. We do know that there were 2,500 people in the original list. That was cut back to 660 people and then that was cut back further. The proposition I put to the Minister is that if we are to decide who is to come to Australia then we must flex our muscles in another area and perhaps encourage the Indonesians to allow people from East Timor to come. Surely the amount of assistance which we give to Indonesia by aid in various ways would allow us to put a reasonable proposition to the Indonesians. I suggest that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs have discussions with his colleague the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) who has had recent contact with Indonesia. One hopes that the Indonesians could be encouraged to allow a few more people to come.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you say the same about the Soviet Union, that we should ask the Soviet Union to let some of its people in?

—If there is a family reunion problem then, by all means; I would not discriminate at all. We should use whatever good offices we have to help anyone here who has a family outside. I merely mention Indonesia because of the assistance we give it. I do not think we give the same assistance to the Soviet Union, but that would not stop us requesting that this be done in the same way. I accept the proposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me move on quickly to refugees. It is encouraging to see the change in approach, particularly as it relates to Central and South America. The flexible approach which the Minister has indicated in his statement is a good one. Page 4 of the statement reads:
The Government made an election commitment to place greater emphasis on seeking political solutions to refugee situations. This aim will be vigorously pursued.

So I commend both aspects, the integrated policy as indicated in the statement and the flexible approach. Unfortunately, again there is no mention of automatic entry to Australia of the spouses of Australian nationals. I have raised this matter before and I make no apologies for raising it again. It seems to me intolerable that an Australian national marrying overseas is not permitted to bring his or her spouse back to Australia automatically but has to go through some procedure whereby someone decides whether he or she ought to have married that person. We do know that the success rate of marriages contracted in the Philippines, Malaysia and other places is high, but we cannot use that sort of argument to say that these people should not be allowed in. I know the policy causes many heartaches to people in Australia, particularly people in the north of our country who go to the Philippines and other places and marry but are not permitted to bring their wives to Australia. I speak particularly of the male situation in this instance. I will continue to press this matter and when it is raised again I will mention some further issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I seek your guidance. When I moved that the Senate take note of the statement I was given five minutes in which to speak. I sought leave to continue my remarks when my time ended. Senator Robertson then sought leave to speak and no time limit was put on him. He did speak in excess of five minutes.
—He could have gone on forever.
—That is right, he could have gone on for as long as he liked.
—There is a procedural motion that could have stopped him, Senator Martin.

—I did not want to stop Senator Robertson, for reasons that will shortly become obvious.
