I represent in this place the Opposition's shadow Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and I was making a statement on behalf of the Opposition. I was stopped a couple of minutes before I had completed my remarks. I would like to finish what I had to say. So I seek leave of the Senate so to do.
—Under sessional order, Senator Martin, your right to speak again is preserved. You will have the right to speak again on this statement when debate on it comes on again.
—Can I ask when that will be? I want to finish my speech now, Mr Deputy President, and I seek leave to do that.

—I am reluctant to have a series of matters discussed by leave because although the Senate is perfectly entitled to grant leave, procedural problems are created if people speaking by leave speak for as long as they wish. The whole purpose of this organisation is that people speak for five minutes. You have asked for leave, Senator Martin, and it has been granted.
—If Senator Martin had not sought leave to continue we would all have been able to speak for only five minutes and the last person would have closed the debate.

—What I will do in future if someone seeks leave is to draw the matter to the attention of the Senate and ask whether there are any further speakers. I will ask those who seek leave not to seek leave but to have the debate adjourned, if they wish, when everyone has spoken. In the present circumstances, Senator Martin has sought leave and that has been granted. Senator Martin has the call.

—The new procedures are all very confusing. I think I am even more confused than I was before. Had I known, I would have sought leave to speak for a few more minutes. I thought this matter was going straight off the Notice Paper at that point.
—Leave has been granted. You may proceed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave- People who are in Australia on temporary visas and who were allowed to stay under ministerial discretion were allowed to remain only in very special circumstances. I said previously that this involved a small number of people. Most of them would have satisfied our immigration procedures had they gone back to their country of origin and applied to immigrate. Because there is no longer ministerial discretion to vary this situation, we shall pointlessly now require people to travel back to wherever they come from, regardless that they fully satisfy our immigration criteria and will be approved to migrate to Australia after being sent home. The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs is in an inflexible situation where that hardship is imposed.

SPEECH.PARA: The final point I want to make relates to the subject of refugees. The Minister laid some stress on the fact that there will be some shift of emphasis from Indo -Chinese refugees, most of our refugee intake, to South and Central American refugees. I have nothing against our extending our policy in that area. I just want to sound a note of caution. We must be careful that we do not fall into the pitfalls that the United States of America did in regard to Cuban refugees. Cubans became refugees because they were literally pushed out of their country by the Cuban Government. In the process not only did the Cuban Government eject people whose political beliefs were not compatiable with that of the ruling regime but also it ejected all the other people who were otherwise socially undesirable. It virtually emptied its prisions and filled the United States prisons in several States. Whilst there is debate between regimes of differing views about what constitutes a social undesirable-some regimes might think it is because a person has right wing or left wing political views-I think we have a common view on the subject of common criminals. I hope that all care is taken to make sure that in expanding the number of refugees from South and Central America this does not happen to us.

The previous Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs sent the Deputy Secretary of his Department to Southern and Central America. The Government also made offers to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees for Australia to take more Southern American refugees. I do not want anyone to suggest that the previous Government was not attuned to the desperate plight of refugees in those areas. The simple fact was that there was very little response to either the direct visits of a senior official of the Department or the offers made to the UNHCR.

TALK.START.PARA: —The previous Government was more than generous in regard to refugees.

—Thank you, Senator Chipp. As Senator Chipp points out, the previous Government was very generous to refugees. Australian governments have a very good record on the humanitarian matter of taking in refugees. When attemps were made to increase the number of South American refugees coming to Australia, very few of them wanted to come to Australia; they wanted to go either to North America or to Europe. So expansive as the Government is in its views, it may well find that not so many refugees want to come here from South America. But that is no reason for not trying. My point was made simply to emphasise that the present situation has not been caused by the previous Government not being attuned to the needs of South American refugees. We hope that our policies in relation to refugees from our region and particularly from Indo-China are not artificially scaled down. The Minister mentioned the fact that there are fewer boat people, but there is a continuing major problem of Indo-Chinese refugees, particularly those from Kampuchea moving into Thailand. It may well be that the Government will have to be flexible enough in the near future to shift its policy again to attend to the growing pressures on a friendly country of our own region.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Senate is commenting very briefly on the overview by the present Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West ) of a suitable migration program for Australia in 1983-84. In historical terms, for Australia at least, with an envisaged intake of some 80,000 to 90,000 persons, we have in view a quite modest program, some features of which have nevertheless attracted adverse comment by the shadow Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Michael Hodgman, which I must admit has not been brought into this chamber by Senator Kathy Martin. Nevertheless I believe that the shadow Minister has, by his statements, put into some jeopardy the usual bipartisan approach of Australian political parties to our migration policy. I think it is important that some of the remarks he made be queried.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the very matter to which Senator Martin just adverted, namely, our recognition of the fact that countries, regimes or governments which make refugees of their people can exist in any geographic part of the world. It is our policy to recognise the fact that in Central and South America there are people who wish to flee from persecution for their political beliefs. We say that the response of the previous Government to this situation was totally inadequate. Of some 17,000 refugees who entered Australia last year only 100 came from Central and South America. I am sure that if former Senator Mulvihill were in this chamber he would be saying that that was a totally inadequate response to the plight of those refugees.

Mr Hodgman, speaking of the Government's decision in relation to Central and South America, said that we ought to have an intake of some 2,500 people from that area. He said that there was cause for serious concern in the Government's plan to shift the focus on refugee migration from South East Asia to Central and South America. He went on to say that the Opposition was extremely concerned that there are some 300,000 refugees in that region. In other words, the shadow Minister tried to convey a picture of the Australian Government seeking to bring to Australia a large proportion of those 300,000-by his admission-unfortunate refugees in Central and South America who are persecuted by their regimes and in fear of their lives and certainly of their liberty. I believe that all we are proposing, in an intake of some 2,000 refugees, is a very modest recognition of the plight of those people. Senator Lajovic expressed concern that people from Eastern Europe ought to be recognised in our migration programs. The Government also says in its statement that we will still maintain an intake of some 10,000 refugees from Indo-China. Our program is recognised around the world as being very fair, just, compassionate and generous; certainly per capita Australia is doing more than any other country to relieve the distress of refugees from South East Asia.

TALK.START.PARA: —That has been bipartisan.

—That has been bipartisan. We intend to continue that program in relation to the Indo-Chinese but we say that about 2,500 refugees from eastern Europe should be admitted to Australia and that particular emphasis should be placed on reducing the number of Polish refugees who are presently seeking resettlement outside Europe. I think Senator Lajovic, by nodding his head, acknowledges the compassion and justice behind the spread of countries and regions from which Australia will continue to receive refugees as one of the great humanitarian aspects of our migration program.

SPEECH.PARA: The other thing which I found disturbing in the shadow Minister's response was his statement that the Opposition supported the introduction of a special category covering people facing human rights difficulties but strongly opposed the proposed 70 per cent cutback in the 'occupations in demand' category. The fact is that we are facing extremely high unemployment in Australia. It seems to me incredible that the shadow Minister should not be sufficiently aware of the Australian situation to realise that it is essential that we cut back the number of those coming into Australia and competing for jobs with our own people, particularly young people.

The Government has said, and said very firmly, that our emphasis will be on family reunions and refugees and that we will not use the immigration program to create competition for jobs with those already in Australia. In particular we are concerned that the immigration program ought not to be used as a means of bringing trained and skilled people into Australia. We believe that the Government ought to have programs of education in order to fill those labour shortage gaps that might occur and that less reliance should be placed on the immigration program as a source of skilled workers. It seems to me incredible that the shadow Minister did not recognise that simple fact.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Like Senator Tate, I too welcome the changes announced by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) in his first statement to the Parliament in respect of migration policy. The changes have been developed within the Australian Labor Party on all levels and the decision-making process has involved people both within the bureaucracy in Canberra and within migrant and ethnic communities. I think the fact that participation in the decision-making process has extended that far is extremely welcome.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to comment very briefly on a number of features of the statement. The first, which has already been touched upon, relates to the labour market. The statement, in foreshadowing a balance in the competing interests in this area, has announced a reduction of migration to approximately 80,000 to 90,000 people with the major cutback occurring in this area of skilled workers. It is interesting to note that when Labor took government, despite the skyrocketting unemployment, 75 acceptable occupation criteria were available upon which people could apply for migration to Australia. That number has been drastically reduced . To the extent that this reduction leaves the way open for a commensurate increase in the number of training and retraining programs it is desirable. It is scandalous that towards the end of last year a secretary-typist in London could apply to come to Australia on the basis of labour market needs when so many young Australians were looking for employment in that very area. To the extent that the problems in this area are addressed also I submit that the changes are extremely welcome.

One area that has been touched on to a great extent is that of refugee policy. It has already been noted that there has been a drift, as outlined in the statement, towards a greater acceptance of refugees from Central and South America. I note that in the last year of operation of our refugee policy 300,000 refugees could have been eligible to come to Australia, but only 100 out of 17, 000 applicants were approved. This statement extends the scope for persons in Central and South America to apply for refugee status and to enter Australia on that basis. However, one aspect of the implementation of policy which has concerned me-not only this policy but also the previous policy-is that it has been brought to my attention that in the last couple of years the Department of Foreign Affairs has taken a role in the implementation of the refugee policy in that region of the world. It would seem from the evidence available to me that that Department has gone to the extent of physically preventing or delaying the delivery of cables to posts in that region. The direct consequence of this action, of course, as Senator Martin has mentioned, is a lack of people applying to come to Australia as refugees from Central and Southern America. Of course, if the policy is not being implemented as it should be, if there is bureaucratic sabotage in respect of this area of policy-as there would appear to be-it is no wonder that the number of people--

TALK.START.PARA: —That was not what was said.
—I am sorry. Senator Martin was discussing something with Senator Chipp while I was speaking.
—I am, when you are mentioning my name.

—I had mentioned the honourable senator's name earlier. But the point I was making was that during the last couple of years cables of directions to implement policy have not gone to posts in central and southern America. They had been physically prevented from going there by the Department of Foreign Affairs. In some instances follow up cables have been sent to posts in that region indicating that no action was to be taken consequent upon the previous cable that was sent. I raise this matter at this stage because it is vitally important in terms of the operation of the bureaucracy and also in terms of some of the comments that have been made about the lack of interest in that region from people who wish to come to Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The last point I wish to mention in respect of refugees is the aspect that has been mentioned by Senator Robertson relating to East Timor refugees. I also urge a definite and substantive response from the Indonesian Government in this area. We have had since 1978 the saga of the agreed list of migrants. At that stage 600 people were listed as being eligible to come to Australia as agreed refugees . Since then, even though approximately 350 people have arrived, for the last three years we have had a list of approximately 120 people who have not been allowed to come to Australia. Also, during the course of this period we have had repeated promises from the Indonesian Government that those people would be allowed to come to Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I believe there may be a misunderstanding, unless I misheard the previous speaker, Senator Bolkus. As I understand it, he said that in 1982-83 only 100 out of 17,000 applicants from Central and South America were granted refugee status for permanent entry into Australia. There is a slight misunderstanding, because the statement by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West)-perhaps it may be possible to clarify this point- reads:

SPEECH.PARA: It is unacceptable for instance that only 100 out of 17,000 in 1982-83 should be from Central and South America . . .

The figure referred to was the total intake of 17,000 refugees. Senator Martin said that whilst the previous Government had a good many faults, about which I have spoken frequently, it had a policy on refugees which, whilst not as extensive as I would like to see, and obviously as others would like to see, nevertheless placed a great deal of emphasis on implementation. I suppose that the same remarks apply to other areas as apply to Central and South America. The difficulty with regard to Central and South America was adequately expressed by Senator Martin. I express one note of concern about this statement. Whilst the Government perceives a need to emphasise the intake from Central and South America, I believe it should not do so at the expense of the intake from Indo- China, which we have an obligation to maintain. But it appears from the statement that the intake from Indo-China will be reduced from 12,500 to 10,000. This will occur at a time when the situation in Indo-China is far from stable. Indeed, the situation may require an additional statement from the Minister.

I would like to know also from the Minister whether the family reunion category will be the category under which Indo-Chinese refugees who are currently in Australia will be able to get their spouses from Indo-China, particularly from Vietnam. I am not sure whether that is the case. But I am sure that most members of the Federal Parliament know of desperately compassionate cases which involve refugees women with small children whose husbands are still in Vietnam. I have a particular case in mind in which it is not only appropriate from the human rights point of view for the husband to be with his wife and family in Australia , but also it would be the obvious thing to do from an econoic point of view for Vietnam and Australia. I raise the issue about whether that sort of case will fall within the family reunion category or within the more limited refugee category from Indo-China. If it is the latter, I express very real concern about the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lajovic Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-If I recall correctly, one of the announcements made by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) breaks another promise given prior to the election by the Prime Mininster (Mr Hawke) when he was Leader of the Opposition, and his then shadow Mininister for Immigration. I recall-I stand to be corrected on this point-that they both assured the migrant communities that there would be no reduction in the migrant intake by the incoming Labor Government. I have yet to see the reaction of the migrant Press to the cut of 15,000 migrants a year. I know that the migrant leaders and the migrant Press urged the previous Government to increase the migrant intake, which at that time was 120,000 a year. This Government has again broken a promise. I would like to continue my remarks with regard to this point after I see the reation from the migrant Press which, I am sure, will not be complimentary to the present Government which is breaking its promise and its assurance that it would not reduce the intake of migrants.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate (on motion by Senator Peter Baume for Senator Martin) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION ON SECURITY AND INTELLIGENCE AGENCIES

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement
Debate resumed from 17 May, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Senate take note of the statement.
Upon which Senator Chaney had moved by way of amendment:
Leave out all words after 'That', insert:
''the Senate is of the opinion that the terms of reference should be amended by omitting paragraph (c) and substituting the following paragraph:
'(c) further to the inquiry in relation to paragraphs (a) and (b) above:

(i) all the circumstances, including the actions of the Government, surrounding the expulsion from Australia of Mr Valeriy Nikolayevich Ivanov, First Secretary, Embassy of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, and the involvement of Mr Harvey David Mathew Combe in those circumstances; and

(ii) whether or not the Prime Minister, the Special Minister of State or any other Minister or any senior Government adviser disclosed confidential information in any way relating to the decision to expel from Australia Mr Valeriy Nikolayevich Ivanov; and' ''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a ministerial statement on and the terms of reference of the proposed Royal Commission on Security and Intelligence Agencies. That Royal Commission contains two aspects in its terms of reference. The first aspect is to undertake a comprehensive review of the structure and functions of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. That has had the advocacy of the previous Government, the present Opposition. The second aspect relates to an investigation of what is now known as the Ivanov-Combe affair and concerns the expulsion of a Russian KGB agent and the alleged involvement of an Australian citizen, a Canberra lobbyist, David Combe. That is the subject matter to which I wish to address my remarks. The Opposition has sought to add an additional paragraph to the terms of reference of the inquiry. The paragraph inquires:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . whether or not the Prime Minister, the Special Minister of State or any other Minister or any senior Government advisor disclosed confidential information in any way relating to the decision to expel from Australia Mr Valeriy Nikolayevich Ivanov.

I support that. I say at the outset that this is a very grave matter indeed. The issue involved is not the fact of some new Minister making some casual accident because he lacked knowledge and was ignorant in regard to his department or of the facts. This is not just another of the bumble-footed fumblings of a government new to office. It is not just another Royal Australian Air Force flight to Tasmania debacle. It is not another debacle of a quarrel between a Minister and the Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Commission or some very ill chosen remarks about the habits-quite wrongly quoted-of koalas. Indeed, it is not even Mr Lionel Bowen and his wonderful theories of how to get a peace force in Kampuchea. It has nothing to do with a new government being in office, to a lack of facts or an ignorance of material. It concerns the qualities of the people concerned, the moral and ethical judgments of the leaders of the Government. It gives us an insight into the state of mind of the people concerned. Strangely, the people concerned are the very people who were involved in these other debacles.

It is interesting that we have on this Cabinet sub-committee on national and international security Mr Young, who, on his own confession broke security, one of the most grave things that any Minister can do, and released information to somebody outside before it was publicly released. Senator Gareth Evans and his colleague, Mr Scholes, who were involved in the Tasmanian aircraft debacle, are also members as is, of course, Mr Hayden with his theories on Kampuchea and East Timor. Mr Bowen is also a member. What an interesting group indeed. This matter concerns, as I say, the gravest questions of national security and human liberty . It is interesting to ask what were the moral and ethical judgments of those concerned. What did they do? How did they look to preserve security and civil liberties?

As this story unfolds, we see that it focuses on the utter disregard of those people for civil liberties, their incapacity to preserve national security secrets, their willingness to sacrifice a former colleague for their own self interest and to dump him without giving him access to any kind of civil liberties at all. We see their unwillingness to give him a fair go and a fair trial and the selectivity of the information they gave him when they had a discussion with him. We see their attempt to make a private deal behind the scenes under duress with their former colleague and the phony excuse they attempted to put up which they asked the public to believe, which was that what they were really doing to Mr Combe was to distance him because he was a lobbyist and a previous friend of the Government and people might think it was naughty if he came close to them. There is a phoniness about that in that they did this in the knowledge that he had in fact been subject to a security risk. The only thing they did was to distance Mr Combe from the Ministers. The rest of the world was to be in abysmal ignorance of the facts and Mr Combe was to be free to make whatever links he wanted with departments, commerce and industry and with the public. Why? Because, as it will emerge from the story, it was a political decision. It was a skin saving decision of the Government and, of course, it was a gross deception. The deception was that the Government would pretend that it would distance itself from a lobbyist, whereas the facts were otherwise.

The judgment was that when it could do nothing else the Government would publicly try him and hang him without any fair go for him at all. Then there was the aggravation after a judicial inquiry had been announced by the senior law officer of this country, the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans), who deliberately and gratuituously set out last Sunday to condemn Mr Combe more and more and to offer more evidence. This is the man who says that one must not mention matters which are sub judice. Yet last Sunday he gratuitously said:
You know the words, 'or appeared to be compromised', they weren't put in by me, Gareth Evans, they were put in at the request of Mr Combe.

What a damning thing it is for somebody in the teeth of a judicial inquiry and after the Government had made the notorious mistake of condemning its mate without trial to say gratuitously: 'You should really read this as the Government believes that you have compromised yourself'. The only words added were his own gratuitous comment. The Chief Law Officer of this country was not asked what Mr Combe said. Senator Evans said that the language, 'appeared to be compromised' was actually David's own. He said:
Really I ought to be entitled to have the benefit of any possible doubt there is about that.

In other words, the Attorney-General says quite clearly that the original statement said that the Government said Mr Combe had been compromised. How much further can one go to knock a man when he is down? How much more un-Australian can one be than to do that, in the teeth of the fact that a judicial inquiry had been announced?

The facts are that there is a Cabinet sub-committee on national and international security, and that sub-committee comprises six persons; the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) who must take absolute responsibility for this and for the grave defects shown in moral and ethical judgment, the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Lionel Bowen, Mr Young, Senator Gareth Evans, Mr Scholes and Mr Hayden. What happened on their say so is this. They received a report from ASIO concerning a KGB agent and his relationship with a Mr David Combe. According to Senator Gareth Evans, the Government satisfied itself that ASIO's information was correct. It is no good for Australian Labor Party people to say: 'It is wicked ASIO that planted this information'. The important thing to remember is that, on the Sunday program, Senator Evans said: 'We satisfied ourselves that ASIO is correct on this'. So the Government accepted that. Having done that, it then had to decide what to do. One wonders what the Government would have done had the person concerned not been a prominent Labor man. One wonders whether the Government would have had a public inquiry straightaway. But no, what the Government decided on was one of the most serious things that have happened in this country.

Six senior Ministers, including the Prime Minister, decided on a course of gross deception. They decided that they would not reveal this matter in any way to the public at large, to the rest of the Cabinet, or to the Ministers or their departmental heads. They decided to invent a strategy. Their strategy was: 'We will distance ourselves from Mr Combe as he used to be close to us and he is now a lobbyist'. That was the deception that they hoped to get away with. Why did they do that? They did it for the very simple reason that they felt that Mr Combe's relationship with Mr Ivanov might be forced out. Of course, they wanted to say: 'We knew, but we kept it secret. We did not want to hurt him. But my goodness we distanced ourselves from him, although it was all right for everybody else in the community to associate with the man whose relationship with Ivanov had developed to the point that it gave rise to serious security concern'.

If Mr Combe's character was so defective and his relationship with foreign governments was so defective, simply getting rid of Mr Ivanov would not solve the problem at all. At its heart, the solution had nothing to do with the national security of Australia or with civil liberties. It was to do with the government trying to preserve the skins of its member and trying to ensure that it would not come out that one who had been close to them was caught in a bind. So the Government conceived this deception. It is an interesting situation whereby six Cabinet Ministers, including the Prime Minister, said: 'We deliberately set out to deceive the Cabinet and the Ministry. We deliberately withheld from Cabinet and the Ministry the reasons why we were distancing ourselves'. Honourable senators should bear in mind that, as I said earlier, the real and substantial reason for getting rid of Ivanov was his relationship with David Combe. Honourable senators should remember that.

We have the extraordinary situation in which a group of senior Cabinet Ministers, led by the Prime Minister, plotted to deceive and invented a story. Who would believe their nonsense story? Nobody believed their story about the lobbyists. It was, of course, a monstrous deception in itself aimed to deceive everybody and to protect their skins. It had nothing to do with the national good. One has to ask oneself this question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—Senator Button laughs. He has good reason to laugh. It would do him good to read the ministerial statement on the expulsion of the man Skripov. The Attorney-General of the day found no difficulty at all in making a public statement, not a parliamentary statement, giving the full details of the Skripov affair. Why was that not done in this case? The Attorney-General shakes his head.
—No names were given. I have got the Skripov document here. You are talking rubbish. There are no names in it.

—I too have the Skripov document before me. The facts of the matter and the description of the events are all in that document. All the to-ing and fro-ing about the passing of messages is in that document. The Attorney-General can shout and try to divert attention from the issue, but the facts of the matter are contained in the statement. Indeed, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the statement on the Skripov affair so that everyone can understand it.
—Leave is not granted. Let him read it into the record.

—I simply say that if the Attorney-General thinks that I will spend the rest of the time available to me reading this statement he can have another think. It just emphasises the kinds of things that I was saying about the attitudes of mind and the morally corrupted thoughts of the people who made the decision; the moral and ethical judgment of these people is wrong. They are now trying to say: 'We are not going to let Hansard have an up to date copy of the Skripov affair because it will disprove what the Attorney-General has been saying'. So, I invite the people of Australia to read that document.
—Put it in. Ask again.

—The Attorney-General has had second thoughts. He thought it was a good idea at the time not to permit the incorporation of the document. As he has done many times before, the Attorney-General has made another crash landing. I suggest that he had better get his bearings right, because no chief law officer in this country could be so bumble-footed every day as that. Apart from his clumsiness, he has to remember one thing: He is in this chamber to preserve human liberties and freedom and not to protect the skins of his fellow Ministers and members of his Government. As I have said, a massive deception was planned and effected. Then came a statement from the Government that it could not do this any more-that it would have to make a further statement in this chamber because information had been leaked out. The Government then started arguing as to who had leaked it and who had not. Of course, Mr Combe said that he had got it from Labor sources left, right and centre; and he has rather spoilt their fun.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the moral point. The Government was then confronted with the name of Mr Combe being leaked out. What should have been the moral and ethical judgment of a Prime Minister or an Attorney-General faced with a situation in which a man's reputation had been tarnished? Surely the first thing he should have done would have been to say: 'I cannot let this happen. He is entitled to a fair trial: When I announce this, I will announce a royal commission'. The answer to a leak and to innuendoes would have been the prompt establishment of a royal commission. Contrary to what Senator Button has said, it now emerges that there was never any intention to establish a royal commission to investigate the Combe-Ivanov affair. The intention was to produce a corrupt statement which the Prime Minister said would put the matter to rest. A royal commission was not to be established. Here again is the corruption of principle. Here again the Government should have said: 'Right, a man is going to be Moscow-tried in this situation. We will not allow it. We will have a judicial inquiry'.

What did the Government do? It made a statement-what an extraordinary statement -that is supposed to tell this country about great principles of national security and human liberty. It made the statement and said: 'It is not only our statement. It is an agreed, compromise statement between the man we are accusing and ourselves'. How in the nature of human justice does anybody ever bring forward such an immoral hotch-potch as this? How could anyone say in this chamber: 'I spent the time with him going through the statement line by line'? It now emerges that, with respect to the most important part of that statement, what the Government believed and intended was quite different from what Mr Combe finally agreed to. The information and advice then available to the Government suggested that Mr Combe's relationship with Ivanov had developed to the point where it gave rise to serious security concern.

The view of the Cabinet Sub-committee on National and International Security was that as events had developed Mr Combe either had been or appeared to have been compromised by Ivanov to the extent that it was no longer appropriate for Ministers to deal with him. Can honourable senators think of anything that is more corrupt in thought than that it was appropriate for everybody else to deal with him, but not Ministers? Let us not forget the part that where he appeared to be compromised was not in the statement. The Government's view was that he had been compromised. It was prepared-without trial at all, after having had him in a room without a solicitor, and giving him selective excerpts-to publish a statement. That statement convicted him on the spot. Does anyone doubt at all that the man was left without a shred of credit, that he had no shred of reputation and that he could not get a job anywhere in Australia? Can anything worse be said of any human being than that he was in fact a spy or on the way to being a spy, that he was compromised, caught up and a danger and a security threat? In other words, any one of his judgments for the future would be bad judgments because he made a bad judgment, an un-Australian judgment, in this matter. That is what this Government did. It cheerfully went along and had a Moscow trial and published the verdict without the man himself having a chance. It then said: 'Oh, he had the chance and he accepts it'. Do not forget what the Labor Government said. It said: 'Mr Combe accepts this'.

In fact Mr Combe says that he does not understand and he does not accept the proposition that he compromised himself. So here again we have a conflict of statements, a massive corruption of thought in thise whole situation. The Government was not going to set up an inquiry; it was going to judge, condemn and announce the verdict and it was going to secure a statement by duress in a back room deal.

TALK.START.PARA: —And execute it.

—And execute it. What else could he do but agree, in what must be the most horrible breach of human liberties in this country? The Government pretends that it had intended to have an inquiry. One of the Ministers, Mr Young, confessed or was forced to confess that he breached security. In any other government at all if that man had a shred of decency he would have resigned. Let me canvass the point that I started with. I said that this statement does not raise the accidental misbehaviour of Ministers because they lack knowledge of their departments or they were clumsy. The judgments were judgments that human beings, at any point of their lives are forced to make in judgment of other human beings-the qualities of ethics and morals, the question of principle and the question of standards. What a corruption it is that in the statement by Mr Hawke he said that the two things that the Government had before it all the time were national security and human liberty. National security, when it was going to put up a deception that it was putting a barrier between this man and Ministers because he was a lobbyist? Although the Government believes he was compromised it let him go on and get compromised again with some other foreign government. Human liberty in this Moscow trial! What kind of enormity is involved?

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at what has happened along this journey. A committee of senior Ministers meets. Those Ministers receive information from the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation which they test and say: 'We believe; we agree'. They reach a conclusion that the man has been compromised and that indeed the other man Ivanov must go, primarily because of his association with Combe. So they invent a deception. They invent this phoney directive that every member of the Labor Caucus must have known was phoney-that there must be a distance between Ministers and Combe. Did anyone ask why?

I raised this question at the beginning. The matter gets to the very heart of the quality of decision-making, an insight into the attitudes of mind and the qualities of moral and ethical judgment of people. It focuses on their attitude to civil liberties. I will expand on that as an example. How could any man, the Attorney-General, the Prime Minister or any of those six men ever again mouth before these people their belief in civil liberties when in fact they took a person and deliberately, to save their own skins, sacrificed him without a trial ? Never before that I know of has that happened. These are the people I never want to hear again-this Hawke Government-talking about civil liberties because if it did that to its mate, God knows what it would do. With friends like that, who needs enemies? The Attorney-General should not smile. He is left without a shred of credit in the field of human liberties. No lawyer, no human being, nobody without the need for the discipline of law would ever do that to any human being.

TALK.START.PARA: —No wonder you are sitting where you are now.

—The interjection is very interesting. We know where Senator Button is now. He has been rebuked, he has had his ear twisted and his nose twisted and that will go on because of the very lack of judgment of which I am now talking. I come to the next theme; that is, the Government's unwillingness to give this man a fair trial, and selectivity of information. The Prime Minister said that this man had every bit of the information before him. Forced out of the Attorney-General was the admission about selected excerpts of tapes. No solicitor was present. What kind of a situation is it where a government, faced with this monstrous position, says: 'We are going to try to make a deal behind the scenes. We are going to lock up our former mate with the ASIO head and with the Attorney-General. We are going to force him into a compromise. We are going to present the statement to people not as the statement of the Government and its beliefs, but as a bargain struck between two people'? Has any government ever done a more monstrous thing? Is it a bargain that has been struck?

SPEECH.PARA: The Attorney-General is pledged to tell the truth, to extract the objective judgments. What does he do? He takes part in a sordid deal of duress, a sordid deal behind doors with selected information, not total information. Here he sits now as a man who went on television and added to his sins by proferring more and more information when he knew, above everything, that once a judicial inquiry is signalled, he ought to do nothing at all to interfere with the liberty of the man. No wonder Mr Combe is wondering about his mates. No wonder he said he will be fairer to Mick Young than Mick Young was to him. So it went-the deception, the pretence that this was to be simply a distancing of lobbyists, the revelation in the statement and then of course the pretence that the Government was always going to have a judicial inquiry. Let us remember that.

Do not forget that when Senator Button was asked whether the Government would have an inquiry into the Combe affair he said that the Government had been considering it on this matter. That was the question and that was the answer. Have a look at it. The sting in the tail is that he said the consideration had been on this matter. Of course that was not true because the Prime Minister has said-no doubt he will rebuke the Minister-there was no intention of any judicial inquiry on Mr Combe after that ministerial statement. The statement was there to put the matter to rest. Senator Gareth Evans was on the Sunday program that there was no intention of a judicial inquiry and that the real reason there was a judicial inquiry was that Mr Combe had committed the terrible error of talking after a statement. Because he had talked and said things it embarrassed the Government and it had to have a judicial inquiry. So he blamed Mr Combe on the Sunday program.

Let me simply say: In some 30 years of traversing public life in this country, in looking at the Petrov and Skripov affairs and looking at the various attacks that have been made on public figures, I have never before seen or been privy to such an ugly un-Australian set of judgments or actions by anybody. It is in fact a totally un-Australian action. It is the breach of every moral and ethical principle. The Government stands condemned. If the Australian Democrats refuse to support the amendment it will show also some penetrating thinking into the minds of the Democrats. I condemn the action of the Government and I commend the amendment to the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will not be necessary to say very much on this matter. All I want to say is that the appointment of the royal commission of inquiry makes it both unnecessary and undesirable to comment further at any length on the Ivanov-Combe affair or any of the matters involved in it. In any event, there is not a great deal that I wish to say in reply to Senator Sir John Carrick for he has contributed nothing in the last half-hour to our knowledge, understanding or appreciation of this affair other than ignorance, bombast and hypocrisy.

SPEECH.PARA: The ignorance in his contribution is evident from the way in which he simply piled speculation upon speculation about the whole course of events about which he could know nothing and, indeed, makes clear that he knows nothing. If I were to attempt to redress his ignorance as to the detailed course of events I would, of course, be placed in the impossible situation of placing on the public record matters which ought not to be on the public record and about which we could be justly criticised if we did so act. So the situation is as I have stated it. If there is anything that anyone remains concerned about in relation to this affair or any aspect of it, the course is open for that person to seek to make an appropriate submission to the inquiry. No doubt the full truth of the matter will there emerge.

The bombast that was involved in Senator Sir John Carrick's contribution was also, I suggest, self-evident-no way more so than in the nonsense that was engaged in by the honourable senator in the context of seeking to place on the record the account of the Skripov affair in 1963. I resisted the attempt by the honourable senator to place the Skripov material on the record for two reasons: Firstly, he had not gone through the normal courtesies of making a request to this side of the chamber before seeking to incorporate material; but, secondly, that material is manifestly irrelevant to anything that is in issue in this case . There is no comparison, no degree of comparability whatsoever, between the circumstances of the Skripov affair and the circumstances of this affair. But in the event that anyone should be in any doubt about that let me repeat now the offer I indeed made to Senator Sir John Carrick in the latter part of his speech -which he so bombastically refused-to allow him to incorporate the material by my seeking leave to incorporate the account of the Skripov affair in 1963. I so seek leave to incorporate that material.
Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —With leave not being granted, the record will remain now utterly obscure. I simply say for the record that the Skripov description of events is a very detailed account of spies crawling around the undergrowth and putting canisters inside bell jars underneath bridges. There is a detailed account of the swapping of messages and information and contacts between a KGB officer, Mr Skripov, and an unidentified Australian agent from the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation who was clearly set up as an agent provocateur to entrap very successfully Skripov into showing his particular colours. The circumstances of that affair are utterly without any basis of comparison with the circumstances of the present affair. Putting them on the record would have made that abundantly clear. Now the record will not disclose those circumstances and so be it.

SPEECH.PARA: The final point I want to make is about the hypocrisy of Senator Sir John Carrick's contribution in this affair. The crocodile tears that have been wept over Mr Combe are in quite remarkable contrast to the way in which the then Government sought to hound Mr Combe into the political grave at the time of the Iraqi affair in 1976. We did not hear much then about Mr Combe's liberties or right not to be traduced or to have his reputation prejudiced on the basis of smear and innuendo. The very same gentleman who has been the subject of public attention on this occasion was the recipient of some really quite extraordinary flak not only by the now members of the Opposition but also, of course, by the media at that stage. People have a short memory in these matters.

I remind the Senate that when one is talking about the protection of civil liberties the crocodile tears that are being wept on this occasion really do stand starkly exposed for the hypocrisy they are when one contemplates the record of the Fraser Government in civil liberty matters. Let me mention some aspects of that record. I refer to the failure to ratify the International Labour Organisation conventions on a whole variety of human rights matters, most notably on the rights of indigenous minorities; the failure to ratify the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women; and the refusal to sign the optional protocol to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights; the ratification of that Covenant only on the basis of a world precedent-shattering series of reservations and declarations far more than any comparable country and which have been the subject of international criticism.

I refer to the area of freedom of expression; the passage of atomic energy legislation containing, as might be recalled, quite unprecedented penalties for citizens dissenting against uranium mining and processing. There was the resurgence of activity, with the active encouragement of the then Government, of the film censorship authorities. There was the attempt to stifle discussion through legal action based on Crown privilege and copyright in the defence papers case, a case which was handled very differently from the National Times case which has just concluded under the auspices of this Government. There was the Anzac Day ordinance and its successor in the Australian Capital Territory which were designed to stifle peaceful assembly. There was the failure to enact freedom of information legislation worthy of the name, as Senator Missen would acknowledge. There were endless delays in subsequent implementation of that legislation. There was the attempt to impose a tax on knowledge again in the freedom of expression area, in the form of sales tax on books, newspapers and magazines.

In the area of equality and discrimination there was the emasculation of Al Grassby as Commissioner for Community Relations. There was the failure to support him in his attempts to combat racism in Queensland and Western Australia . There was the support for the attack on the Aboriginal land rights by the Northern Territory Government. There was the failure to use the Commonwealth's power to move in to protect the people of Noonkanbah against deprivation by the Liberal Government in Western Australia. There was in the area of police and security--

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this your excuse for starting badly?

—The record is a long one, a very unhappy one and a very sordid one. It demonstrates this hypocrisy that I am talking about which is displayed whenever the subject of civil liberties arises. There was the failure to proceed with the Criminal Investigation Bill and the undermining involved in successive versions of that Bill of the report of the Australian Law Reform Commission. There was the passage of narcotics legislation with its alarming, unprecedented and insufficiently restricted new powers vested in the police and the courts. There was the way in which ASIO surveillance activity very substantially increased under the last Government without any accompanying safeguards being built into that legislation and, in fact, with fierce resistance by the last Government to the attempts by the then Opposition Labor Party to build in very detailed accountability provisions for the operation of that organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: One could go on and on. I will not use the occasion to bore anyone further because it is a very tedious and long list when one seeks to recite the credentials on civil liberties matters of those sitting opposite. On this occasion I obviously do not seek to go any further into a defence of the Government's position as to the details of this case. The character and the content of the Government's position will clearly emerge in due course.

But I will make two other points to demonstrate the hypocrisy of the Opposition 's position on this matter. There was the total failure of Senator Sir John Carrick, in anything he said, to address the role played by the Opposition in bringing to public attention for the first time the name of David Combe in relation to the Ivanov affair. There was the orchestrated question session both in this chamber and simultaneously in the House of Representatives which was deliberately and cynically designed to get on to the record in the context of the ASIO affair the name of David Combe. This was done by the people who are shedding the buckets, the rivers and the oceans of crocodile tears that we see now.

Finally, as a demonstration of the sheer inbuilt, inherent hypocrisy of the Opposition's position, so noisily articulated by Senator Sir John Carrick, is the way in which we have had this constant invitation-repeated most recently just a few minutes ago-to put the detailed account on the record as to why the Government acted as it did in this matter. That is combined simultaneously with denunciations of the Government for such detailed matter as it has put on the record on the basis that in security matters, so it is said, one should never do anything other than confirm or deny. The Opposition cannot have it both ways. It cannot claim to have both a detailed account put on the record and at the same time be denouncing the other side when it attempts to do just that to set the record at least partially clear. That kind of hypocrisy, combined with that kind of bombast, combined with that kind of ignorance is not a constructive contribution to debate on this or any other subject.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment because very clearly there is a case to answer with respect to the actions of the Ministers of this Government. I have every confidence in the Royal Commissioner and in the terms of reference in a general sense, that the Commissioner has been given. A crucial part is the role played by the Ministers of this Government and they are not explored within the terms which are laid down before the Royal Commissioner. I do not wish to go into a general discussion or debate about the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, into Mr Combe or the incompetence of the Australian Labor Party in this matter. I will do that in great detail and depth at a later date. I want to talk specifically to the amendment that is before us which is whether or not the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Special Minister of State (Mr Young), any other Minister or any other senior Government adviser disclosed confidential information in any way relating to the decision to expel from Australia Mr Valeriy Nikolayevich Ivanov, because it strikes at the very heart of responsible government. There is clear, undenied evidence that the Special Minister of State, Mr Mick Young, talked to at least one man, a Mr Cameron, over lunch and breached the secrecy of Cabinet on a matter of absolute importance to the security of this country. If he will do it on one matter, what will he do on other matters? What will other Ministers do if we do not have a system of secrecy and confidentiality with respect to Cabinet decisions? These allegations have not been denied; in fact, it has been agreed that they are true . We have Mr David Barnett, Mr Richard Farmer and a whole range of people-we do not know how many-knowing about the matter and they knew because members of this Government, Ministers of the Crown, broke an oath and told people outside Cabinet what the Cabinet's decision was. I do not know who the sources were. We know that one of them was Mr Young but it might have been any or all of the five Ministers involved. We cannot tolerate that sort of situation.

SPEECH.PARA: Many issues are involved in the Royal Commission on Security and Intelligence Agencies and, as I said at the outset, I do not wish to canvass all of them. If we look at the actions of Mr Young the facts are beyond dispute. He was at a luncheon with several lobbyists or journalists-I do not know how many. Did he tell only one person, Mr Cameron, or did he tell a whole lot of people? He thought that he could make the situation all right by saying afterwards: 'They stayed with me; they did not go out'. That is not the point at all. It does not matter whether Mr Young held their hands and put tape across their mouths. The point is that he told them; he breached the security of Cabinet and that is what security is all about. We cannot entrust the nation's security with someone who has such a loose regard for a sense of duty as Mr Young has admitted to having.

The convention of Cabinet solidarity is not some sort of effete system that the Liberals have developed over the many years they have been in government. It is a matter of absolute necessity for the conduct of the affairs of state. In this instance we are concerned with national security but we could just as well be concerned with financial matters. Indeed, the mini-Budget which will be presented tonight is a matter, I think, of great financial significance to the business community. If Ministers leak the contents of a Budget before it is brought down, it is possible that people can make all sorts of financial killings in the light of that knowledge. Take a simple thing such as a rise in the excise level. Someone could corner the market in whisky or brandy, buy it up before the Budget is released, and resell it afterwards. I guess that Labor Party members can be excused because they are commercially ignorant people. At best they are academics and at worst-well, we will no go into that. Obviously they have no knowledge of how the commercial world works. On those grounds alone there is an overwhelming case for Cabinet secrecy with respect to its deliberations.

The charges, as Senator Sir John Carrick outlined, are very grave against Mr Combe. The use of the word 'compromise' in a technical sense has a very distinct and specific meaning. It is not a colloquial word in any sense at all. It carries the gravest of connotations as to what Mr Combe's actions were. I believe the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). I do not dispute in any way at all the Attorney-General's judgment on this matter. I have had the opportunity of watching him for nearly five years and while he might be frequently extravagant and flamboyant with his language, thoughtless too from time to time and might fence with words when it suits him, when he gives me or the public a direct answer I believe him implicitly. His statement to Sam Lipski was absolutely black and white. I have every certainty that the Attorney-General and those Ministers who are involved had every justification for taking the action that they did with Mr Combe, and I do not seek to expose why they did it. I have confidence that the action they took was correct and I will not challenge them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish I had your confidence.

—That is my belief and I will not walk away from it. The point is that we are probably dealing with one or more Soviet agents. I know enough of the world to know that the Soviets never put half-trained people into the field. They are all professionals. Therefore I take very seriously the actions that they get up to. In the face of the gravest charges about Mr Combe there is a need for a responsible approach to this issue. Let us look at Mr Young's actions . When he was challenged in the House of Representatives, what do we see? I quote from the House of Representatives Hansard of 17 May. In answer to a question from Mr Fife about whether he regards the statement to Mr Cameron on the expulsion of Ivanov as consistent with the oath of office of a Minister of the Crown, Mr Young replied:

SPEECH.PARA: I was so excited-I had just been shown the salaries of Ministers-that I forgot what really the commitment was when I was sworn in. I can understand why Malcolm cried when he lost the election.

My God, a Minister of the Crown is worried about his money! He is for sale to the highest bidder; he is dazzled by a salary. What a sense of responsibility from a Minister of state! No wonder he is known as the arch wheeler-dealer in this place. How will this country be run with a Minister such as him looking after electoral reforms and the electoral boundaries? We would not know what could come from someone who takes such a cavalier approach to his sense of responsibility as Mr Young has demonstrated on this matter. This is not a trivial matter in any way at all. We do not know what Labor Party members, what friends of the Labor Party and what business people are availing themselves of leaks from a Cabinet that is apparently filled with people such as Mr Young.

Finally, I move to Labor's paranoia with the intelligence community. This is a long-standing thing and it reaches extreme forms. I would certainly excuse the Attorney-General and the Prime Minister from the extreme category. Very clearly, the Labor Party is absolutely paranoid about the intelligence community.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, we are not. We know they are out to get us.

—As Senator Robert Ray has demonstrated, Labor senators constantly need to have their insecurity cosseted by lashing out at imaginary ghosts in the form of people looking after the security of this country. Apart from the feelings of the ALP on this matter, I should like to look at one of its actions. I shall quote Mr Combe on this matter. In an article in the Bulletin of 19 January last year, relating to the Iraqi breakfast, he made the statement:

SPEECH.PARA: Some months after the whole affair was over I saw an ASIO dossier on Fischer which set out his record-
How many people in this Senate, apart from the Attorney-General and the former Attorney-General, have ever seen an ASIO document?

TALK.START.PARA: —Who leaked it?

—That is precisely the question I was about to ask. Who gave the information to Mr Combe? Where did Mr Combe see an ASIO dossier? How many other Labor people see ASIO dossiers? Do people working in ASIO or any of the five intelligence organisations in this country want their responsible approach to their lives and their duties treated by a cavalier approach by the Labor Party with respect to confidential documents? How did Mr Combe know that a Mr Fischer had an ASIO file? How did he see it? It is characteristic of the ALP's approach to security in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I find this whole business astonishing when I look at the statements of the ALP in relation to the last election. I shall quote, because one of the authors is here-Senator Gareth Evans-from a document 'Labor and the Quality of Government' which came out on 9 February of this year. That document states:

Labor is committed to a systematic implementation of the principles of open government. In addition we remain committed to effective administrative remedies as being essential to fairness in government to the proper public accountability of administrative bodies and the preservation of individual rights.
How can we have accountability of administrative bodies if Ministers go around leaking information? Later in the policy speech of 16 February--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are exposing some interesting areas.

—I will have to correct the Hansard on that point. I was referring to a document entitled 'Labor and the Quality of Government' and to a statement to the effect that 'Labor in office would be committed to restoring the probity of government'. How can we have probity when people act like Mr Young acts? Of course we have the delightful quote that 'the flow of Cabinet business has been notoriously poorly organised with Cabinet constantly preoccupied with crisis management at the expense of expeditious decision-making '-a reference to the Fraser Government. How more relevant it has been to the last two weeks of this Government. Labor is bound both morally and ethically to support the amendment which the Opposition is putting.

SPEECH.PARA: Now that some Australian Democrat senators are in the chamber I should like to turn to their opposition to this amendment. I listened very carefully to Senator Haines. As usual nothing in her speech justified the position she was taking. The fundamental point that I make in support of this amendment is that of ministerial accountability. There is nothing more to it than that. I wonder whether the Democrats have forgotten the claim they made so frequently in their electoral platform that they are there to keep the bastards honest. And now they come for the first time in this Parliament to the crunch point; they come to the point of moral judgment and whether they will keep the Government honest and whether they will put the finger on a Minister who has clearly breached every convention in the book. I believe that the Democrats have shown that they lack the moral fibre to take on the Labor Party on this issue. They will not challenge the Labor Party; they will not vote against it. They are terrified of a general election and losing their position. They will not support the Opposition's amendment. From the mewling and meandering I hear from the Democrats in front of me I hope that their consciences are stirring them. If their consciences are stirring them, let them take counsel of their fears, conquer them and do that which principle demands they do, and support the Opposition with this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the first opportunity I have had to speak on this matter since it arose in the Parliament. Indeed, it is the first opportunity we really have had to look at the new Government and the test which it would face when it encounters the problems of national security and civil liberties. One must say that in regard to this matter the Government has obviously fallen at the first barrier.
—The fence, not the barrier.

—Oh no, the Government has not even got out of the barrier. It probably got lost before it even got out of the stalls. This is a subject on which the Government is tested. It is not a matter in which we in this chamber can tolerate the idea that Senator Gareth Evans puts before us that now that there is a Royal Commission on Security and Intellegence Agencies it is unnecessary for him to comment. In other words, parliamentary accountability is out of season while there is a royal commission. If that is the reason we have set up a royal commission, let him say so, but to my mind parliamentary accountability remains an important question. It is important for us to analyse what we may know about the course of conduct which the Government has engaged in in regard to Mr Combe, the appointment of the Royal Commission and the adequacy of its terms of reference, which obviously are not adequate. We must also ensure that the Royal Commission will cover the whole area of accountability which I believe to some extent it may otherwise miss.

SPEECH.PARA: I say to the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) that I certainly believe it is important for us to investigate some of the facts which have appeared in the statements that have come forward in the past. In the course of his very short speech, Senator Evans-I suppose brevity is to be praised is most circumstances, but not today-mentioned the criminal investigation Bill which, of course, is one of the things with which our Government did not succeed. Senator Evans has never let us forget the fact that we have never passed a criminal investigation Bill in this Parliament. I would like the Attorney-General to look at the terms of the Bill and the rights under that Bill which are properly to be given to ordinary citizens-I suppose Mr Combe is entitled to those rights as an ordinary citizen-and see how the course of conduct by the Government in regard to Mr Combe falls so far short of the entitlement which we believe ought to be--

TALK.START.PARA: —Be fair. There are no criminal charges here.

—He is not on a criminal charge; I see, so that is it. That is a very convenient excuse, is it not? Of course, criminal investigation includes investigation of all kinds of things, including matters which may not finish up as a charge. Of course, the criminal investigation Bill is designed to protect people in those situations. A matter does not have to end with a criminal charge . Of course, a person who loses his occupation and reputation will suffer very considerably if he does not have the right of civil liberties which we hope that Bill will ensure. I think the Attorney-General should look again and see whether his conduct and the conduct of the Government has measured up to those needs.
—Which particular clause of that Bill are you suggesting that we would breach if that were the case?
—Certainly, he did not have his lawyer at the beginning. He was brought here and he was taken through documents. He was read documents and so forth.
—Selected documents.

—Selected documents at that; documents which the Government chose to put before him. Then of course the Government came to the agreed statement. It surely is true that in regard to statements which will damage a person one ought to be very careful in what one has said. The Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I trust this statement will put to rest the uncertainty of the last few days, and convince all Australians, of whatever political persuasion, of the correctness and fairness of our handling of the matter.

Of course he did not have that effect at all. Indeed it was intended to be an important statement. Indeed it was intended that Mr Combe should be committed to that statement because he went through it line by line. I know that even more recently the Attorney-General said 'word by word'. I take it that the words in the statement were carefully considered. I should like to look at a few of them to see the way in which the assassination of this man's reputation has been-

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying I am telling lies when I say you didn't accept that?
—No, I am not saying lies; I am talking about loose statements-
—What are you talking about?
—If the Attorney would stop for a moment and listen, he might learn something to his advantage. He has indeed assassinated Mr Combe's character by the language used in the statement.
—Which he agreed to.

—He did not agree to it; he did not agree that the points put forward as facts were correct. He says, in the very careful words that the Attorney-General put into the statement, that he understands and accepts the statement but he has said publicly and firmly that he did not agree with it, and of course he does not agree with it today. Whatever the Attorney-General intended obviously Mr Combe did not intend to say that the facts put forward in the statement were correct. We know that, as he said, he has become an object of public censure without the opportunity to defend himself.
—Do you think he might have changed his mind?

—Of course he might have changed his mind, because he might have had a chance later to read the statement and to see the words to which he was committed. One reads in this statement what is said to be the principled position taken by the Government. I mention that matter because it is the background to the statement. Why was Mr Combe called in? Why was it that the Government felt it was necessary to take action? Honourable senators will recall from the statement that the full Ministry agreed on 2 May to a number of considerations, the first of which, states:

SPEECH.PARA: Ministers' doors should be, and be seen to be, open without the need for leverage by a Party insider;

I am interested to know why it was necessary for the Government to come to that conclusion and to establish that principle. Had there been leverage? Had people got in in this way? Had Ministers been susceptible to wrongful pressure? It certainly reads to me as though that was so. Perhaps there should be an investigation of the activities of Ministers, not just lobbyists, who apparently have been succumbing to that pressure. It was found necessary to establish this principle to stop this happening. The second consideration states:
. . . it was not appropriate that a former Party official, by virtue of that status, have special advantages or access to Government denied to others.

That is interesting, too. One can only assume that that happened, that in the short period that the Government has been in office not necessarily Mr Combe but officials had been getting special access to Government denied to others. If this is so, and it happened in the first month or two of the Government's reign, one wonders what we will see before it finishes.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you think lobbying is all about?
—I would think lobbying is not all about getting--
—Access to government.

—Yes, but not getting special advantages. If they get special advantages then one must wonder what those special advantages are. Let us look at some of the other points in the statement. This statement has destroyed a man 's occupation and living. There is no question about that; they have been destroyed. In the course of the statement it is said in regard to Mr Combe that a relationship had developed to a point where it 'gave rise to a serious security concern'. It does not say he was a security risk. The statement later goes on to say that he was not a spy and he has not broken the law; both those things are said on the other side of the fence. It says that he is a 'serious security concern'. What might that mean? I do not have Senator MacGibbon's trusting faith in the security service or the people who necessarily make it up. I think they are very ordinary people. I must say, having met and fallen into conversation with one or two Australian Security Intelligence Organisation agents who have come to me once or twice to ask me about someone-I have no necessity to say anything critical of them-they prove to have extremely right wing views of a very odd nature. I doubt whether many people in the security service would have serious left wing views of an odd nature, but I must say that I would not put all my faith in all security officers having a balance of views.

SPEECH.PARA: If there is serious security concern, what does that mean? They can easily get upset; they can easily be concerned; and they can easily make a mistake in regard to documents. That is what Mr Combe is saying. The fact is that that is a very carefully used expression which does the maximum damage to a person but does not really explain what it means. As I say, we have had plenty of examples of this sort of language in the past.

The statement goes on to say that the Government came to the conclusion that his relationship with Ivanov developed to a point where it gave rise to serious security concern. I do not challenge the Ivanov expulsion. It is accepted on both sides of the political fence. Those who know the details, including the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock, accept that he should have gone. No doubt that was justified. But as far as Mr Combe is concerned, the Prime Minister said in his statement:

The view of the National and International Security Sub-committee was that, as events developed, Mr Combe either had been, or appeared to have been, compromised by Ivanov to the extent that it was no longer appropriate for Government Ministers to deal with him.

I put aside the point which Senator Sir John Carrick made-that apparently it is all right to deal with anyone else around the place but it is Government Ministers who have to be protected. What does the Prime Minister mean by ' compromise'? Senator MacGibbon says that that is a well known tool in the trade and that one should know what it means. I must confess that I immediately think of the Christine Keeler case or something like that when people talk about being compromised. I think the word has all kinds of meanings in the eyes of people. It does not tell me anything. To say something derogatory about a person and to suggest that the person had at least been misled or hoodwinked, might not suggest that the person knew the situation. Mr Combe has denied that he knew that Ivanov was a KGB agent. I think he recognised, as most people would, that it was quite probable that he was. The statement suggested that he might not only have been compromised but also appeared to have been compromised. That is even vaguer language, and no one can tell me that it is not deliberately phrased in that manner. It does the maximum damage to a person without saying what has happened.

This is a disastrous statement from the point of view of anyone connected, as the Attorney-General has been for many years with civil liberties organisations. He should be ashamed to produce a document which produces so much damage.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the last two paragraphs of it, completely clearing his name of being a spy or being guilty of any criminal offence? Is that not to the point?

—Yes. The Attorney puts an ambit on the statement. He says that Mr Combe is not a spy and there is no criminal offence, having said the other things as well. Not knowing what the principled position of the Government really is leaves us in a real mess. At the end of the statement the Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: But I trust this statement will put to rest the uncertainty of the last few days, . . .

I remind honourable senators of something else that was in the statement. One would think that Combe would have some rights, before a decision was made, to clear his name in some way if there were any doubt. The statement said:

. . . the Government has never been in any doubt about the validity of its decision. At the same time it was concerned that he should not become the object of public censure without some opportunity to defend himself. From the time that the Opposition used his name in the House yesterday, it was essential that he be given this opportunity.

Apparently it was not essential that he should have the opportunity before then. It was not essential even when others, I gather, including people in the Australian Labor Party, were bandying his name around the Parliament before it became known in the Parliament. No, it was only when it became awkward and inconvenient for the Government and a matter of public knowledge that he had the right to defend himself. I suggest that he has an excellent right to claim that he was treated extremely badly. Many people who have written about the incident have said so, including Laurie Oakes. The fact is that much damage has been done to this man. Laurie Oakes put it very well when, after dealing with Mr Combe being 'compromised', he said:

That hardly seems like an adequate basis on which to take action that can be expected to destroy a man's reputation and livelihood-though, to be fair to the Government, it did attempt to keep Mr Combe's involvement in the Ivanov affair from becoming public knowledge.

What a hopeless task it was to try to keep that matter from becoming public knowledge. Even Cabinet members were prepared to make breezy remarks about it at luncheons. I say that this whole incident is a disgrace as far as civil liberties are concerned.

Let me turn briefly to two other areas which I think are important, particularly now that a royal commission has been appointed, headed by Mr Justice Hope, who certainly made a very full examination of the security organisations a few years ago. There are many aspects of that examination that I hope he will reconsider. When we passed the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Bill and put ASIO on a legal foundation nearly five years ago, we legalised many of the illegal activities which ASIO had been performing and which were disclosed in Mr Justice Hope's various reports, to the extent that those reports were available to the Parliament.
