Mr Justice Hope was then quite scathing in some of his remarks about the previous operation of ASIO. He said, among other things, in paragraph 42 of his third report:

The Australian intelligence community is fragmented, poorly co-ordinated and organised. The agencies lack proper guidance direction and control. They do not have good or close relations with the system of government they should serve. In some cases, they have lacked funds and other resources (for example, adequate staff) to do the jobs expected of them. In other cases they have used lack of funds as an alibi for not doing jobs they should have done.

I think it is important that after this period there be an examination to see whether ASIO is now acting properly and efficiently. One hopes that there will be an examination of other aspects. We realise that it is thought desirable that the secrecy provisions of the recent ASIO legislation which conflict with the proposed freedom of information legislation be reviewed. That has not yet been done. I hope it will be done. I hope the judge will give further consideration to that matter.

Over and above those matters, I wish to raise the question of accountability to this Parliament which I raised in 1979 when the ASIO Bill was before the Parliament. The Parliament was not even able to see many of the reports of Mr Justice Hope. Many of them were kept secret and we had to take the Bill upon the trust of Government and Opposition leaders who perhaps had seen more details than we had. At that time I expressed the view that we had never obtained a proper system of accountability to the Parliament. I still hold that view. I hope that Mr Justice Hope, who at that time did not favour the setting up of a small parliamentary committee to supervise the operations of ASIO, will reconsider this idea. When the ASIO legislation was being considered I moved an amendment to bring in a sunset clause that would have brought the legislation up for review within the next year or two. That motion, although supported by the Opposition and one of my colleagues, was defeated. At that time, as recorded on page 1067 of the Hansard for 28 March 1979, I had the following criticism to make concerning accountability to Parliament:

I think that much of the main criticism relates to the fact that ASIO really will not be accountable to the Parliament. I have long held the view that there ought to be a small parliamentary committee of distinguished and long serving members of Parliament to supervise some of the work and activity of ASIO. I believe that this has been advocated often but Mr Justice Hope did not applaud it, nor does the Bill include it. However I remain of the view that that should be done. The annual report is to be made to the Minister, not to the Parliament. There has been criticism of the fact that there is no provision in the Bill for audit control. Mr Justice Hope, in his fourth report, expressed the view-and applauded the suggestion of the Treasury-that provisions for audit ought to be set out in the Bill. I believe that there is in fact an auditing of most of the activities of ASIO but I believe that there ought to be a provision in the Bill, as His Honour recommended, to make this evident and clear.

I believe this is one matter that certainly should be considered in the current review. We are now finding problems in regard to ASIO, problems in the form of decisions such as this. I believe that we need a small committee of members of parliament, sworn to secrecy, who would regularly conduct interviews and take up complaints. Such a committee exists in Great Britain. Committee members would not, of course, generally report to the Parliament but the Parliament would, I trust, be in a position to rely upon their judgment to ensure that there was an input by those in this place who are elected by the people.

There is one other matter that I think ought to be raised in connection with the Royal Commission on Security and Intelligence Agencies. We do not know what is happening to the promised review of the freedom of information legislation. It was promised in the election campaign that there would be a very radical change to the Bill, which was a disappointment to many of us but which came into operation last year. At least it was a record of the previous Government, a record which honourable senators will recall the Whitlam Government could never produce. One hopes that the undertakings which have for years been given by Senator Gareth Evans and others and which were given by the Government in the election campaign-that the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs would be implemented-will be honoured. We hear deadly silence. We hear disturbing rumours. One hopes that this will not be another betrayal of the Government's promises.

I was recently in the United States of America for the purpose of observing what was happening there in regard to freedom of information. I recommend to honourable senators an article which Peter Cole-Adams, the Age correspondent in Washington, wrote in the Age in May 1983. I had discussions with him while I was there and I conducted my own investigations. I come firmly to the same conclusion as he has, that the head of the present United States Government, or, as Mr Cole-Adams calls him, 'the Great Communicator'-a man who glorifies in that name and who projects himself as a crusader for freedom-is making vigorous and systematic efforts to reduce public access to government information. That is what is happening in the United States under the guise of national security. I believe that in the debate which is taking place here, in the actions which the Government is taking, in the reliance which the Government makes upon what Michelle Grattan of the Age of 9 May termed the 'national-security mystique'-an expression she took from Tom Wicker of the New York Times-we have to be careful not to accept that everything that has a label of national security is therefore justified as not needing to be investigated. The Australian Democrats seems to have lost the fine early flourish of their policy to 'keep the bastards honest'. Apparently the ones to whom the Democrats referred originally were on only one side of the fence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do not worry; they are on both sides of the fence.

—I am reassured to hear from Senator Macklin that they are on both sides of the fence. I trust that we can expect the Democrats to adopt the same even-handed approach in these dealings. That approach will be put very well to the test today in the vote on the amendment before us. That will decide whether the terms of reference of the Royal Commission should be widened to ensure that it fully investigates all aspects that need investigation. The last few weeks have been a period not of open government-that has not come yet-but what I call open-mouthed government, or perhaps loose lipped government. I do not know whether that period is drawing to an end. A certain Minister said that he would be very dull in Question Time. I think he has been, but perhaps he has just been true to form.
—It is not true to form.

—No, it is not true to form; that is true. He is showing unusual dullness, but whether he can keep it up is another matter. The important consideration is that we in this chamber are entitled to query the disgraceful performance in the Combe affair and the way in which it has led ultimately to a royal commission. That does not stop the Senate from questioning and being concerned with matters of importance in this area. We are concerned to ensure that there is a proper investigation by the Royal Commission of all matters, including the question of accountability of Parliament, and that we are assured that there will not be a reliance on national security to stop a real improvement in the freedom of information legislation in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I await with desperate interest the statement which I trust will come soon from the Attorney-General on the implementation of the promises which have been made, which had some effect, I am sure, on winning votes in the last election. On all these grounds, I support the amendment. I support also the fact that there will be an investigation, but I hope that it will be full and thorough, and that the Attorney-General will learn from the folly of his ways in the last few weeks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -The statement we are discussing at the moment concerns the Royal Commission on Security and Intelligence Agencies. In particular, we are discussing the amendments moved by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney). Senator Haines, who spoke on the last occasion that the Senate discussed the matter, raised the necessity for widening proposed sub- paragraph (c) (ii) of the Opposition's amendment. Sub-paragraph (i) is a replica of that which is already contained in the original terms of reference of the Commission; in other words, it is unexceptional not only to us, but also to the Government. So the only point at issue is sub-paragraph (c) (ii), which states:

SPEECH.PARA: whether or not the Prime Minister, the Special Minister of State or any other Minister or any senior Government adviser disclosed confidential information in any way relating to the decision to expel from Australia Mr Valeriy Nikolayevich Ivanov;

The amendment then takes in paragraph (d) and subsequent items in the terms of references. I foreshadow that the Australian Democrats propose to move an amendment to the Opposition amendment in the following terms:

Proposed sub-paragraph (c) (ii), after 'senior Government advisor', insert 'or the Leader of the Opposition in the House of Representatives and the Leader and Deputy Leader of the National Party in the House of Representatives'.

We would be amenable to some other honourable senator inserting in that amendment the fact that Senator Chipp is our Leader. I will outline to the Senate the reasons for expanding the Opposition's amendment. Senator Sir John Carrick, who led in the debate today, in a moving speech made a number of points which focused, in particular, on the need for justice for a particular individual-in this case, Mr Combe. That is a laudable aim. It is one which I hope every honourable senator in this place will support. We often find individuals who run up against the bureaucracy or the Executive Government and are trampled upon. One of the items to which the Parliament can still turn its attention is the protection of the individual citizen in these matters. That is an extremely important item, and one to which we ought to pay attention.

If we are concerned about whether there might have been disclosure of confidential information, certainly as Senator MacGibbon pointed out-Senator Missen also pointed it out in passing-we would have to include all of those people who may have had access to that confidential information. Many wild claims have been made not only here and in the House of Representatives but also on various television programs about where this information may have come from. Some of the people are included in the Opposition's amendment by name; that is, the Prime Minister and the Special Minister of State at least in their formal designation. The words 'any other Minister or any senior Government advisor' would obviously include all of those Ministers currently serving on the Cabinet Sub-committee on National and International Security. Of course, it has been a convention in this country for quite a long time that the Leader of the Opposition is briefed by the Prime Minister on sensitive matters of national and international security. That is an extremely important part of the democratic process in this country, one which has been built up by convention. There is, of course, no formal necessity or requirement for governments to do so. But governments of all political persuasions have carried out this activity of keeping the Leader of the Opposition fully informed on all of these matters; hence, they are able to create, at least at that basic national security level, some general agreement that it is useful that the Prime Minister and the alternative Prime Minister have access to as much detailed confidential information on national security as can possibly be divulged. Therefore, it would be important in seeking justice, as Senator Sir John Carrick said, to make sure that we include in the Senate's opinion of any possible extension of terms of reference all of those people who might have been privy to this information. Senator Haines alluded precisely to that situation. That is why I now formally move:

Proposed sub-paragraph (c) (ii), after 'senior Government advisor', insert 'or the Leader of the Opposition in the House of Representatives and the Leader and Deputy Leader of the National Party in the House of Representatives'.

We seek to include not only the Leader of the Opposition, but also the Leader and Deputy Leader of the National Party in the House of Representatives. The Opposition has sought to include 'any other Minister'; in other words, Ministers who may have heard from other Ministers. The Opposition amendment covers Ministers who are on the Cabinet Sub-committee on National and International Security, and the possibility that those Ministers may have leaked information to other Ministers and senior Government advisers. It is fairhanded, if that be the case, that we also include those people to whom the Leader of the Opposition could possibly have leaked information, such as the Leader and Deputy Leader of the National Party in the House of Representatives. After all, it was Mr Sinclair who first raised Mr Combe's name in Parliament. Therefore, it is only evenhanded, if we are to seek an opinion from the Senate in relation to Ministers, other Ministers and senior Government advisers that we extend it to include the Leader of the Opposition, about whom allegations have also been made publicly, and the Leader and Deputy Leader of the National Party about whom allegations have also been made publicly. The proposition, therefore, is to extend the Opposition's amendment to include those people. We hope, in doing so, that the Opposition will agree to the amendment that we have sought to attach to its amendment, so that the Senate may express an opinion on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wished to indicate before the debate ran out that the Opposition has no difficulty with the amendment to its amendment which has been suggested by the Australian Democrats. The Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock, has already publicly indicated that he proposes to make himself available to the royal commission. The Opposition certainly has nothing to hide in this matter. The Opposition's sole concern has been to ensure that the terms of reference are wide enough to encompass matters about which concern has been expressed in this debate and elsewhere. Whilst the Opposition does not want to be heard to suggest that it believes itself at fault in any way, it has no objection to being subject to the same scrutiny it would like to see the Government and its advisers subjected to. I want it to be clear on the public record that our sole concern is to have adequately wide terms of reference. On that basis we have no objection at all to the amendment to the amendment we propose.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the context of the cognate debate on the various Bills for Acts to alter the Constitution, I wish now, in the latter stages of my remarks, to refer to the proposal to confer an advisory jurisdiction on the High Court, which proposal has the support of, as I understand it, all those who represent the electors in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: In proposing that an advisory jurisdiction be vested in the High Court, I think it needs to be said right from the beginning that one is concerned not with an improper function being vested in that judicial body. To give an advisory opinion is to act in a judicial manner. Questions put to the High Court will be true questions of law. It will not be dealing with mere political advice or some advisory function which could as well be performed by law officers of the Crown. True questions of law will be posed to the High Court. Indeed, the High Court already exercises something akin to an advisory opinion jurisdiction in its granting of declaratory judgments. In order to expedite the consideration of the constitutional validity of some particular piece of legislation it will give an opinion at times before the Act concerned is proclaimed and certainly before it has been implemented or had any effect on any particular parties. That jurisdiction, whilst it shows that the High Court does not need to have an actual dispute before it, before it can engage in examining the constitutional validity of an Act of Parliament, is inadequate. Therefore, this proposal has many advantages. Not the least of the advantages is that in a declaratory judgment jurisdiction there are still rules as to standing and as to the parties who might appear before the Court which rather restrict the range of those who might be able to aid the Court in giving its advisory opinion.

I believe that a major benefit of this proposal is that the High Court will be able to have before it argument from the whole range of parties that the High Court designates as proper to appear before it in relation to the major constitutional questions that may be involved. Of course, in cases of Commonwealth laws and other matters the reference itself will be by the Cabinet- by the Governor-General in Council. I think one has some protection in that against those over-zealous Attorneys who can sometimes appear on the political scene and who may be tempted to overburden the High Court with too many references. Indeed, this particular proposal that it be the Cabinet which makes the decision as to the sending of a reference will, I believe, lead to a certain caution and responsibility in the instances which will come before that Bench.

As to the jurisdiction or the matters which may be referred, there are four major categories. The first relates to any question of law as to the validity of an enactment of the Parliament of the Commonwealth or as to the validity, if enacted, of a proposed enactment of the Parliament. In other words, a Bill can be referred to the High Court for its advisory opinion. This has some dangers. I for my part certainly wish that any proposed enactment that is referred to the High Court will have passed through the various stages of parliamentary debate and consideration in both chambers up to, perhaps, the third reading stage in the Senate or in the second chamber, as the case may be. In other words, it ought to be the case that it is the considered opinion of the Parliament, even if not finally enacted, as to what ought to be the law which is put before the High Court. I believe that there are instances-for example, trade practices legislation some years ago and the question of Commonwealth sovereignty over off -shore resources-which might have been more conveniently and expeditiously dealt with and that more robust and certain legislation and administrative arrangements could have been entered into by the Commonwealth had an advisory opinion jurisdiction been available to test the question of whether the Commonwealth had power in relation to certain trade practices matters or in relation to certain matters to do with off-shore seabed resources. They could have been dealt with in this way rather than waiting for the legislation to be passed and challenged in a way I recall in relation to the trade practices legislation which led to the tribunal, the very key element in that legislative framework, being rendered virtually powerless for almost a year.

The second category of questions that can be put deals with those matters which are perhaps crucial to the working of our parliamentary democracy, such as section 57, the double dissolution provision, sections which deal with the alterations of the boundaries of States or the referendum section, section 128. All of these sections-I do not have time to detail them-fairly bristle with clauses, phrases and conditions precedent which can cause misgivings and which cry out for interpretation. If it were the case that the High Court could be approached to give an advisory opinion as to those particular meanings we could be saved the trauma of some activity of a momentous nature being undertaken in relation, for example, to double dissolutions or as to the proposal of a matter to be put to the people, only to find later that that action was based on quite ill conceived, unconstitutional grounds. Even if nothing can be done, of course, the bitterness and the controversy which is generated in those circumstances can be most debilitating to our democratic institutions, as indeed we have had some recent experience of. I commend that category of matters being able to be put to the High Court for an advisory opinion.

There is a further category that at the request or with the consent of either House of Parliament any question of law concerning the qualification or disqualification of members may be put to the High Court. Indeed, there is a Senate committee report on the very matter of disqualification of members of parliament. Once again, there are very grave difficulties in borderline areas- for example, to do with offices of profit and dual nationality-which if they could be resolved by an advisory opinion of the High Court at the request or with the consent of the House concerned would avoid needless difficulties. Of course, it is always necessary to recognise the primacy of the House in relation to these matters and the membership of each chamber. The fourth category is quite new; that is, that any question of law arising under, or with respect to, any treaty, including any question of law relating to the implementation of any treaty, may be referred to the High Court. In the light of recent events over the past weeks and months one can see the virtue in that proposal. Indeed, the framers of the Constitution recognise that the High Court ought to have a jurisdiction in relation to these treaties. Section 75 of the Constitution states:
In all matters-(i) Arising under any treaty: the High Court shall have original jurisdiction.

For various reasons that section has fallen into some disuse; it has been something of a dead letter. The question is whether the jurisdiction might not be usefully revived by the conferring of this advisory jurisdiction in relation to questions of law arising under a treaty or a proposed treaty. Indeed I can see great benefit in the Commonwealth Government being able to seek the advisory opinion of the High Court as a prelude before embarking on some course of action in reliance on a treaty. Why ought it not be the case that the High Court indicates where, within the Federation, lies the legislative or Executive power to carry out the international obligation which has been assumed by the signing and ratifying of the treaty? There are instances in Canada and India where the supreme courts have most usefully discharged this function and enabled both those countries to understand the way in which an international obligation may be discharged within the federations concerned.

I could refer to some other matters but I think I have discharged my obligation to the chamber by outlining my understanding of the proposal. Basically, it boils down to the fact that we live in an indissoluble Commonwealth which is governed by the Constitution. It ought to be possible and it seems to me to be most beneficial for the Commonwealth Government, after due consideration by Cabinet, to approach the High Court to ensure that we act, whether legislatively or through Executive or parliamentary activity, in accordance with the Constitution. In other words, this is a preventive jurisdiction which will prevent us from committing ourselves to some course of action, as I have said, either legislatively or through the Executive, which, after the event, is found to be unconstitutional with all the disarray, trauma and difficulty within our internal federal relations which that might cause. We ought to be able to go to the highest judicial tribunal and seek its earliest possible opinion as to the constitutional propriety of a particular course of action. That is what will be achieved when this proposal is endorsed by the people, as I am confident it will be. I think it will be to our benefit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address my remarks to the Constitution Alteration (Fixed Term Parliaments) Bill 1983 and also to touch upon Senator Peter Rae's private member's Bill, the Constitution Alteration ( Appropriation Bills) Bill 1983. The private member's Bill on fixed term parliaments, which I ultimately supported last November, in its original form sought two objectives. First, it sought to strip the Senate of its power to reject Supply and, secondly, to provide for a fixed term for the House of Representatives. According to surveys the second objective now has popular appeal. In fact, some surveys indicate that over 70 per cent of the population are in support of the concept of a fixed term parliament. One suspects that the former objective to strip the Senate of its power to reject Supply does not have the same popular support. Since Federation the Australian public has been educated to believe that the checks and balances in a system where both Houses have roughly co-equal power offer a security that is not to be underestimated.

SPEECH.PARA: Since 1975 the Australian Labor Party has been preoccupied with the subject of reducing Senate power. One suspects that the real motivation of the original Evans Bill was to limit the Senate's power under the camouflage of the popular appeal of providing a fixed term for the lower House. We said on that occasion that they are separate issues and that the Bill should be stripped of all but the provisions relating to fixed terms. I supported the amended Bill as an endorsement of the principle that, subject to limited circumstances, a government elected for three years should serve for three years. I believed that the Bill provided a reasonable formula upon which that principle could work.

As this Bill is materially that which I supported before and as I have not been dissuaded from my view that a more stable system of government with less uncertainty will result from the Constitution being so amended, I will vote for it. The majority of my colleagues are of a different mind. I respect their arguments but, in my view, the arguments for change are more compelling. There may be some honourable senators on the other side of the chamber who support my colleagues but, of course, under the Labor Party system of discipline we will never know. The freedom we have in the Liberal Party to stand and put a contrary view in this place is something I hope will be never lost. I am sure that that is recognised and supported by the Australian people.

The arguments for the principle of fixed term parliaments are well known. I wish to do no more than restate in summary those that I found particularly compelling. First, the fact that a Prime Minister will not be able to call early elections at will should result in fewer elections. I understand that the average term of the House of Representatives is now approximately 2.4 years. Too many elections are an unnecessary diversion of public energy and finance. Secondly, I believe-I think consistently with the first argument-that elections for the House of Representatives and the Senate should be held simultaneously. Early elections for the House of Representatives can throw the Houses out of alignment, as has now again occurred. As a result, a separate Senate election- the fifth since 1949-will have to be called, or the House of Representatives will have to be called out early, probably on the same argument that was used by the Liberal Party in 1977 to get the Houses back into sequence.

Thirdly, the proposal would remove from a Prime Minister the power of shortening his term on the basis that he assesses the time is ripe for maximising his chances for re-election. I believe that governments are elected to govern both in difficult and in good times. The public has the right to judge the performance of a government over a full term. Fourthly, it would remove the uncertainty and speculation of early polls.

TALK.START.PARA: —How does it do that? A Prime Minister could manipulate an election under the fixed term proposal.
—Only by creating a vote of no confidence in himself.
—But he could do it.

—Potentially he could do it, but I think most honourable senators would concede that it is unlikely. It has to be rare that governments would want to vote themselves out of office. I repeat my fourth argument which I believe to be of particular significance. It removes the uncertainty and speculation of early polls which I believe inhibits business confidence and, I know from experience, retards the efficient functioning of the Parliament. I therefore reach the conclusion, prima facie, that the concept is commendable. Against that argument, of course, I have to evaluate my arguments first against the concept and secondly against the mechanics of the Bill. The first argument and the most emotive for reasons of public confidence and security is that it will reduce the power of the Senate. I have even heard it argued to the extent of proclaiming that all that would be left would be the equivalent of a House of Lords. The Australian Senate is an extremely powerful second chamber. It is rare among second chambers in that it can reject or, on the 1975 precedent, withhold Supply . In other words, it can stop the effective functioning of a government that retains the confidence of the lower House. The rationale for this power lies in the view held by some at Federation that the Senate was a States' assembly-in fact, it originally was to be called the States' assembly-that it was to have custody of the States' interests, that its existence was necessary to protect the interests of the smallest States and that to do so it required adequate powers.

SPEECH.PARA: For many of the delegates at the original Conventions adequate powers were equal powers, thus including pewer to initiate and to amend money Bills, but the compomise reached was power to reject Supply. Whether that is valid today must be questioned. I ask for examples to be shown to me of the smaller States joining together to force the people's House, reckless of their interests, to move in another direction. That does not mean that there may not, in the evolution of the Senate, be contemporary and valid reasons for retention of such powers. Under this Bill, however, the need to examine such justifications is unneccessary because it does not remove the power to block Supply. It is however argued by some that the destruction of the power of the Senate lies in the fact that in practice the Senate will not exercise its power if it cannot force an election. If the House of Representatives is elected for a fixed term, it will not be able to force an early election. In the original Australian Constitutional Convention debates is a remarkable absence of discussion as to what happens if the Senate rejects Supply. The impression one gets is that the Government and lower House would be forced to a compromise that would not be in conflict with the interests of the smaller States.

It is interesting that Mr Sinclair, the Deputy Leader of the National Party, at the recent Constitutional Convention in Adelaide argued that the fixed term concept for the House of Representatives would actually increase the Senate's power. Without the Prime Minister having the option to call an early election, a government would be forced to a compromise. Certainly some delegates at the early Conventions did speak of the government being responsible to both Houses- the people's House and the States House-which suggests ultimately an obligation on government to go to the people if it cannot maintain Supply by virtue of rejection by the Senate. However, very few would argue today, and I certainly would not attempt to argue, that the Senate should be able to force the House of Representatives to an election if the Senate is not to go to the people at the same time. Because of the Senate's protective fixed term that is unlikely unless a double dissolution mechanism is in place. As the existing double dissolution provisions remain under this Bill it is, therefore, difficult to see how, to any real extent, Senate powers are reduced by the Bill.

The second argument that is put forward and is somewhat related is that a fixed term will introduce a grey area in that there will be no clear mechanism for resolving a stand-off where the Senate rejects Supply and the Government will not compromise. At the recent Australian Constitutional Convention in Adelaide, which I have just mentioned, the New South Wales Opposition, through its shadow Attorney-General, stated:
The New South Wales Opposition is favourably disposed to the fixed term concept for parliaments.
Mr Kennett, the Leader of the Opposition in Victoria, stated:
The Liberal delegation here also believes very much in the principle of fixed term parliaments.

I might say in passing, in case I feel somewhat alone, that the concept also has the support of the Young Liberal Movement in Australia and has recently gained the support of the South Australian division of the Liberal Party of Australia by a majority in the ratio of approximately two to one.

TALK.START.PARA: —You knew Mr Kennett's proposal could have forced-

—I am about to come to that. Both the New South Wales Opposition and the Victorian Opposition were concerned with the Bill-I think that will cover the points Senator Martin wishes to make-because there is-
—Are you aware that Mr Kennett's proposal would have taken the Senate to an election if the Government fell in the House of Representatives?

—Yes, I am. I have already said I would regard that point as totally unsatisfactory. I have heard very few attempts to justify it. The New South Wales Opposition and the Victorian Opposition were concerned with the contents of this Bill. They support the principle of fixed term parliaments but they are concerned with the contents of this Bill for the reason that there is not such a formula for resolving a conflict. I acknowledge this grey area which to me is unsatisfactory, but in much the same way the present Constitution is unsatisfactory. To me there is now a major grey area. As I said, I do not believe the Senate by itself should force the House of Representatives to the people. I am not at all sure that the Governor-General would override the convention that he must act on the advice of the Prime Minister, particularly in view of the recent experience in relation to the last double dissolution where the Governor-General accepted the recommendation of the Prime Minister that both Houses be dissolved under the deadlock provisions of section 57 when it might be said that the only things that were dead were the Bills themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, I have considerable doubts that the Governor-General would dissolve the House of Representatives whilst the Prime Minister maintained the confidence of that House in a non-double dissolution situation. So a grey area exists now and will exist afterwards. It will not be resolved until the Australian people wrestle with the separate issue that either the Senate must cease to have power to reject Supply or the Constitution provides what will happen if in fact it does so reject Supply. Senator Peter Rae's Bill provides a solution. It gives the people the opportunity to say that they want the Senate to retain this power and, if it exercises that power and if it takes this major exercise of responsibility, both Houses should go to the people. I hope that Bill will be supported by the Government so that the Australian people will have an opportunity to say whether or not they support a mechanism that will, for the first time, clearly indicate what is to happen in relation to a stand-off.

Returning to the arguments that are put against the concept of fixed term, thirdly, it is said by some that the Bill will remove from the Governor-General a discretion and that that is undesirable. As I think I have indicated, that causes me little concern because the basis under which the Governor-General will now act is shrouded in mystery. I support the principle of providing certainty within our Constitution wherever possible. The fourth argument I wish to touch upon is the notion of a fixed term being contrary to the principles of the Westminster system of government. The government practised at Westminster is unique. Certainly the system of government in Australia is not pure Westminster but modelled on it only in part and in part on the Federal system, with snippets of others and aspects not found elsewhere. Therefore, no question of contaminating the pure Westminster occurs by the introduction of this Bill. But further major tenets of Westminster are also not interfered with by the Bill: The Parliament remains elected for a defined period and the Executive's continuation in office depends upon the continued support of the people's House. To that extent the Bill does not provide for an absolute fixed term, as happens in the United States. The Bill in fact does not result in the loss of characteristics of the Westminster system that are important to be preserved in our system.

I will mention a few of the other arguments. It is said that the Government will not be able to go to the people for a so-called mandate or because times have become difficult and difficult decisions have to be taken. Almost without exception this has meant an assessment by the Prime Minister that an early election will be of benefit to him. I believe it is time that he no longer had that option. Similarly, it is said that a Prime Minister with a small majority will not be able to go to the people to strengthen his hand. I think that again it is time the myth was put to rest that it is impossible to govern with small majorities. Therefore, when I had to balance the arguments for the concept of fixed term parliaments against the current system it was clear to me that a change was justified and, in fact, called for.

When I look at this Bill I find areas which I believe are capable of improvement. Nevertheless a fair attempt to implement the principle exists and I firmly support that. I am concerned that in the event of a double dissolution the new parliament will sit for only the balance of the term. One of the objections to the current system is that we have too many elections. I cannot see why a new term should not end on the specified election day which is as near to the three-year term as possible. It means the term will be either a little over or a little under the three years, depending on when in the year an election is held. Consequential amendments would, of course, be necessary for the Senate.

I am also in favour of the David Hamer position which is that double dissolutions should be limited to cases of genuine deadlocks and that, therefore , the power should lapse three months after the grounds have been given, if the power has not been exercised. I understand that that will be put in an amendment to be moved in the Committee stage and I trust that it will receive the support of the Committee. However, as I have indicated, I have supported this Bill before in its present form and I will therefore support it today. If it becomes law I am confident that it will play a part in improving the structure of government in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating six constitutional alteration Bills in a cognate debate. They are the Constitution Alteration ( Fixed Term Parliaments) Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Inter-change of Powers) Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Advisory Jurisdiction of High Court) Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Removal of Outmoded and Expended Provisions) Bill and two private members' Bills. The one introduced by Senator Peter Rae is basically the Court proposal, as it has been called at the various constitutional convention. That Bill is called the Constitution Alterations ( Appropriation Bills) Bill. The other private members' Bill was introduced by Senator Mason and is called the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill. I wish to indicate briefly the position of the Australian Democrats in relation to these Bills and to concentrate my attention basically on the Bill introduced by Senator Mason.

SPEECH.PARA: I will deal with the first Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Fixed Term Parliaments) Bill. We had quite an extensive debate in the last Parliament on a similar Bill. The current Bill differs in a number of respects from the previous Bill. I think that in the Committee stage some fairly lively discussion will surround some of those changes. Some amendments will possibly be moved in the Committee stage and I think it would be appropriate to discuss those amendments in full at that time. The Australian Democrats will be supporting the Constitution Alteration (Fixed Term Parliaments) Bill. The types of reasons we find compelling are basically those which Senator Hill has just outlined and which were outlined at the beginning of the debate by Senator Evans.

We believe that the introduction of fixed term parliaments will disturb very little of the constitutional structure. There will still be the ability to have a double dissolution. There will still be the possibility of the government collapsing in the House of Representatives and a new one not being able to form. In that case a vote on a new government would be taken by the electorate. Basically, the situation will remain unchanged except insofar as there will be introduced into the system a fairly massive disincentive to go for the quick election, that quick opportunity to get another three years of power. A disincentive is basically what is being introduced. We believe the introduction of that disincentive into the system is appropriate. We believe it is a disincentive which, in 1983, is necessary. I believe if we look back over the last decade and compare our operations in this country to those well-known butts of jokes like the Italian Parliament we could well hang our heads in shame when we find that our activities in this country have been worse than those in other countries. We would find that we have in fact used and abused the present system . I believe the people are entitled to a far better system than the one we have now.

In essence, the Democrats' position in relation to the Constitution Alteration (Fixed Term Parliaments) Bill is that the people are entitled to vote on whether they want fixed term parliaments. That is the issue at point. The issue in this chamber is whether we will put to the people a question for their deliberation and for their sovereign vote. For honourable senators to deny, in this place, people that opportunity I believe is wrong and anti-democratic. For honourable senators to say in this place that they do not agree is perfectly democratic. For honourable senators to argue why they do not agree with the concept certainly is perfectly democratic. To say 'We will go out on the hustings during the election campaign and campaign against this proposal because we believe it is wrong' is a perfectly proper proposition. To say that people should not be allowed to have a vote on the matter is an anti-democratic attitude. That is basically the position of the Australian Democrats in relation to this legislation.

The other Bills-the Constitution Alteration (Inter-change of Powers) Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Advisory Jurisdiction of High Court) Bill and the Constitution Alteration (Removal of Outmoded and Expended Provisions) Bill-we believe have been generally accepted at the constitutional conventions and, therefore, are also appropriate and appropriately worded propositions to go to the people. I am rather disappointed in Senator Durack's comments that they are a great waste of time. That seems to me to be a rather backhanded comment on the great deal of time, energy and effort that have gone into these Bills over the course of a large number of the conventions that we have had up to date.

The fact that there will be a referenda vote on one issue which will cost a certain amount of money, I believe, gives us an impelling reason why we should look at a range of propositions going to the people at that time. Since people will be called out and the expenditure will be in the order of $21m it seems appropriate that there be a range of questions proposed which are adequate questions to propose. That is why, for example, the Australian Democrats will be supporting the proposition which Senator Peter Rae has brought forward. We believe that is an entirely appropriate proposition to put to the people. I think he has been able to demonstrate a great deal of support within the community for that proposition. It was argued by Premier Court of Western Australia at the conventions. It is a proposition which I think Senator Rae might very well be able to say has the support of his party. I do not know whether it has the unanimous support of honourable senators, but it has the support of his party. Therefore, he could very well say that he at least has the support of a considerable percentage of people in this country. Because of that, I think it is appropriate that that proposition be put to the people for their deliberative vote as to whether they wish to go down that track in relation to the problem of Supply. I will come to that matter a little later.

The Australian Democrats will be supporting the proposition contained in the Constitution Alteration (Fixed Term Parliaments) Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Inter-change of Powers) Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Advisory Jurisdiction of High Court) Bill and the Constitution Alteration (Removal of Outmoded and Expended Provisions) Bill and the idea that those propositions be put to the people. We will also be supporting the campaign that people vote in favour of those changes to the Constitution. We believe that they are changes which will enhance the operation of goverments in this country and that the Constitution Alteration (Fixed Term Parliaments Bill) will enhance not only goverment but also the power of the Senate. Senator Hill said that some people have suggested this. Close analysis of the operation of such a Bill reveals what I imagine is unintended result on the part of the Labor Party. It will increase rather than decrease the powers of the Senate. The Senate will gain the power to bend the House of Representatives to its will easier than it can already. At the moment the Prime Minister is entitled to go to the Governor-General if the upper House rejects Supply. What the Governor-General would do in those circumstances is a matter for conjecture.

TALK.START.PARA: —He would take his Minister's advice.

—We thought that he might take his Minister's advice. I do not want to canvass what the Governor-General may or may not do in such a circumstance. At the moment it seems to be somewhat in the lap of the gods as to where we might go if such a circumstance occurred. I presume that Senator Peter Rae, in bringing forward this Bill, is seeking to address himself to precisely what may happen in that type of circumstance. I believe that the notion of the fixed term Parliament will strengthen the power of the Senate, which notion the Australian Democrats support. When this Bill came forward on other occasions we stated our support and we will continue that support into the electorate. I hope that on 20 August there will be an affirmative vote on that issue. I do not wish to canvass that matter any more in depth. When we get to the Committee stage we will be able to spend some time looking at each item again very closely. Doubtless we will as this has become the custom in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to Senator Peter Rae's Bill. As I have said, following the spirit of Senator Mason's Bill and the spirit that the Australian Democrats have shown in relation to constitutional alterations to come before this place, providing the question is a single question, providing it is compact and not misleading, providing that it is a properly formed question-Senator Hamer made an extremely valuable contribution on this item in the last Parliament in stating what would constitute a proper reason for going to the people-and providing it meets the types of criteria here outlined we would support its going to the people. However, we are not quite sure why the Opposition has brought forward this Bill at this time. One could conclude that the Opposition has some views on the rejection of Supply, possibly in the August session of parliament, and wishes to canvass this issue at that time possibly for a rerun of The Dismissal program. This point horrifies me and leads me to reiterate that the Australian Democrats in the Budget session will vote for Appropriation Bill (No. 1).

Senator Rae's proposed amendment to the Constitution would bring about a fundamental change in the balance of power between the two Houses. In fact it would be such a fundamental change as to make the Senate certainly the most powerful House in the Federation. It would be such a powerful House that it would be entirely appropriate under such circumstances, if Senator Rae's proposition is carried, that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer reside here and not in any other place.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not more powerful than the Tasmanian Legislative Council.
—I am sorry. Nothing is more powerful than the Tasmanian Legislative Council.
—Other than the Queensland one.
—There is no upper House in Queensland. That disappeared.
—Which explains a lot.

—It does explain a lot. We believe that the current system is inappropriate. At present if the Prime Minister, having the confidence of the House of Representatives, wants to call an election for both Houses the Senate must have rejected at least one Bill and rejected it again on recommittal after the appropriate period. In the meantime if the Senate had the numbers to delay such a Bill-it has done so in the past-it could drag out the operation if it wished to do so. How much power the Senate might have in that regard is a matter for debate and discussion. The move that Senator Peter Rae is suggesting would not be appropriate at this time. If the fixed term Parliament is to have an opportunity to work and to work well it deserves some time to work on its own without the additional impetus of Senator Rae's Bill. We hope that the fixed term situation, together with possibly more sane politics in this country, may overcome the problems that arose in 1975. We delude ourselves if we believe that we will be able to draw up a Constitution which will take account of every vagary of human nature and every wile and act of deviousness that can be used to manipulate the Constitution to the advantage or disadvantage of a party or group . However, we can attempt, in sensible debate and in rational ways, to change the Constitution from time to time to make sure that it takes account of modern thought and new ways of getting the best government for this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to Senator Mason's Bill. I refer firstly to the comments made early today by Senator Durack on why this Bill was not receiving the support of the Opposition. Senator Durack commented that the first thing people would vote on would be proposition 13. This demonstrates the paucity of understanding of what we are about and what this Bill is about. I understand that Senator Missen will also object to this Bill and we certainly look forward to a more in-depth and intelligent contribution than the one from Senator Durack. Proposition 13 was passed in in California in 1978. Only two other States in the United States of America ever passed a similar proposition-Idaho and Massachusetts. Six States rejected it, two twice. Of couse what many people fail to note is that proposition 13 concerned a land tax and the people of California were entitled to do precisely what they liked. At least they had a chance to vote on the matter. In 1980 a proposition put to them to halve income tax lost in an overwhelming vote.

What lurks under Senator Durack's proposition is a distrust of people. They cannot be trusted to run their own country or to say what they would like about tax. What Senator Durack is saying is: 'If we had this the people would put up a proposition 13 and support it'. If that is what the people want why does not Senator Durack support it now? We are supposed to be representatives of the people. That is what the people want; that is what we should support. What the Democrats are saying is: 'Let the people decide on this issue. Let them have a decision-making process in which they have a voice on individual items and let them state their will in their country'. It is extremely important that that occur.

People may not trust their legislators; they may not trust Cabinets; they may not trust the Prime Minister. But they certainly trust themselves. It is this trust in their decision-making process that we must not denigrate. I remind honourable senators that we are discussing a number of Bills fundamental to this country. When we refer to the fundamental points in this country, what do we do? We go to the people and ask them. When we refer to our Constitution, the most fundamental document in this country, we ask the people what their view is. Presumably Senator Lewis is not denigrating that procedure. Accordingly, even people who feel that most political decisions should be made by experts, presumably in this circumstance, ought to think again before they say that the people should not have this opportunity.

We believe that the cure for the ills of democracy is more democracy, not less. The people must be able to insert themselves into the decision-making process. We need to develop our democracy and take it to further points which will enable people to assess important issues such as uranium mining, abortion and the Tasmanian wilderness-important issues that do not sit with political parties or any political group. These issues cut across political parties, always have done so and always will do so. But many of those items are in many ways not even appropriate items for political party controversy. Some of them either go over the top or they go right the way through; they are issues of conscience and of fundamental concern to the entire population. It is on all these issues, and these issues alone, that people would be asked these questions because of the nature of the Bill that Senator Mason has introduced. If it goes to the Committee stage we will have an opportunity to debate it further.

I believe that if this opportunity is available, many of those hot and controversial issues-extremely difficult issues for political parties ever to face; ones which we shy from because of the controversy contained within them and because of their divisiveness-would be likely to come to the fore. They have indeed come to the fore, when one looks at the history of this operation in the various States of the United States of America. Of course, this process applies not only in California but also in the 26 other States of the United States. Many other countries have a much more elaborate initiative process than we have. The referendum is an initiative process. It is a government initiative process. We are looking to extend that to allow people to initiate that process. To enable that to occur there must be reasonable mechanisms so that we know that it is an important issue. We have always canvassed the proposition that it is best in terms of expenditure to have these propositions linked as closely as we can to general elections. In this way people would be asked not only to vote for the political party of their choice to govern the economy but also on those occasions to cast their vote on important issues of concern to the entire country.

It is sometimes said about our citizens, and I am not one to agree with it, that there is apathy and alienation in regard to the political process. If there is apathy and alienation I believe that as politicians we must take some of the blame, if not all of the blame, for that occurring. Simply taking the blame is not a useful attitude to take. When one diagnoses a problem one needs to come up with some solutions. What types of solutions might there be? Senator Mason has suggested, I believe from in a comparative study of world politics, that solutions exist in other countries, and they are used constantly. People are able to assert themselves on these issues. There is the ability for a legislature to ignore the wishes of the people, or indeed to put aside entirely an issue that is too hot or controversial. At those times that government in many ways turns people off. For example, in relation to the issue of taxation raised by Senator Durack, people are turned off because time and again political parties go to elections and say: 'We will lower taxes'. When they go into government what happens? They raise taxes. It happened with the previous Government. In every election campaign it said 'We will lower taxes', and after every election in seven years it raised taxes to heights which have never been seen before in this country. This Government went to the people and won a mandate on the basis of lower taxes. We will probably find out later tonight that the Government intends to raise taxes. The cynicism of the operation turns people away from the political process. I believe that if people could become involved in issues such as the tax issues, they certainly would. They would certainly make sure that politicians and parliaments were kept honest on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —They might abolish tax altogether.
—People are not stupid.
—That is an unworthy suggestion.

—That is a totally and utterly unworthy suggestion. People are not stupid; they have shown their capacity to make extremely intelligent judgments. It is their country and they should be allowed to make those decisions. It is a denigration of the entire population to say the people would vote out all taxes. It shows the absurdity of the honourable senator's proposition. Senator Missen should look at what happened in California. The proposition for higher income tax was lost overwhelmingly because the people understood.
—People understood very well why, too.

—They know why. They are not fools; they know what is going on in their own country. They know they pay taxes and that they need to pay taxes if they want social services. But they know the level at which they want to pay taxes and what they want done with them. Senator Missen says that they should not be allowed to have this right because they might lower their own taxes. That is the most extraordinary proposition I have ever heard from someone who says he represents the people. It is one that Senator Durack and Senator Missen put. The public interest in this regard is not being adhered to by the Labor Party, the Liberal Party or the National Party of Australia. I challenge any honourable senator to come with me on to a public platform before the citizens of this country and argue that the people sitting in that hall should not be allowed a citizens' initiative. If that honourable senator got out with his shirt on his back, good luck to him.
—They wouldn't dare.

—They would not say to those people: 'You should not be allowed, by petition, to put forward a proposition for a deliberative vote of the entire country'. That is what we will do if we vote against this measure. We would be saying to the people: 'You should not be allowed, by petition, to put up a proposition'.
—Of course you are saying that.
—That is what we would be saying.
—Let them have the choice.

—Let the people have the choice to say whether they want this power. That is what we are asking of the people in this Parliament. That is what we are asking of the Government and of the Opposition. Let the people say whether they want this choice, not whether we believe they should or should not have it. Let the people say whether or not they should have this choice. The Opposition should test its proposition where it counts-where the people cast their votes. The Opposition was talking about testing it out. Time and again Senator Walters said: 'Let us test this proposition.' If this proposition is put on 20 August every honourable senator in this place knows it will be carried overwhelmingly. They know that, and that is why they are afraid to put it. The central argument-let us not have any quibbles about this-that is being put in this place by politicians is that this question threatens the control of the political system. That is basically what they are saying. The political system that we have here would be threatened by the involvement of the people. This extension of the democratic process would threaten our cosy power. That is what those people are saying and they are scared stiff of testing that theory at a referendum.

SPEECH.PARA: In a free society such as ours the guarantee of the initiative is the vital cornerstone of democracy. It will come in this country, as it will come in every other democratic and free country. The people who are holding it up now are holding up the tide of history but it will not be held up indefinitely. Kings have disappeared, presidents have disappeared and the operation of this type of democracy will disappear. As we have more and more informed electors they will demand more and more power, and in getting that power they will demand more and more information. Essentially what will happen is that we will not have an open government, we will not have that enormous and overwhelming demand for information from government and we will not have the demand to sweep away the secrecy of government behind closed doors until people have that power. When they have it they will seek to know more of what is going on and they will seek to insert themselves more and more into the political process. That, after all, is what we ought to be about.

We ought to be about making sure that every person in this country is concerned about politics, is concerned about his country and is concerned to have a vote and to be interested and informed. That is the ultimate; that is the ideal and we must not put it aside or put blinkers on. We must seek ways to bring that about. It is not good enough to say 'Let's have a little education program' or something like that. Basically, education will not work. The power must exist. We all know of the movement that took place in women's rights from the time that women gained the power to vote. When ordinary people gained the power to vote in Britain, and of course in Australia, we all know what happened. Ordinary people came to the fore; not only the rich and moneyed classes involved themselves in politics but also ordinary people were elected to parliament. When this occurs ordinary people will concern themselves in their own work places on these vital, controversial and difficult issues. Finally, they will want to go in and say yes or no to whether Australia ought to have a uranium industry. When we get to that point I believe we will have moved a long way ahead in the development of our democracy. I hope, as a final appeal to the Senate, that it supports this Bill so that at least we can test the will of the people on this issue. Let us not take from them the opportunity to say, 'Yes, we do want this advance; we do want this power'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak on the six Bills before the Senate at the moment. Of course, there being six Bills it is impossible to deal at any length with the arguments involved. Of course a number of arguments have already been expressed. I certainly support the views of my colleague Senator Hill on the most important of the Bills before us to amend the Constitution. I refer to the Bill relating to fixed term parliaments. I support that Bill as I support the Government's other constitutional amendments. I will get to the other Bills a little later.

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite right that the Government should bring forward a Bill that tries to overcome a problem which has remained dormant for a number of years but which could always rear it ugly head again. I applaud the attempt to change the Constitution to allow for fixed term parliaments. Despite the rather belaboured attempt by the former Attorney-General, who kept calling it Senator Evans's Bill and Senator Evans's idea, it is really Senator David Hamer's idea that is before us. He was the one who brought forward the proposal for fixed terms, finding in that a solution to a number of problems. The solution will not be satisfactory to everybody and many people will find problems that this legislation does not entirely overcome. On the other hand, it is a genuine compromise to overcome the dangers which have been found by our constitutional process a number of times in the past, particularly in 1975, and to overcome a period in which we have had only a short time between elections, uncertainty and insecurity. We have seen that for years, and now it can be brought to an end.

I will deal very briefly with some of the arguments in regard to that. However, last year I made a second reading speech on a Bill proposed by the Attorney- General (Senator Evans)-the Constitutional Alteration (Fixed Term Parliaments) Bill 1981. I reiterate part of what I said in my second reading speech of 25 March 1982, at page 1239 and following of Hansard, and stand by the arguments which I then expressed. I set out the need for us as politicians to find some sort of reasonable solution to the problems which have faced the Constitution in this area. I then applauded the Bill but pointed out that it needed alterations. As we all know, the Senate made alterations to the Bill; it removed provisions in regard to Supply and the Governor-General's powers that would only have had the effect of adding fuel to the flame of opposition to the Bill. Now the Senate has before it another Bill, which is almost a replica of the Bill passed by the Senate in 1982 with the support of six Liberal senators but which, of course, did not proceed and was not debated at all in the House of Representatives during the last Parliament.

What we do know now is that, following recent events and following an attempt by a Prime Minister to use the opportunity to have an early election and not to go the full term, we have increased argument in favour of the fixed term proposition. As is clear from gallup polls, something like 70 per cent of the people say that they believe in fixed terms and they want to see them. Of course it is part of the belief of many people that, when we have a referendum proposal , if we manage to confuse the people and bring up arguments from time to time they all get worried about it and thereby one side may not get the majority it seeks, or not get a majority in a majority of States. I believe that this is one of the propositions which is firmly fixed in people's minds as a desirable need. It is one which I believe will, in the course of argument in the referendum period, hold up very well.

TALK.START.PARA: —They want fewer elections rather than fixed terms.
—They want fewer elections and they also want fixed terms. They see both things going together, and I am sure that both things will go together.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say in passing that the arguments for fixed terms were well summarised in a paper with which I think most honourable senators will be quite familar. It was prepared recently by Senator David Hamer. I mention five advantages to which he referred, which I think in summary are the main desirable features of this fixed term proposition. The first is that is solves the problem of simultaneous elections for the Senate and the House of Representatives, which has never been completely overcome and which has led us to having early elections to align the two Houses and which would lead to another election of this Parliament within two years unless we were to embark upon the curious idea of having a separate Senate election-a gallup poll election. No government not out of its senses would these days do that. So it will overcome the simultaneous elections proposition in a way that I think is better than the proposal of 1977, on which 62 per cent of the Australian public voted. However, the proposal carried a majority in only three States and narrow minorities in two other States. That is one excellent solution that this Bill provides. The second is that it removes an unwarranted political advantage from the incumbent government; that is, the advantage a Prime Minister has to choose his time, to go to an election when it is to his advantage. We know that sometimes Prime Ministers misjudge the situation.

The third advantage is that it should result in fewer elections. Earlier today Senator Durack expressed the view that this would not be so, that in fact we would probably get into the situation, as in West Germany, whereby there would be pre-arranged or artificial motions of no confidence and so further elections. I find that proposition extremely far fetched. I believe that if the fixed term proposition does not really give to any particular party any great benefit but leads to a government that is re-elected in an early election serving out only the time left to the end of the fixed term, then we will find both Prime Ministers and party leaders being discouraged from trying to have early elections for the House of Representatives. I also think that dissident groups that might otherwise be tempted to force an election will be very reluctant to do so, knowing that it will mean that they will have to face another election. As my colleague Senator Hill said, honourable senators will find in practice that there will be not more but indeed far fewer elections. There will be the regular election every three years, or four years, if we subsequently go to that position.

The fourth argument that Senator Hamer raised was that it was less likely that a hostile Senate would withhold supply as a means of forcing an unwarranted election. This argument has been taken further and I believe that it is correct. A fixed term parliament will provide little benefit in doing that. It will probably lead to the necessity for negotiation and discussion. Unless double dissolution Bills are before the Parliament we cannot, even at the moment, force the Senate out, but I think the withholding of Supply by the Senate will be much less likely if the fixed terms come into existence. The fifth argument, and the one that I regard as perhaps the most important, for fixed term parliaments, is the elimination of a prolonged period of uncertainty during which people ask: ' Will there or will there not be an early election?' We know the damage that this has done in this community. We know the way in which this matter has been dangled before the British people recently. Their Parliament has now gone to an election a year ahead of time for the benefit or what is thought to be the benefit of the present Prime Minister.

I mention also in regard to the fixed term proposition an amendment of which Senator Hamer has given notice, or of which he certainly has indicated his intention to give notice and which I likewise support. That relates to double dissolution elections. If double dissolution elections are to be held we have to ensure that they are based on genuine issues and not issues that have been put away in a back cupboard somewhere for a year or two and then brought forward with the claim that the Parliament is unworkable. I think the idea that we must use a double dissolution issue within three months or not use it at all-that we will otherwise lose the right to use it-is an excellent one. I trust that will commend itself to the Government and to the Australian Democrats. It seems to me to be an excellent improvement on the proposal which is presently before us. Otherwise, I believe that the fixed term proposition, which we debated at length last year, is an excellent one. I intend to support the Bill and to campaign vigorously for it in the course of the referendum campaign.

The other three proposals which the Government puts forward, although they deserve more attention now, will receive attention during the referendum campaign. I believe that they have general support in the Parliament. One, of course, is the Constitution Alteration (Inter-change of Powers) Bill. I was sorry to see that Senator Durack damned it a little with faint praise when he said: 'The States apparently want it, so perhaps it is all right, if we are to have a referendum'. It seems to me highly desirable that we should clear away the problems which at times over the years have discouraged the States from interchanging power with the Commonwealth and discouraged the Commonwealth from interchanging power with the States. The legislation makes it clear that the States will not lose their rights permanently. I think that altogether this proposal, which was carefully worked over by the Constitutional Convention, deserves strong support.

Likewise, I perhaps have some prejudice in favour of the Constitution Aleration (Advisory Jurisdiction of the High Court) Bill. That legislation was recommended not only by the Constitutional Convention but also in a report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. During my chairmanship of that Committee we examined, and found to be sound, the reasons for giving that power to the High Court. I have seen no valid arguments so far to indicate why that measure should not have very widespread support. It will provide a useful facility for the High Court and it will be valuable in determining the validity of Commonwealth Bills at a much earlier stage than might be the case if we wait until some litigant chooses to bring a matter before the High Court and then perhaps does not argue it very well. I think the legislation will enable Federal and State governments to obtain the opinion of the High Court as to the validity of their various legislation. The last of the four recommendations of the Government-to tidy up the Constitution, removing unnecessary provisions-I think is very uncontroversial indeed. I believe that it is highly desirable that the Australian people should support the four changes to the Constitution which the Government has proposed. I believe that they will have very widespread support.

I turn to the other proposals that are before us. The Constituton Alteration ( Appropriation Bills) Bill, which Senator Peter Rae has brought forward as a private member's Bill with the general support of the Opposition, has a quite long history. If flows from the Constitutional Convention in which, we will recall, there have been bitter battles over the years over two proposals-on the one hand the Whitlam proposal which would have taken away the Senate's right to block Supply and on the other hand the Court proposal which rigidifies the right of the Senate to deny Supply and ensures that if the Senate blocks Supply there will be an election. The good thing about the latter proposal, which the non- Labor majority was successful in passing through the Constitutional Convention, is that it overcomes the problem that at the moment the Senate can act irresponsibly by throwing out Supply Bills but, if there are not double dissolution Bills before the Parliament, cannot be forced to the people. That, of course, is an undesirable situation. A fixed parliamentary term will ensure that that does not happen.

I do not think that Senator Peter Rae's proposition-the rather complex Bill which has come from the Constitutional Convention and which is really in genesis the Court proposal of some years-has any real possibility of success in a referendum. It will obviously be voted very much along party lines. That has been the case in the Constitutional Convention. It will be seen as a means of strengthening the power of the Senate to refuse Supply and perhaps making that occurrence more likely. I do not propose to vote on that Bill. I believe that it is useless to present it to the people. Indeed, it may have the effect of confusing the electors and causing the defeat of other proposals. I trust that that is not its purpose. I believe that Senator Rae, who has pressed this matter for years, has tried to find solutions, but this is a solution which is seen by a very large proportion of the Australian people as placing the Senate's powers in an even stronger position. Therefore, I think it will on the whole be divisive.

I wish to say a few words about the sixth proposal which is before us-the participatory democracy proposal of the Democrats, known as the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill. It has superficial appeal. One could always go to meetings and say: 'Should you not be able to make the laws yourselves? Why do you leave it to members of parliament to make the laws? You should pass this Bill and then you can put up a proposed law and with 250,000 votes you can get it on the ballot'. Of course, it is easy because so many single issue groups in the community will be able to raise that amount of votes, and they draft the law. It is put in their terms, and if the terms turn out to be impractical and inoperable, we will be stuck with it. Honourable senators should read the terms of this Bill. In that situation, another referendum will have to be held. It is very interesting-I do not intend to speak at any length on this argument-to read a publication by the American Enterprise Institute for Public Policy Research in Washington, D.C., entitled 'Referendums-A Comparative Study of Practice and Theory', edited by David Butler of the Nuffield College, Oxford, and Austin Ranney of the American Enterprise Institute. These people have great knowledge of and authority in this area. Dealing with the operation of such a proposal in Switzerland, at page 42 they state:

A hundred thousand citizens can demand the revision of the constitution. The signatures, set out on a special form, must be collected within eighteen months (this rule was laid down only in 1978; previously there was no time limit). Generally speaking, initiatives are used for amendments to the constitution. The citizens put forward a full draft of the text of a new article or a new clause.
The significant aspect that is different from the proposal put forward by the Australian Democrats is this:

The Federal Assembly cannot change anything in this draft but can put forward an alternative of its own. The initiative needs assent by the majority of the people and of the cantons-and the same applies to the counter-proposal from the parliament.

There is no provision, or tying in of a provision, that this Parliament will have anything to say. The proposal is to move from parliamentary democracy to participatory democracy. It will take away the opportunity which we have in this Parliament to debate proposals such as those before us.
