We are elected by the people to put forward in the Parliament proposals and amendments to laws before they go to referendum. But in the Democrats' proposal, we either take it or leave it. Whatever is prepared by this shadowy group which gets 250,000 signatures will be the language that is put before the people. That is what will become the law and parliament becomes redundant. Honourable senators who read the details of this system will see that the Parliament cannot repeal the laws unless, of course, there is an absolute majority of each House of the Parliament and it is submitted to the electors. Of course, the Bill states:
When a proposed law is so submitted to the electors, the vote shall be taken in such manner as the Parliament prescribes.

What on earth does that mean? Does that mean that other parts of the Constitution, other requirements for the carrying of amendments, are not applicable? It is an altogether shapeless and unsatisfactory referendum proposal , one which would sound the death knell to parliamentary democracy in this country. I take up Senator Mason's challenge. I will argue this subject with anyone because it has not been argued. Superficially, it is appealing. Anyone who believes in the development of the Westminster system-the argument, creation , discussion and compromises which can occur in a parliament in the discussion of a Bill, and the way in a which interests can therefore be accommodated and recognised-will not agree with this Bill. It will be agreeable only to the group which introduced it. Once it is passed we may be stuck with it forever. It is a well-intentioned idea, but a dangerous one. I certainly oppose the matter being the subject of a referendum and oppose it altogether. I have indicated my attitude on these Bills. I trust that the major Bills will have a successful passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Six Bills are before the Senate, all of which seek a constitutional alteration. I support four, and oppose two, of the Bills. I wish to speak to one that I support and one to which I am very much opposed. I follow the lead of Senator Durack and Senator Rae, who have preceded me in this debate. Whilst I agree with many of the arguments put by my colleagues Senator Hill and Senator Missen, as I will outline, I disagree with some of their ultimate conclusions. The four Bills that I support set out proposals that were supported by the recent Australian Constitutional Convention held in Adelaide. The two that I oppose were not supported by that Constitutional Convention. The proposal of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) for fixed term parliaments was not supported by the Constitutional Convention. The Constitutional Alteration (Elector's Initiative) Bill introduced by the Australian Democrats was so preliminary and speculative that it was not even placed on the agenda of the Constitutional Convention. It certainly has not gained any swelling of public support in the nation.

SPEECH.PARA: One of two Bills to which I refer more particularly is Senator Peter Rae's private member's Bill-the Constitution Alteration (Appropriation Bills) Bill- which seeks to alter the Constitution to put into effect the amendment recommended by Standing Committee D of the Constitutional Convention-originally, the Court proposal, which seeks a solution by way of making the Senate more accountable when it may block Supply. I believe it is inappropriate for the Senate having, rightly, the power to block Supply in this Parliament, then not to be a part of the election that is forced as a result. I believe a general election should not be subject to the haphazard chance of double dissolution Bills lying about that can lead to the Senate and the House of Representatives facing an election, in the event of Supply being blocked; rather, expressly following the Senate blocking Supply, the Senate is accountable and must, as a whole, face an election. That is the nub of Senator Rae's Bill.

I am surprised that the Government is not supporting that Bill, because it is a matter that has been passed by a healthy majority of the Constitutional Convention. An amendment put by Senator Rae at that Convention was passed 46 votes to 32 votes. When the amended motion to accept the report of Standing Committee D on this matter was subsequently put, it was passed without a division, without protest and without dissent. That approving outcome should be compared with the advisory jurisdiction of the High Court proposal that was also considered by the Constitutional Convention and passed at one stage by 54 votes to 36 votes and, later, a revised proposal at the Adelaide meeting was passed by 51 votes to 35 votes. This has been described by Senator Evans as a substantial majority. He uses that substantial majority as one of the grounds for going ahead with the proposal for a referendum. I do not disagree with him that there was a substantial majority. I argue only that there is a like substantial majority with regard to Senator Rae's proposal. Why is it that the Government does not agree with that argument in this case also? In addition, I believe Senator Evans has put the proposal that his party would give such authority to the Constitutional Convention-that the Australian Labor Party in government would take up any constitutional proposal that is approved by the Convention and put it to the people at a referendum, and then let the people decide whether there is such a majority as there was on the floor of the Constitutional Convention. What happened to that undertaking or promise? It has been supported by the Constitutional Convention. Where is the support from the Government to put it to the people in a referendum?

The other Bill to which I will now address all of my remarks is what I call the Senator Evans fixed term parliament referendum proposal, which is the one that has been most contentious in debate around the country and certainly in this chamber. Its objective is to fix a date for the next election, which would be a simultaneous election in November 1985 for half the Senate and the whole of the House of Representatives and thereafter, on the third anniversary of that date to have subsequent Federal elections. Another provision in the Bill is that if there was an extraordinary election-the two grounds for this are set out in the Bill; the lack of confidence in a government in the House of Representatives or a double dissolution deadlock between the two Houses, as is presently set out in section 57 of the Constitution-the Parliament elected would be only a lame duck parliament and serve for only the remainder of the term of the previous Parliament. I will refer to that objective of the Bill later as being the most objectionable one and the one which I believe will be more and more understood over the coming few months and lead to this referendum proposal being defeated.

The Bill also seeks to guarantee simultaneous elections for the Senate and the House of Representatives. That in itself is a commendable proposal. I will refer to it again later. The Bill sets out the specific day in November, the third Saturday, when there would be an election every third year.

Whilst I oppose this Bill, I am not opposed to the principle of fixed terms per se. After all, this Senate has fixed terms of six years. I regret that only one of the 64 senators has actually served a full term. The other 63 of us have not. In the present circumstances, even those recently elected will not serve a full term. The fixed term principle in the Senate-it does not apply in the House of Representatives-can be seen by Australians to be lacking in fulfilment.

I am in favour of reform to overcome disabilities and serious inadequacies in the way in which the elections have been conducted and parliaments formed and concluded in the Commonwealth and in the States. I am responsive to the overwhelmingly popular view that in this country we are having too many elections. The most obvious example that people from all parties cite is the recent Commonwealth election in March 1983. Another example in my State of South Australia is the election called by the Corcoran Labor Government in 1979, which led to that Government being overwhelmingly defeated and to the Tonkin Government's term of office in South Australia. I believe that the people of Australia are dissatisfied with there being too many elections, not only because they are being called unnecessarily early and foreshorten parliamentary terms but also because they cause further elections once the Senate term and the House of Representatives term are put out of syncronisation. That is the case now. If there is no constitutional change, a Senate election must be held before July 1985 but the next House of Representatives election is not due until May 1986. So, there is a multiplicity of unnecessary elections. I believe that is the view of a majority of people in all parties.

I am also responsive to the popular view that the parliaments of Australia need a longer term. I believe that that will make for good and stable government and allow a government to implement its program without the necessity to look too quickly to whether it is gaining sufficient public approval to win a pending election. There has been an overwhelmingly expression of the view in Australia that we should move to four-year parliaments. This view has been expressed by both sides of this chamber. It is a view that has been expressed at the Constitutionl Conventions. In fact, at the recent Constitutional Convention in Adelaide that proposal was supported. It still leaves me confused and dismayed why the Government did not take up the four-year parliament proposal as the main priority for a referendum this year, rather than Senator Evans's fixed term parliament proposal, which I believe should have a much lower priority. I very much support the proposal for a four-year parliament.

I also wish to acknowledge honestly and straightforwardly that right now concern continues to be expressed in all parties about the circumstances of the March 1983 election. It is regarded as an opportunisitic election, the time of which was decided, with advice, by a Prime Minister for his own reasons and, presumably, to advantage my party, which was then in government. But it backfired on that Prime Minister. There was nothing in the Constitution to prevent him from choosing a time that he thought would be more likely to lead to victory. He did not have to wait for the end of the parliamentary term, which would have been towards the end of 1983. This ability of a Prime Minister of any persuasion to opportunistically choose a time to the advantage of himself or of his own party has this year raised even further the dissatisfaction of the people. The argument that it was necessary to have the March 1983 election in order to get a renewed mandate has also been seen by the people in all parties to be hollow. Those who in the future, whether in the Commonwealth or in the States, try to argue that they need a renewed mandate, I believe, will be treading on very shaky ground. They will perhaps suffer the same consequences as my party did in the recent election. Certainly, the people of Australia are not convinced by the hollowness of this argument that a fresh mandate is required.

There was also, in the recent March 1983 election, a technical use of the double dissolution ground that had built up in the preceding year. Indeed, the Prime Minister at the time straightforwardly acknowledged that he was not necessarily going to put the double dissolution Bills to a joint sitting and that they would not necessarily be the policy of the new Government that he would lead. Rather the Constitution allowed these Bills, having been twice refused by the Senate, to act as a trigger, as a technical device to allow a double dissolution of parliament. I believe that is not appropriate. It is not in the spirit of the original Constitution. I believe that the people of all parties are seeking to have their representatives in the Parliament deny that technical trigger. I support the amendment that I understand Senator Hamer is moving to provide that the trigger should lapse if it has not been activated in three months. I am also very conscious of the fact that the recent election this year led to even more expressions of disapproval at the way in which our Constitution allows a parliamentary term to begin and end. The people of Australia, of all parties, are calling for reforms.

Having said that by way of introduction, I now wish to say why I am directly opposed to the Constitution Alteration (Fixed Term Parliaments) Bill introduced by the Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans. Essentially I am opposed to this Bill because it provides that, in the event of an extraordinary election, the Parliament then elected will only serve out the remainder of its three years. It will not gain a full three years in office, a full fixed term or a full number of years-whatever term may be determined. I believe that this is counter- productive to the thrust of reforms that I have outlined as being those which the people of Australia are seeking to urge upon this Parliament. I believe that it should be the case that, if there is an extraordinary election, the Parliament then elected should have a full term to enact the proposals that it has taken to that extraordinary election at which it has gained the most recent mandate of the people. The first reason I am opposed to Senator Evans's Bill is that it leads to a lame duck parliament-a parliament that I believe would be unable to achieve the stable and good government for which the people of Australia are calling and which, for example, has led to the proposal for a four -year parliament.

Secondly, the Bill has the apparent objective of reducing the number of elections in Australia. But I believe that no honourable senator in this chamber would be able to demonstrate that that could be guaranteed. I believe it is likely to lead to more elections. Let me give one example: A parliament in the fixed term cycle is elected for a three-year fixed term. After two years there is an extraordinary situation, either a double dissolution trigger-that is, a deadlock between the two Houses-or a want of confidence motion in the Government is passed in the House of Representatives. There must be an election. One year later, when the three-year term has expired, there is another election. So within the space of three years there have been two elections, whereas under the proposal I am putting forward-about which Senator Hamer has written extensively and for which many others in the country give support-after that extraordinary election following a two-year parliamentary period there would be a full term of three years. So we would have two elections in five years and not two elections in three years. That is the more appropriate way to go. Senator Evans's Bill may indeed lead to more elections, not fewer elections.

Another aspect is that it does not deny an opportunistic Prime Minister or government to put before the Senate a Bill which, given the composition of the Senate, they know the Senate will deny. By so doing such a Prime Minister or government could still manipulate the terms of the Constitution, as set out in Senator Evans's Bill. That would allow them to have an election of their own choosing at a time of their own choosing and in the circumstances which I have already outlined and of which I believe the Australian public disapproves. The third reason I oppose this Bill is that I believe it will fail on 20 August. It will not gain a sufficient majority of votes in the country as a whole nor will it gain a sufficient majority of States.

Let me compare this with the simultaneous elections referendum of 1977 which was supported by both major parties. It was very well understood by the people of Australia. There was a great deal of common support for that proposal by political parties but it still failed. I put it to honourable senators that Senator Evans's Bill is much more contentious than that proposal. There are divisions in the Australian Labor Party about it. There is opposition from the Opposition parties, even though there are some honourable senators who may support it. I believe that Queensland and Tasmania certainly will not support that referendum. I believe Western Australia will not support it and I would regard South Australia and New South Wales at this stage as being hard to predict with perhaps 50-50 support for the proposal. Even then, speaking for my State of South Australia, the degree of support it would attract would be based upon misconceptions and an over-simplistic presentation of the apparent advantages of the Bill. I would not wish to deny that those South Australians who I think are likely, given all the propaganda of the next three months, still to support the Bill, would be doing so with full understanding of these grave disadvantages in the Bill.

I am not certain about the outcome of the referendum; nobody can be. but I am putting forward the view that, in the light of earlier examples, it is likely to fail. Yet if this $21m gamble is lost by Senator Evans and the Government we are doing an enormous disservice to parliament and constitutional reform in the country. The opportunity for referenda do not come to a parliament or the people of Australia every year. If this proposal is so fraught with difficulty and division that it is not likely to be supported by the people to a successful outcome, then it will be setting back the kinds of proposals that I outlined in the earlier part of my speech, such as a four-year parliament. Why does the Government not get behind proposals that have already gained a preliminary consensus in the Parliament or in the country, such as the four-year parliamentary term? This $21m gamble is irresponsible. I still implore the Government not to go ahead with that referendum and waste the opportunity that is before it.

It is said by some that 70 per cent of the Australian people have shown, in a recent public opinion poll, that they support the fixed term concept. That does not mean that 70 per cent of the people support Senator Evans's Bill. They are saying: 'The great majority of us in Australia are dissatisfied with the way in which you are calling elections too often. We want you to reform it'. They want us to come up with a solution that will not lead them to all the dissatisfaction that I tried to express at the beginning of my speech. I think it is quite wrong -it is invalid-to make the jump from that public opinion poll result to a supposed support for Senator Evans's Bill. This Bill only superficially meets the views that were the mainsprings of that 70 per cent public opinion poll. The Bill is deceptive and superficial in that it is seeking to try to pick up the public support that has been expressed in such public opinion polls. I believe that the task of the Opposition and many institutions and parliaments in Australia over the next three months is to so point up the deficiencies of Senator Evans's Constitution Alteration (Fixed Term Parliaments) Bill as not meeting genuine concerns that we ensure it fails.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, can I just get it right: The people will not be voting for a fixed term, they will be voting for an Evans Bill which will have other motives? Is that right?

—The honourable senator has put forward a view. I certainly agree with what he says. I believe it is quite easy for politicians to dress up Senator Evans's Bill to superficially appear to meet a plea by the Australian public to have fewer elections. I believe that that dressing up would be deceitful, superficial and simplistic. I hope that we may be able to enlighten the people of Australia because I believe they cannot easily be fooled.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to speak on two alternative proposals which I believe ought to be a part of the preliminary discussion that leads to a consensus on which such an opportunity as a referendum should not then be a gamble but should be one that is based upon a more certain prediction that it be passed. In the few minutes that remain I have not the time to go into this matter other than to make a few comments on the two alternative proposals. The first is that instead of this referendum we should have a referendum on a four-year parliament and that it may even be linked to a fixed date, say, November, but if there is an extraordinary election, such as a double dissolution, the term of the next parliament should be at least three years and not more than four years so that we get back into the pattern of the November elections again. I believe that that would be a sufficient full term and would achieve the arguments I stated earlier. It will also bring back the possibility of it being more likely to achieve the simultaneous elections reform that has already been put to the Australian people but which was denied because it implied that the Senate could too easily be taken out and have its term shortened.

In summary, I outline a four-year parliamentary amendment with fixed date aspect which I believe is to be preferred. An alternative-which would overcome the problem before us of the next Senate and next House of Representatives elections-would be simply to amend section 13 of the Constitution so that we have a once off amendment. This amendment should say that the next simultaneous election will be in November 1985 by extending the terms of present honourable senators to three and a quarter years instead of two and a quarter years for the short term senators and six and a quarter years rather than the present five and a quarter years of the longer term senators. These terms flowed because of the constitutional provisions linked with the date of March 1983 of the last double dissolution election. By that simple amendment-which I believe could gain the support of all parties in this chamber and could assure the public that there will not be this double election of the Senate followed by the House of Representatives, but rather one general election for half the Senate and the whole of the House of Representatives-we could achieve with much more unanimity the lessening of the number of elections.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating six Constitution alteration Bills, but I propose to confine myself in these remarks exclusively to the Constitution Alteration (Fixed Term Parliaments) Bill. Some two or three years ago I heard my colleagues Senator Hamer and Senator Missen talking about a fixed term parliament in favourable terms. I suppose that without thinking in depth about the subject I had come to think there was probably a lot of merit in the idea. I was then asked to be a speaker at the Third Annual Meeting of the Australasian Study of Parliament Group on the subject of fixed term parliaments and that required me, in order to make a speech to that function, to apply my mind in depth to the subject. The more I thought and read about it and applied my mind to the subject, the more opposed I became to the concept until by the time of the proceedings I was totally opposed to it. I have remained that way ever since. Senator Gareth Evans also addressed that conference, as did a number of other people. I seek leave to table the proceedings of the Third Annual Meeting of the Australasian Study of Parliament Group.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I shall come back to those papers in the course of my remarks. I put it to the Senate, and I shall in due course put it to the people of Australia, that this proposal is the first in a series of proposals which will be put by the Australian Labor Party over a period of years to disembowel this chamber. We should look at section 4 of the 1982 platform of the Labor Party which is headed 'Constitutional and Legal'. This appears on page 19 of the document. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The support of the Australian people will be sought for amendments to the Australian Constitution-
Paragraph 3 states:
To ensure that the Senate has no power to reject, defer of otherwise block money bills.
Paragraph 4 states:
To provide that the Senate may delay for up to six months, but not reject, any other proposed law.

Those two proposals would disembowel this Senate. It would not be worth while for the chamber to sit and we might just as well do away with it. Those are the Labor Party's objectives as set out in its constitution and adopted in the middle of last year. Let us look at how it proposes to achieve that objective. We are somewhat fortunate that a paper which was prepared by Dr Blewett of the other place actually was published and we were able to get a copy of it. It was published in 'Labor Forum', Volume 1, No. 1, Autumn 1978. This paper is entitled 'Dunstan shows the way in constitution reform'. Dr Blewett analysed what had happened in regard to so-called constitutional 'reform'. He indicated how he believed the Australian Labor Party could alter the Federal Constitution, our national Constitution, and set out the steps that it should take based on the success of the changes to the South Australian Constitution. Having stated a series of proposals for reform-some of which were adopted in the 1982 platform- he then goes on and says how to go about it. He states:
Labor needs to maximise the use of the 'hurrah' words in our political vocabulary in order to mobilise community support and to split its conservative opponents.
That is the first thing we will get-'hurrah' words. He goes on to state:
. . . the ALP should avoid spelling out the goals in minute detail, so that the party leaders can seize the opportunities of the moment to advance the basic strategy.

Again, the people will not be told what we are really aiming at. The people will just get vague ideas and whenever there is an opportunity the party leaders will be able to slip in and seize the opportunity of the moment. Dr Blewett said that there should be constant repetition of the goals. He went on to state:
In South Australia, Labor publicity and Labor speakers pressed relentlessly and tirelessly the constitutional themes.
Has that not happened? Ever since this paper was published in 1978 we have--

TALK.START.PARA: —Ever since Senator Gareth Evans came into the chamber.

—Ever since Senator Evans became a member of this chamber we have had this constant talk about changing the Constitution. It has been said that we must change the Constitution. Labor senators and members of parliament, Labor leaders, Labor journalists, Labor editors and Labor writers keep talking about the Constitution. I say seriously that the Constitution of Australia has served us very well for 83 years. This constant repetition of the idea that there must be a change is clearly designed as part of this strategy. That is what it has to do with. Some people on the other side of the chamber keep saying that it has to do with 1975. I shall come to that and prove beyond a shadow of doubt that this proposal has nothing whatsoever to do with 1975. But I will come to that. The next proposal is that there must be unity. Dr Blewett said:

SPEECH.PARA: There were . . . party differences in South Australia--
At that time-
But the differences never became public.

Back bench senators and members who have listened to this debate from time to time may have started to twig that there might be something wrong with this proposal of Senator Evans. They might not be quite sure because they do not really want to believe what Senator Lewis is telling them. They want to believe what their side is telling them. They think Senator Lewis might just have a point but they will not allow their differences to be exposed because the strategy is that differences must never become public. Dr Blewett also said:
Fourthly, Federal Labor must seize any opportunity that will serve the long term goal . . .

This is highly significant because he went on to say that in South Australia in 1977, or whenever it was, a proposal put by Mr Steele Hall led initially to the change to the South Australian Constitution.

TALK.START.PARA: —When was it?
—It was 1970.

—It was in 1970. This is very significant because Dr Blewett wrote an article which appeared in the Canberra Times on 22 April 1979 and in which he referred to proposals of Senator Hamer relating to fixed term parliament and also to not having Ministers in the Senate. In particular, it referred to the proposals for having a fixed term parliament. Clearly, Dr Blewett became aware of this proposal in 1979. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Hamer's proposals are simple and clear-cut.
I add that I do not know whether Senator Hamer will want to hear these words, but Dr Blewett went on to say:
While he is often irritatingly elitist, and both disrespectful and neglectful of the impact of party-
I do not quite know what 'impact of party' means-
. . . both his objective and his means are worthy of careful consideration.
I emphasise that he said:
. . . both his objective and his means are worthy of careful consideration.

Honourable senators can see what happened. The Labor Party saw this as an opportunity and it has leapt at it. I agree with what Senator Missen has said: These are not Senator Evans's proposals. These are Senator Hamer's proposals taken up by the Labor Party as a chance of furthering its long term aim of disembowelling the Senate, castrating the Senate, and making the Senate worthless. I go back to Dr Blewett's paper-these are not my words. The next section states:
Fifthly, it is necessary to dramatise and personalise constitutional issues . . .

Honourable senators should just have a look at what Labor Party members have done. They have constantly attacked the former Governor-General and the former Prime Minister in relation to so-called constitutional reform or change.

TALK.START.PARA: —Worn black arm bands.

—They have worn black arm bands, dramatised, and made matters personal issues. This whole strategy is clear once one reads Dr Blewett's paper. Let us come to the next section entitled 'A Symbolic Event'. Dr Blewett then talks about Sir John Kerr and says:

SPEECH.PARA: Kerr brings us to the sixth prescription-the need for an event as a symbolic focus for the constitutional struggle.

Dr Blewett then mentions Remembrance Day 1975. It is very interesting that Senator Gareth Evans first introduced this proposal on Remembrance Day 1975. Is that not proof that this is all part of the strategy set out by Dr Blewett in this paper? I will conclude with another quotation from Dr Blewett's paper which states:
Labor must corral the symbols of the Australian nationalism, because these will be critical elements in what is, in many ways, a cultural battle.

What has happened? Every time we look at the Labor Party we see that its motto shows an Australian flag with ALP written above it. Yet when we look at the Labor Party's platform we see that one of the first things it will do is to try to change the flag and our national anthem. Ultimately it wants to have a republic.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hypocrisy.
—As Senator Walters says, that is absolute hypocrisy in the Labor Party's platform. That is what it is all about.
—They are so ashamed they have all gone.

—As Senator Messner says, honourable senators opposite are so ashamed they have all gone except for the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) and one of my colleagues from Victoria who sits on the other side. However, let me put a parliamentary view. A fixed term proposal is intended to give the Executive-that is, the Government and not the Parliament-a fixed term of government of three years. That means that a government would not have to fear any perils of office. We could have a President Nixon with a Watergate situation. There would be no way we could force a government to an election. As long as a Prime Minister had a majority in the lower House we could have any sort of disaster but there would be no way to stop him. According to the proponents of this scheme, the Prime Minister of the day would be able to go on. This proposal is not to do with parliament. It is not to do with having fewer elections. This proposal is to enshrine the Executive in the House of Representatives-not the members of the House of Representatives but the parliamentary Executive-for a full term of three years, regardless of behaviour. I say to those back benchers who I hope are listening to the broadcast of proceedings: Why do you not think about this proposal? Do they really think that this proposal will in any way advance the Parliament? Do they think that this proposal will in any way give those people in the House of Representatives the opportunity to come forward and talk about parliamentary proposals? Does it not just enshrine the Executive in that House for a permanent period of three years? In my paper on the fixed term parliaments proposal which I have tabled and which honourable senators can look at if they want to read it, I said:

SPEECH.PARA: If Parliament is to survive, let alone prosper, it must maintain its independence.
I suggest that we should consider whether the fixed term proposal would go any distance towards giving the Parliament independence.
To those honourable senators who support this proposal I say:
. . . you are prepared to guarantee an elected government a term of 4 years, regardless of its behaviour. I do not see that as in any way advancing the freedom of the people . . .

Those honourable senators should remember that liberty and freedom of the people does not come from governments. If honourable senators look at the history of the liberty of the people they will see that it has always come from the Parliament. I go back to the time when, for the first time, the Parliament stood up to the King in Westminster and demanded freedom. In those days the King was the Executive. What the Government is now saying is: 'Put the King over there and let him stay there for three years regardless of what he does'. What happens , for example, if the King allows the Parliament to sit for only one day a year? What would happen in those circumstances?

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, fair go.
—Senator Grimes smiles and says: 'Fair go'. What would happen in those circumstances? Nothing. The Executive would still go on governing.
—Would not the members of parliament do something about it?
—What could the members of parliament do?
—You do not think much of the American system, do you?

—No, I do not think much of the American system. The interesting thing is that neither do a lot of American academics who want to change the American system. I have tabled in the Parliament papers which prove that. I was challenged by Senator Evans on that matter and I tabled the papers for him to look at. Let me come back to the papers that I have tabled because there are some interesting quotations in them. Professor Colin Howard, who put forward a paper, is certainly no supporter of this chamber, as honourable senators will hear. Let me read to the Senate what he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude by expressing that point of view without any ambiguity at all because I am as well aware as most of us, probably all of us, that the present eager interest being displayed in certain quarters in fixed terms for the House of Representatives is based much less upon a concern for fixed terms in themselves as upon a desire to use that reform as a device for reducing the powers of the Senate.
That is an interesting quotation from Professor Colin Howard. He added:
I am all in favour of reducing the legislative powers of the Senate . . .

He is in favour of reducing our powers. Yet he was able to point out honestly that the people who are putting forward this proposal are not interested in the fixed term concept; what they are interested in is limiting the powers of the Senate. In other words, Professor Howard was saying that this proposal was a mere device. Page 21 of Professor Howard's papers states what the Attorney- General said. The professor said that this proposal:
Would be more likely to be politically acceptable in the short term as a solution to the constitutional problems shown up by 1974 and 1975 . . .

Again this is another device apparently to deal with the situation that arose in 1974 and 1975. Let me now turn to that matter. Under the fixed term proposal, what would happen if some future Senate decided that it would block Supply and at the same time the House of Representatives-the Executive in the other place- said: 'We will not go to the people'? What if under our party system the Prime Minister of the day held his party together and said, 'No, we will force the Senate to pass Supply' and the Senate said: 'We will not give in'? Why will not people try to answer what would happen under the fixed term proposal?

TALK.START.PARA: —What would happen?

—That is the important point. Under the fixed term proposal absolutely nothing would happen. There would be no way that we could have an election. The government of the day would run out of money and this country would be in absolute chaos.
—What about the inherent powers of the Governor-General?

—I understand that the Governor-General must take the advice of his Prime Minister and the advice of the Prime Minister would be not to call an election. We could not get a change of Prime Minister because of the situation under the fixed term proposals. I believe there would be absolute chaos as this country ran out of money.
—You do not really believe that.
—People keep saying: 'You do not really believe it'. Of course I believe it.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 4 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Aviation aware of the concern expressed, particularly by local government spokespeople, over the use of the Perth Airport by KC135s during a recent military exercise.

(2) Is the Minister also aware that this concern is related not only to noise pollution but also to the fact that the Western Australian emergency services would not have the capacity to handle an accident involving one of these tankers .
(3) Are any more visits by such aircraft currently forecast and will the Minister consider some means of advising nearby residents prior to such an exercise.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am well aware of the concern expressed and felt by organisations and individuals around Perth Airport about the use of Perth Airport by KC135 aircraft, which is a tanker version of the C135 (an earlier version of the Boeing 707).
(2) I am also aware that the concern is caused by aircraft noise and by the fear of the consequences of an accident.

My Department provides emergency services at Perth Airport to the international Category 9 standard. This is the highest standard of emergecy service and is designed to handle adequately a Boeing 747. The total maximum fuel capacity of the KC135 is considerably less than the fuel capacity of a B747.

(3) A series of flights involving KC135 and WC135 aircraft has been approved to operate at approximately six monthly intervals. The most recent flights took place on 27 and 28 November last year. The WC135 aircraft collects air samples which are later analysed to determine if elevated levels of radioactivity are present in the atmosphere.

This is done to verify world wide compliance with the terms of the 1963 Nuclear Test Ban Treaty. On occasions a KC135 may be required to accompany the WC135 to provide fuel for an extra long range mission.

Each application to use Perth Airport, both for aircraft that are part of the approved series or are of occasional individual missions, is only approved if my Department is satisfied that no other airport can be used, that the flight is scheduled to cause the least annoyance, and that all noise abatement procedures are followed.
It is intended that, whenever possible, advance notice will be issued to the media on any exercise involving KC135 aircraft.
